caption: Supplementary Material 1: Figure 1.  Single-nucleus RNA (sn-RNA) sequencing analysis of the association between senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) (A) and mTOR expression (B) in different brain cells with factors including AD pathology, sex, APOE4 genotype, and ABCA1 expression (Related to Fig. 1).
description: Supplementary  Material  1:  Figure  1.  Single-nucleus  RNA  (sn-RNA)  sequencing  analysis  of  the  association  between  senescence-associated  secretory  phenotype  (SASP)  (A)  and  mTOR  expression  (B)  in  different  brain  cells  with  factors  including  AD  pathology,  sex,  APOE4  genotype,  and  ABCA1  expression  (Related  to  Fig.  1).
context_description: ABCA1 expression also correlated with SASP scores in the same human brain samples (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] A). Sn-RNA sequencing analysis also indicated that mTOR activation scores were positively associated with ABCA1 expression in astrocytes, excitatory and inhibitory neurons, microglia, oligodendrocytes, and oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B). AD characteristics, such as Braak stage, NFT burden, and neuritic plaque burden, were also positively correlated with mTOR activation in excitatory neurons (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B), where APOE4 was associated with increased mTOR expression in excitatory neurons, oligodendrocytes, and pericytes (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] B).
pub_title: Cellular senescence induced by cholesterol accumulation is mediated by lysosomal ABCA1 in APOE4 and AD

The  negative  control  refers  to  omitting  the  primary  antibody. Beta-actin  and  Na  +/K  +  ATPase  were  used  as  markers  for  different  fractions.  (C)  Total  membrane  ABCA1  and  caveolin-1  protein  levels  in  human  postmortem  mid-frontal  lobe  tissues  were  detected  by  WB.  (NCI  E3/3,  n=33;  NCI  E3/4,  n=19;  AD  E3/3,  n=44;  AD  E3/4,  n=42.  One  sample  labelled  with  a  star  was  excluded  as  it  had  MCI)  (Related  to  Fig.  2).
context_description:
Using SenTraGor (STG, a reagent for detection of lipofuscin) [ 50 [rid=CR50] ] staining in postmortem human brain slices (mid-frontal lobe region) from ROS, we observed higher STG intensity in GFAP-positive astrocytes in AD participants compared to NCI participants with the APOE3/4 genotype (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] A, the STG/GFAP staining test is shown in Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] A), corroborating the increased astrocyte senescence markers in AD observed in the transcriptomic data. 
Given that ABCA1 is predominantly localized in cell membranes [ 51 [rid=CR51] ], cytosolic proteins were removed (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] B, Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] B). Total membrane ABCA1 levels were higher in APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 carriers with AD dementia than in APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 carriers in the NCI group (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] B; full blots are shown in Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] C). 
In human postmortem middle frontal lobe tissues, caveolin-1 protein levels were higher in both APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 carriers with AD dementia than in the NCI group, although there was no difference between the APOE3/3 and APOE3/4 genotypes in either group (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] M; full blots are shown in Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] C).
pub_title: Cellular senescence induced by cholesterol accumulation is mediated by lysosomal ABCA1 in APOE4 and AD

context_description: ABCA1 was more abundant in lysosome-enriched fractions in the AD group than in the NCI group within the APOE3/4 genotype but not in the APOE3/3 genotype (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] C, full blots are shown in Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ), supporting that more ABCA1 was trapped in lysosomes in APOE4 AD.

caption: Supplementary Material 4: Figure 4.  Caveolin-1 regulates ABCA1 degradation. (A) HeLa cells expressing ABCA1-GFP were treated with recombinant ApoE3 or ApoE4 (0.2μM) for different hours. Cells were lysed with RIPA buffer and total ABCA1 levels were detected by WB using an anti-GFP antibody. The lower panel shows the densitometric quantification of the blots shown in the upper panel. ABCA1 was normalized to β-actin and then normalized to rApoE3 at the 0 h point. (B) Immunoprecipitation was performed with GFP-trap agarose in the lysate of HeLa cells or HeLa (ABCA1-GFP) cells treated with or without recombinant APOE3 (rE3) or APOE4 (rE4) for 4 h. Elution was detected using sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with silver staining. (C) 1115 and 1082 ABCA1 binding targets were detected in the recombinant APOE3 (rE3) and recombinant APOE4 (rE4) treatment groups, respectively, whereas 768 targets were found in both rE3 and rE4 groups. The top 14 candidates of the enriched KEGG pathways were identified from these 768 common targets (FDR < 0.05). (D) Enrichment levels (rE4 vs. rE3) of targets in the endocytic pathway. NSAF was used to calculate the fold change of each target. See the methods for calculating the NSFA. (E) Primary astrocytes were transfected with 15nM of non-target (NT), Caveolin-1 and AP2B1 siRNA for 48 h. The total protein levels of caveolin-1 and AP2B1 were detected by WB after siRNA transfection. (F) Immortalized astrocytes were transfected with 20nM of non-target (NT) or caveolin-1 siRNA for 48 h. The total protein levels of ABCA1 and caveolin-1 were detected by WB after siRNA transfection (n=3 biological replicates). (G) Caveolin-1 is overexpressed in immortalized astrocytes for 24 h, followed by labeling with 3H-cholesterol for 18 h. Cholesterol efflux was measured after treatment with the CS6253 peptides for 4 h (n=3 biological replicates). The right panel shows ABCA1 and caveolin-1 protein levels after plasmid transfection. (H) BHK cells were treated with LDL for 24 h, and caveolin-1 protein levels were detected by WB (n=3 biological replicates). Data are represented as mean± SD and were analyzed using unpaired t-test (E, F), one-way ANOVA (H), or two-way ANOVA (G) followed by Tukey’s test. *p<0.05, ** p<0.01, ***p<0.001; **** p<0.0001 (Related to Fig. 3).

The  top  14  candidates  of  the  enriched  KEGG  pathways  were  identified  from  these  768  common  targets  (FDR  <  0.05). See  the  methods  for  calculating  the  NSFA.  (E)  Primary  astrocytes  were  transfected  with  15nM  of  non-target  (NT),  Caveolin-1  and  AP2B1  siRNA  for  48  h. Data  are  represented  as  mean±  SD  and  were  analyzed  using  unpaired  t-test  (E,  F),  one-way  ANOVA  (H),  or  two-way  ANOVA  (G)  followed  by  Tukey’s  test.  *p<0.05,  **  p<0.01,  ***p<0.001;  ****  p<0.0001  (Related  to  Fig.  3).
context_description:
To explore the underlying mechanism, we treated ABCA1-GFP overexpressing HeLa cells with recombinant ApoE3 (rE3) or ApoE4 (rE4). rE4 treatment resulted in lower total ABCA1 protein levels than rE3 treatment, indicating greater ABCA1 degradation (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] A). ABCA1-binding complexes were enriched for proteomic analysis (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] A and Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] B). Proteomic analysis revealed 768 shared proteins between rE3 and rE4 treatments, with 314 proteins unique to rE4 (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] C). Nine of these proteins (Supplementary Table 4) showed higher expression in the rE4 treatment group than in the rE3 group (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] D). Reducing caveolin-1, but not, AP2B1 expression by siRNA increased plasma membrane ABCA1 levels in mouse primary astrocytes (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] F, Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] E), supporting that caveolae-mediated endocytosis regulated ABCA1 degradation. Surprisingly, reducing caveolin-1 expression significantly decreased ABCA1-mediated cholesterol efflux (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] G) despite an increase in total ABCA1 protein levels (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] F). Furthermore, overexpression of caveolin-1 in astrocytes enhanced cholesterol efflux (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] G). 
Cholesterol loading, by adding LDL, led to increased caveolin-1 expression (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] H and I) and showed a dose-dependent increase in baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] H).
pub_title: Cellular senescence induced by cholesterol accumulation is mediated by lysosomal ABCA1 in APOE4 and AD

caption: Supplementary Material 5: Figure 5.  ABCA1 and caveolin1 expression in different cell types isolated from adult mouse brains. (A) Mouse brain tissues were homogenized with TBS and TBS containing 1% Triton X-100 (TBSX) and then dissolved with guanidinium chloride (GnHCl). Validation of ABCA1 and caveolin-1 expression in the different fractions. (B) Diagram of the isolation of different cell types from mouse brains. (C) Brains of APOE3 or APOE4-TR mice (male, 9-10-month-old) were collected and dissociated to form single-cell suspensions to isolate different cell types. Cell type-specific markers were used to determine the purity of the cell population using western blotting. ABCA1 and caveolin-1 protein levels were measured by western blotting. (D-E) Quantification of ABCA1 (D) and caveolin-1 expression (E) in different cell types (4 mice total from two independent experiments). Data are presented as mean± SD and were analyzed using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s test. *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ****p<0.0001 (Related to Fig. 3).

context_description:
Mouse cortices were fractionated using TBSX and guanidine HCl to isolate soluble membrane and insoluble aggregated proteins (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] A). 
To identify the main cell type in which ABCA1 and caveolin-1 interact, we isolated microglia, astrocytes and axon-enriched fraction from the brains of adult mice (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] B). Astrocytes were enriched in the CD11b fraction (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] C). ABCA1 was mainly expressed in astrocytes and axon-enriched fractions, and lower ABCA1 expression was detected in microglial cells (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] D). Caveolin-1 was mainly expressed in astrocytes and microglia but not in axon-enriched fractions (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] E).
pub_title: Cellular senescence induced by cholesterol accumulation is mediated by lysosomal ABCA1 in APOE4 and AD

(A)  Body  weight  of  mice  in  the  experimental  processing  (PBS  group,  n=14,  5  females  and  9  males;  HPCD  group  n=15,  5  females  and  10  males). context_description: Body weight was not affected by HPCD treatment (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] A). Total cholesterol levels in the brain (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] B) or plasma (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] B) were also no different between HPCD and PBS groups. Lysosomal ABCA1 levels were lower in the HPCD treatment group, as verified by lysosome isolation and immunostaining (Fig. 5 [rid=Fig5] G and H; validation of lysosome isolation is shown in Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] C). Treatment with HPCD was associated with more efficient cholesterol efflux, as evidenced by increased trends of small HDL particle formation in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and plasma, although these changes did not reach statistical significance due to the small sample size (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] D-F).

context_description: To validate these findings in human cells, we cultured human induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC)-derived astrocytes with APOE4/4 genotype (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] A). When these human iPSc-derived astrocytes were treated with methyl-β-cyclodextrin (MβCD) after LDL loading, cellular cholesterol accumulation (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] B) and IL-1β and CCL2 mRNA levels were decreased (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] C).

title: NIHMS590622-supplement-Supp_info_1.pdf
context_description:
Moreover, samples in the paired-end group had many more mappable reads than those in the single-end group ( Table 1 [href=#T1] , Supplementary Fig. 1 [href=this file] ). Indeed, the two groups showed distinct global patterns of pseudogene expression ( Supplementary Fig. 2 [href=this file] ). For each cancer type, we observed generally weak correlations between the expression level of pseudogenes and their WT genes, which is consistent with the previous study ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [href=this file] ). As observed in Kalyana-Sundaram et al. (2012) , we detected some tumor-lineage-specific pseudogenes (296 from the paired-end group and 41 from the single-end group, Supplementary Fig. 4 [href=this file] ). In addition, for three cancer types with available RNA-seq data from nontumor tissue samples, we identified differentially expressed pseudogenes between tumor and nontumor samples (54 in BRCA, 110 in KIRC and 138 in LUSC, Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=this file] ).
For several cancer types with established tumor subtypes, we performed the supervised analysis and revealed substantial numbers of pseudogenes with significant differential expression: 48 in UCEC (endometrioid vs. serous) , 138 in LUSC (basal, classical, primitive and secretory) , 71 in GBM (classical, mesenchymal, neural and proneural) and 547 in BRCA (PAM50 subtypes: luminal A, luminal B, basal-like, Her2-enriched and normal-like) (Methods, Fig. 2a [href=#F2] , Supplementary Data 1 [href=this file] ).
The predictive power of pseudogene expression is comparable to those achieved by the mRNA expression profiles, suggesting that both pseudogene and mRNA expression can classify the UCEC subtypes independently ( Supplementary Fig. 6 [href=this file] ).
Based on the NMF consensus clustering, 837 BRCA samples can be classified into three distinct subtypes: subtype 1 ( = 144), subtype 2 ( = 390), and subtype 3 ( = 303) ( Fig. 4b [href=#F4] , Supplementary Data 2 [href=this file] ).
Based on the 500 pseudogenes with the most variable expression, we were able to classify 446 KIRC samples into two distinct subtypes ( Fig. 5a [href=#F5] , Supplementary Data 3 [href=this file] ). We observed an enrichment of pseudogenes (115 out of 500) with a statistically significant P-value ( < 0.05) ( Fig. 5c [href=#F5] , Supplementary Data 4 [href=this file] ).
To further assess the clinical utility of the observed pseudogene-expression subtypes, we classified the KIRC samples into four risk quartiles based on the risk scores (in terms of overall survival) calculated from the multivariate Cox model, employing only clinical variables: low risk group (Q1, = 110), low-medium risk group (Q2, = 111), medium-high risk group (Q3, = 112), and high risk group (Q4, = 112) (Methods, Supplementary Data 3 [href=this file] ).
To gain some mechanistic insight into how expressed pseudogenes contribute to the observed KIRC pseudogene-expression subtypes, we performed a systematic analysis ( Supplementary Fig. 9a and Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). Among the WT cognate genes with strong positive correlations with their pseudogenes, we noticed that the survival correlations of individual WT genes with prognostic value match the survival pattern of the pseudogene-expression subtypes: WT genes with better prognosis (potentially tumor suppressors, hazard ratio < 1) show higher expression levels in subtype 1 (the better survival group) and the genes with worse prognosis (potentially oncogenes, hazard ratio > 1) show higher expression levels in subtype 2 (the worse survival group, Supplementary Fig. 8b [href=this file] ). Finally, we examined the classic miRNA decoy model as proposed in Poliseno et al. (2010) and identified 38 such candidates ( Methods and Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). One candidate of interest is the potential regulation of a putative tumor suppressor α-catenin (CTNNA1) by the pseudogene PGOHUM00000257111 through competition for up to 9 shared miRNA regulators ( Supplementary Data 5 [href=this file] ). Indeed, the expression levels of PGOHUM00000257111 were significantly higher in cluster 1 (t-test P = 1.48×10-7), which may lead to the elevated levels of CTNNA1 in subtype 1 ( Supplementary Fig. 8b [href=this file] ) and therefore better survival.
Finally, we performed feature selection ( Supplementary Data 6 [href=this file] ) and built the classifier from the whole training set using the best-performing algorithm (with the highest AUC) identified through the cross-validation, and applied it to the test set in order to independently validate the predictive power.
We gratefully acknowledge contributions from the TCGA Research Network and its TCGA Pan-Cancer Analysis Working Group (contributing consortium members are listed in Supplementary Note 1 [href=this file] ).

Across downregulated genes we observed an enrichment of synaptic and neuronal pathways ( Figure 3 [href=#F3] ; Table S3 [href=this file] ). Finally, synaptic pathways were enriched within downregulated genes ( Figure 3 [href=#F3] ; Table S4 [href=this file] ).
Other modules were enriched for development/angiogenesis (green, upregulated, and enriched for End and Per), immune system (tan, upregulated), and synaptic signaling (green-yellow and turquoise, both downregulated and enriched for neuronal cell genes) ( Table S5 [href=this file] ).

We detected a total of 4,275 genes only associated with pseudotime in amygdala and 3,102 only associated with pseudotime in olfactory bulb ( Table S8 [href=this file] and Table S9 [href=this file] , respectively).
It is important to stress that the two modules are not related (see Table S2 [href=this file] ) representing two distinct biological processes.

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
When evaluated on cell-type level, TAPE has the best performance of MAE, and comparable CCC with relatively small variance on real datasets (Supplementary Table 8 [this file] ). 
Meanwhile, we find that deep learning methods are robust for the cross-protocol prediction, while the performance of some statistical methods will drop if the reference and pseudo-bulk data type (UMI to counts or counts to UMI) are exchanged (Supplementary Figs. 1 [this file] and 2 [this file] ). 
Detailed comparison results are available in Supplementary Table 8 [this file] . For the “similar” scenario, we investigated TAPE’s performance on distinguishing similar cell types (CD4 T cell and CD8 T cell) in all the three PBMC datasets (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). With 13 defined cell subtypes (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ), all the methods can not achieve satisfying results (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] , median CCC < 0.1), which clearly shows the common limitation of current methods. 
In Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] , the two colors stand for the different methods, and the two coordinates of each dot represent overall MAE and CCC for all cell types respectively. 
From the results (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ), we can have four conclusions: (1) TAPE’s predictive power is better than CIBERSORTx when the randomly selected DEGs are less than 1000; (2) both methods can achieve good performance when the DEGs are signature genes and there are not any similar cell types; (3) both methods can not distinguish DEGs from CD8 T cell rather than CD4 T cell if the DEGs are randomly selected; (4) CIBERSORTx is better than TAPE if the DEGs are signature genes and there exist similar cell types. 
The results show that TAPE only predicts and as DEGs in NK cell and no DEGs for other cell types (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
Firstly, when we study the correlation at the gene level using “overall” mode (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ), about 30% of the predicted genes have the negative correlation. However, this phenomenon can also be observed in CIBERSORTx (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ), which indicates the information loss between bulk samples and inferred cell-type-specific GEP is hard to be reconstructed. Thirdly, we notice that both CIBERSORTx and our method can not distinguish DEGs from similar cell subtypes correctly if the DEGs are not signature genes (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ) which means that their resolution is still limited. But CIBERSORTx has displayed its advantages in distinguishing signature DEGs from similar cell types because of the incorporation of the signature matrix (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ). 
When we used it to test whether deconvolution methods can achieve good performance with immune cell subtypes, we merged all 30 cell types into 13 cell subtypes (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
This step is very important, because TAPE will fail in predicting test bulk data proportions properly without proper filtering (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] and Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ) . If the less variable genes are not filtered out, TAPE can not predict a good result because of the noises (Supplementary Table 2 [this file] and Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
Hyperparameter tuning file is available in Supplementary Tables 3 [this file] – 7 [this file] . 
All other relevant data supporting the key findings of this study are available within the article and its Supplementary Information [this file] files or from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary information
context_description:
After clustering (Supplementary Fig. 1a–e [this file] ), a total of 37,943 cells were annotated into 23 clusters using a predefined set of marker genes (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
To reveal heterogeneity within oligodendrocytes, we grouped the aforementioned oligodendrocytes into six classes described in a published database , as follows (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] –d and 3a [this file] ): (1) Differentiation-committed oligodendrocyte precursors (COPs) and newly formed oligodendrocytes (NFOL) that express Sox6, Pdgfra, and Cspg4. (2) Myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (MFOL) that express Ctps, Ablims, and Thbs3. (3) Mature oligodendrocytes 1, 2 (MOL 1, 2) that express Il33, Ptgds, and Opalin. (4) Mature oligodendrocytes 3, 4 (MOL 3, 4) that express Klk6, S100b, Anxa5, Cd59a and Mgst3. Moreover, we discovered an additional oligodendrocyte cluster, which gradually increased in the 3-, 6-month-old App KI mice (Fig. 1b–d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). This cluster was present in the UMAP plot even with down-sampled data (400, 1,200, and 2,400 cells) (Supplementary Fig. 2f [this file] ). Remarkably, we found that this cluster shared some signatures with MOL2, while Alzheimer’s disease risk factors such as C4b, Apoe and Cd74 are strongly expressed (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] , 3a [this file] , 3b [this file] , and Source data file). 
We further confirmed the lineage transitions of DAOs and homeostatic MOLs from COP and NFOL in control and AD brains (Fig. 1e–g [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), but density from the DAO cluster exclusively appeared in 3 and 6-month-old AD brains (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] g). 
We reanalyzed previously published single-cell transcriptome datasets from postmortem AD brains (Supplementary Fig. 5a–c [this file] ) . 
Notably, consistent with scRNA-seq results, we observed a significant increase in Mbp + , Cd74+ oligodendrocytes in 3- and 6-month-old App KI and 6-month-old 5xFAD mice, whereas the number of NeuroD1+ post-mitotic neurons significantly decreased (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] a, b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 6a–c [this file] , and Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] , b [this file] ). We further confirmed an increase in Cd74+ and Oligo2+ AD-associated oligodendrocytes in App KI mice using flow cytometry (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] c, d [rid=Fig2] , and Supplementary Fig. 6d [this file] ). 
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis revealed that 6-month-old App KI mice exhibited a thinner myelin layer relative to the axon diameter (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] and supplementary fig. 8 [this file] ). 
Consistently, we found a significant increase in Mbp+ and Cd74+ DAOs in the hippocampus of premature progeria (6-month-old) and 13-month-old mice (Supplementary Fig. 9a–d [this file] ), whereas the number of NeuroD1-positive post-mitotic neurons decreased in the hippocampus of 13-month-old mice (Supplementary Fig. 9e and f [this file] ). We further confirmed that the genes enriched in DAOs were highly correlated with gene signatures shown in the aged human brain (Supplementary Fig. 10a, b [this file] ), indicating that Cd74-positive DAOs increased in the aged brains and had transcriptional profiles more similar to the aged human brain. 
In particular, we found significant alternations in the transcriptional profiles between DAOs and MOL 3/4 clusters and GO-term of up-regulated genes in DAO versus MOL3/4 showed the interleukin & chemokine production and ERK signaling (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] a and c [rid=Fig3] ), which was also confirmed during the disease progression in AD mice brain (Supplementary Fig. 11a, b [this file] ). 
We first identified microglia with a high DAM module score based on previously published DAM signatures (Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] , 12a, b [this file] ), that gradually increased during AD progression (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] e, f [rid=Fig3] , and Supplementary Fig. 12c [this file] ). 
Supplementary Fig. 13a–c [this file] shows efficient inhibition of phosphor 44/42 MAPK signaling in primary oligodendrocytes upon treatment with 200 ng/ml SCH772984, a specific Erk1 and Erk2 inhibitor. Remarkably, oligodendrocytes treated with SCH772984 exhibited a significant increase in Mbp+ branching compared with the controls, whereas the number of Cd74+ cells significantly decreased (Supplementary Fig. 13d [this file] , 13e [this file] , and Fig. 4a–c [rid=Fig4] ). 
First, in order to examine the potential interactions between DAOs and other neuronal cell types, AD DAOs were co-cultured with AD neurons, astrocytes, and microglia treated with SCH772984 (Supplementary Fig. 14a [this file] ). We found that AD DAOs with other neuronal cell types did not increase the number of Mbp+ branches in the presence and absence of SCH772984 treatment (Supplementary Fig. 14b–f [this file] ), suggesting that inhibition of ERK/MAPK signaling in other neuronal cell types did not contribute to the phenotypic changes in DAOs (Fig. 4d–f [rid=Fig4] ). Moreover, to investigate whether other neural cell types can contribute to the AD-associated phenotypes via ERK signaling, each of the neurons, microglia, astrocytes and oligodendrocytes isolated from AD mice were subjected to SCH772984 treatment, and AD pathology was determined after co-culture with the remaining untreated AD neuronal cell types (Supplementary Fig. 15a [this file] ). Remarkably, we found that ERK1/2-inhibited oligodendrocytes significantly diminished the Aβ42/40 ratio in the AD primary neuronal cultures (Supplementary Fig. 15b [this file] ). Also, we observed a decrease in the amyloidogenic processing marker C99 in the AD neuronal cultures with SCH772984 treatment (Supplementary Fig. 15c–e [this file] ), indicating that AD oligodendrocytes predominantly contribute to the pathophysiology of AD via ERK signaling. 
Consistent with previous results, systemic administration of SCH772984 significantly reduced the occurrence of DAOs in the hippocampus of App KI mice (Fig. 5b, c [rid=Fig5] , and Supplementary Fig. 16a–d [this file] ) but not Cd74 + Iba1+ microglia (Supplementary Fig. 16c, d [this file] ). 
Moreover, we confirmed a decrease in the number of Aβ plaques (Fig. 5m, n [rid=Fig5] ), coupled with an increase in the number of NeuroD1+ cells in the SCH772984-treated AD mouse hippocampus (Supplementary Fig. 16e, f [this file] ). 
Figure 5a, b, c [this file] obtained from the AD Knowledge Portal ( https://adknowledgeportal.org (https://adknowledgeportal.org) ) under study 557 snRNAseqAD_TREM2(syn21126450).

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
We also observed a clear linear trend between the measured correlation of protein expression within well-imputed pairs and their imputed co-expression, further supporting the robustness of COWAS imputation models ( Supplementary Figure 1 [this file] ). 
For LDL cholesterol, which had the best-powered GWAS of the three traits we considered, we identified 38 protein pairs with a significant co-expression effect ( Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ). 
By visualizing significant COWAS pairs as a network, we identified complexes of mutually interacting proteins that modulate LDL cholesterol levels ( Supplementary Figure 3 [this file] ). For example, we found that APOE and PLTP both decrease LDL cholesterol levels, while their co-expression is associated with increased LDL cholesterol levels ( Supplementary Figure 4 [this file] ). 
Effect sizes, standard errors, and values for the pairs shown in Figure 3 [rid=F3] are also summarized in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
Results for protein pairs identified as significant using at least one of these three tests with IGAP GWAS data are shown in Supplementary Figure 5 [this file] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
Finally, we considered an alternative, product-based formulation of COWAS (see Supplementary Note 1 [this file] for details). The mean out-of-sample for product-based co-expression imputation models was slightly higher than for any of the residual-based co-expression imputation models, and over 99% of well-imputed pairs again had a nominally significant correlation between imputed and observed expression ( Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] and Supplementary Data 1 [rid=SD2] ). 
We also discovered 22 pairs with an overall effect on AD using the product-based COWAS global test and EADB summary statistics ( Supplementary Figure 7 [this file] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). Full results for AD using the product-based version of COWAS are provided in Supplementary Figure 7 [this file] , Supplementary Table 3 [this file] , and Supplementary Data 18 [rid=SD2] – 19 [rid=SD2] . 
Effect sizes, standard errors, and values for the pairs shown in Figure 4 [rid=F4] are also summarized in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] . 
In Supplementary Note 1 [this file] we define an alternative, product-based version of COWAS in which is replaced with . 
In Supplementary Note 2 [this file] we derive a summary-level version of the second stage following the approach introduced in the multivariate imaging-wide association study (MV-IWAS) method [ 14 [rid=R14] , 16 [rid=R16] ], which is related to other methods in the field of Mendelian randomization [ 87 [rid=R87] , 88 [rid=R88] ]. We also provide full derivations for both individual-level and summary-level versions of standard TWAS/PWAS in Supplementary Note 3 [this file] .
pub_title: Co-expression-wide association studies link genetically regulated interactions with complex traits

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
Across all of the model types we considered, the median out-of-sample correlation between estimated and imputed co-expression was always lower than the median out-of-sample correlation between measured and imputed single-protein expression ( Figure 2a [rid=F2] , Figure 2c [rid=F2] , and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
Among these well-imputed pairs, lasso regression with -pQTLs pre-screened by their effect sizes achieved the highest mean out-of-sample for predicting co-expression (mean , Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). On the other hand, ridge regression with both -pQTLs and -pQTLs pre-screened by their values yielded the greatest number of well-imputed protein pairs ( Figure 2d [rid=F2] and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
Model performance metrics for every combination of protein pair and model type are provided in Supplementary Data 2 [this file] – 13 [this file] . 
Full imputation performance metrics for all analyzed proteins and outcome traits are provided in Supplementary Data 14 [this file] – 20 [this file] . 
Full results for LDL cholesterol, including the estimated effect sizes and standard errors for each pair, are provided in Supplementary Data 14 [this file] . 
Full results from our validation study for LDL cholesterol are provided in Supplementary Data 15 [this file] . 
Full results for AD, including the estimated effect sizes and standard errors for each pair, are provided in Supplementary Data 16 [this file] . 
Full results for all protein pairs passing quality control are provided in Supplementary Data 17 [this file] . 
The mean out-of-sample for product-based co-expression imputation models was slightly higher than for any of the residual-based co-expression imputation models, and over 99% of well-imputed pairs again had a nominally significant correlation between imputed and observed expression ( Supplementary Figure 6 [rid=SD1] and Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
Full results for AD using the product-based version of COWAS are provided in Supplementary Figure 7 [rid=SD1] , Supplementary Table 3 [rid=SD1] , and Supplementary Data 18 [this file] – 19 [this file] . 
Full results for PD, including the estimated effect sizes and standard errors for each pair, are provided in Supplementary Data 20 [this file] .
pub_title: Co-expression-wide association studies link genetically regulated interactions with complex traits

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
The procedures for sample selection are shown in Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] . More details for the distribution of brain 5hmC data can be found in Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] – 3 [this file] . 
Of the 2821 DhMRs (606 associated with AD diagnosis, 1542 associated with Aβ load, 1399 associated with PHFtau tangles, annotated to 2642 distinct genes) identified in stage II (replication), about 69% reside in exons, ~15% in intergenic regions, and ~17% in introns (Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] ). Compared to non-AD associated 5hmC regions (total 194,944), AD-associated regions (total 2821) were significantly more likely to coincide with regions related to transcription start site (TSS), transcription states, and enhancer states, but less likely to co-position with regions corresponding to heterochromatin and quiescent states (Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] , Supplementary Data 20 [rid=MOESM22] ). 
Of these, 108 AD-associated, 581 Aβ-associated and 135 PHFtau-associated 5hmC regions were positively correlated with gene expression, whereas 65 AD-associated, 240 Aβ-associated and 53 PHFtau-associated 5hmC regions were negatively correlated with gene expression (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] , Supplementary Data 22 [rid=MOESM24] ). These genes were clustered into multiple protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). The most significant biological processes and pathways of these functional clusters were associated with mTOR signaling, mediator complex and transcriptional regulation of RNA polymerase transcripts (II and III), SWI/SNF and npBAF complex, γ-secretase complex, DNA replication and repair, etc. (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] , Supplementary Data 24 [rid=MOESM26] ). 
At GWAS threshold of 1 × 10 , genetic variants residing in regions harboring AD-associated 5hmC alterations were significantly enriched in DNase I hypersensitive sites (DHSs), transcribed histone modifications, TSS, and transcribed chromatin states, but depleted in repressed chromatin states and H3K27me3 in various tissues such as blood, blood vessel, embryonic stem cells (ESCs), colon, liver, and fetal intestine(Supplementary Figs. 7 [this file] – 9 [this file] ; Supplementary Data 30 [rid=MOESM32] – 32 [rid=MOESM34] ). 
We also performed colocalization analysis using summary statistics from a cell-type specific -eQTL analysis of eight human brain cell types and found that one of the colocalized genes, , is expressed in both astrocytes (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ) and microglia (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ).

Focusing on the 2821 DhMRs associated with AD pathologies (606 regions associated with AD diagnosis, 1542 regions associated with Aβ, 1399 regions associated with PHFtau, annotated to 2642 distinct genes), we evaluated whether altered DNA hydroxymethylation affects the expression of genes located in the vicinity ( ± 50 kb) of each DhMR using brain RNA-seq data (DLPFC) from the same participants (Supplementary Data 21 [this file] ). 
To further functionally annotate the AD-associated 5hmC regions, we calculated the correlation between the level of 5hmC and the level of H3K9ac generated in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex from the same individuals (Supplementary Data 21 [this file] ) in ROSMAP . 
In a subset of individuals (Supplementary Data 21 [this file] ) with both 5hmC and brain proteomics data (DLPFC) , we calculated the correlation of AD-associated 5hmC with protein abundances (Methods). 
A total of 731 unique individuals with both 5hmC and proteomic data were included in this analysis (Supplementary Data 21 [this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary information
context_description:
The data set is released in its entirety as Supplementary Materials [this file] to this paper, via an interactive website ( https://cancertrials.io/ (https://cancertrials.io/) ), and through the online Synapse repository (ID: syn25813713) . 
For trials reporting event-free survival data (e.g., PFS; Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ) median = 0.950 (Q1 = 0.909, mean: 0.929, Q3 = 0.970) as compared to a theoretical maximal = 0.996, which corresponds to 5% of observed variance not explained by the Weibull model. This is illustrated in Supplementary Fig. 2a, b [this file] for Weibull fits to OS and PFS data for panitumumab in combination with FOLFIRI and for FOLFIRI alone in wild-type and mutant metastatic colorectal cancer (trial 20050181 ; average = 0.99 for OS curves and 0.92 for PFS curves). 
Across the entire data set, some of the worst fits for two-parameter Weibull forms were observed for trials with relatively few events, for example, the Chronicle trial ( NCT00427713 (NCT00427713) ) with only eight deaths in the treatment arm and 16 progression events in the observation arm (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] ; Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
For a small number of trials in which the asymptote of the fitted survival curve was greater than zero (i.e., patients were expected to be alive at the end of the longest follow-up), a three-parameter Weibull distribution consisting of the traditional two-parameter distribution with an additional “cure rate” term had an improved fit (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
This is potentially consistent with a two-population hypothesis (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Moreover, a mixture model exhibited no meaningful improvement in fit as compared to a single-distribution for OS data from ICI or control arms in these trials (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). This generated the steep decline in PFS values observable in the control and experimental arms of actual ICI trials, and improved fit to PFS distributions, raising mean from 0.93 to 0.98 (Fig. 3c [rid=Fig3] ; Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ; “Methods”). 
A challenge in the analysis of such data is that, when too few events have occurred, nonparametric numeric confidence estimates return non-informative values (usually reported as a value “not reached” or “indeterminate” as illustrated for two different scenarios in Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). We found that 12-month survival estimates were non-informative for 20–40% of OS trial arms, and 23–61% of event-free survival trial arms, with higher failure rates occurring when the sample size was smaller (Supplementary Fig. 5b, c [this file] ). 
For event-free survival (for which 99 event-free survival curves could be compared), the precision of a Weibull-based approach was also greater than a nonparametric approach across all sample sizes, while accuracy was equivalent for small sample sizes (fewer than 40 patients) (Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] ). 
Thus, parametric fitting of data from 15 patients made a comparably precise and accurate estimate of median PFS as nonparametric analysis of 60 patients (Supplementary Fig. 6b [this file] ). 
We observed that for a representative simulation, a two-parameter Weibull form accurately described the synthetic trial data ( = 0.98; Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
Parameter values for trials reporting event-free survival followed a similar pattern to OS values (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] and Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ). 
A similar pattern was observed for event-free survival data, with control and experimental values differing by 1.0% for unsuccessful trials and 36% for successful trials (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
For event-free survival data, 155 comparisons of experimental and control arms from 146 trial figures revealed a range of Δ values from +0.55 to −0.85 (median |Δ | = 0.08) (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
All data generated or analyzed during this study are included in this published article (and its supplementary information [this file] files).

The IPP gene set contains 26 immune-related genes and 3 genes used for normalization, and we used those the total of 29 as input in the IPP models ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
In the 7 studies ( 43 [rid=B43] , 45 [rid=B45] , 46 [rid=B46] , 51 [rid=B51] – 53 [rid=B53] , 58 [rid=B58] ) with GE data collected at time points 3 to 7, there were 270 arrays sampled on 173 patients, of whom 134 were alive and 39 (22.5%) deceased at day 30; 122 were used for training and 51 for testing models ( Supplementary Tables 2 [this file] , 3 [this file] ). 
We ran the COCONUT algorithm on the 17 studies selected for analysis and assessed the effect of co-normalization: (1) on patient-level GE data across studies ( Figure 1 [rid=F1] and Supplementary Figure 1 [this file] ); (2) at the gene level in controls and cases ( Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] presenting data for CD3D); (3) for 2 genes in controls and cases, here with CLDN8 (a housekeeping gene, with minimal difference in mean GE between controls and cases and minimal overall GE variance) and CEACAM1, up-regulated during sepsis ( Supplementary Figure 3 [this file] ).

As expected, -xQTL are strongly clustered near their target genes’ transcription start site (TSS) ( Fig. 1E [rid=F1] ) and are correspondingly enriched in functional regions of the genome ( Fig. 1F [rid=F1] ; Table S1 [this file] ). To investigate the variant-level overlap among -e/iso/sQTLs, we calculated Storey’s pi1 statistic ( 40 [rid=R40] ) and found that genetic variants directly associated with RNA splicing (especially isoQTL) capture independent and additional signals from eQTLs ( Fig. 1H [rid=F1] ; Methods [this file] ).

Each CS prioritized a median of 5 SNPs, with 2,423 containing exactly one SNP, which are strong candidates for functional validation ( Data S1 [this file] ).

Following the multi-ancestry QTL mapping pipeline, we independently mapped xQTLs in the three largest ancestry groupings: EUR, AMR, and AFR. 986 eGenes were shared between the multi-ancestry dataset and the three ancestry groupings ( Fig. 2B [rid=F2] ; Table S2 [this file] ). We then performed statistical fine-mapping separately in the ancestry groupings ( 42 [rid=R42] ), and show that AFR, despite of the smallest sample size, has on average the smallest credible sets (CS) of causal variants ( Fig. 2D [rid=F2] ; Data S2 [this file] , S3 [this file] , S4 [this file] ).

We generated continuous annotations for genetic variants based on fine-mapping posterior probabilities ( 51 [rid=R51] ) and found SCZ GWAS signals to be highly enriched among fetal brain regulatory elements -- more so than in the adult brain ( Fig. 4B [rid=F4] ; Table S4 [this file] ; Methods [this file] ). Across these traits, we consistently observed greater heritability mediated by isoform regulation (isoform h /h 6.45±1.92%) than that of gene expression (3.15±1.25%) or splicing (2.13±1.74%), although the overall extent of mediation remains small ( Fig. 4C [rid=F4] ; Table S4 [this file] ; Methods [this file] ). Extending these analyses across trimester-specific annotations, although less well powered, pointed to isoform-regulation in Tri2 as being particularly important, especially for BIP ( Fig. 4D [rid=F4] ; Table S4 [this file] ).

Other novel disease mechanisms prioritized by these analyses include: downregulation of the GABA -receptor subunit in SCZ (eQTL: rs514733, CLPP=0.32; Fig. 5B [rid=F5] ; Table S5 [this file] ), providing genetic evidence for GABAergic dysfunction hypothesized to contribute to disease pathophysiology ( 60 [rid=R60] ); splicing dysregulation of in BIP (top colocalization sQTL: rs11750832, CLPP=0.97; Fig. S10 [this file] ; Table S5 [this file] ) which encodes adenylate cyclase, a cell membrane-bound enzyme regulating cAMP signaling and a target of the mood stabilizer lithium ( 61 [rid=R61] ); splicing dysregulation in BIP of (sQTL: rs17183814, CLPP=0.70; Fig. S10 [this file] ; Table S5 [this file] ), a voltage gated sodium channel subunit with rare variant associations in ASD and epilepsy ( 62 [rid=R62] , 63 [rid=R63] ); and in MDD, the dysregulated splicing of (CLPP=0.43; Fig. S10 [this file] ; Table S5 [this file] ), a highly constrained E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase and regulator of N6-methyladenosine RNA modification involved in neural-immune activation ( 64 [rid=R64] ). 
We next conducted an isoform-centric transcriptome-wide association study (isoTWAS) ( 65 [rid=R65] ), to identify genes and their isoforms whose regulated expression is associated with SCZ risk. isoTWAS identified 536 isoforms across 271 unique genes with significant isoTWAS associations (Bonferroni-corrected P < 0.05 across genes, FWER-corrected P < 0.05 across transcripts of the same gene, permutation P < 0.05; Methods [this file] ). To leverage local LD and to account for SNP weight correlations, we performed fine-mapping on isoTWAS associations that passed permutation testing ( Fig. 5D [rid=F5] ; Table S5 [this file] ). 
Among 14 TWAS-identified genes with >3 conditionally independent eQTLs, the MRLocus framework provided additional support for 7 genes with FDR<0.2 ( Table S5 [this file] ; Methods [this file] ). S11 [this file] ). 
In total, we identified 124 gene and isoform co-expression modules demonstrating enrichment for all major developmental cell types ( 36 [rid=R36] ) and recapitulating early biochemical processes and developmental pathways ( Fig. 6A [rid=F6] ; Methods [this file] ). 
Overlaying enrichment for common and rare variation within the hierarchical structure defined by co-expression pinpointed groups of modules that harbor most of neurodevelopmental disease risk ( Fig. 6B [rid=F6] ; Table S6 [this file] ; Methods [this file] ). S12 [this file] ). 
S12 [this file] ), which exhibits strong enrichment for cross-disorder common variation and rare variation risk for ASD, epilepsy, and SCZ. S12 [this file] ), which strongly enriched for synaptic gene ontologies and excitatory neuron marker genes. S12 [this file] ). 
S12 [this file] ) displayed robust BIP, education attainment (EA), and SCZ enrichment while harboring high risk hub genes like and – similar to the prenatally-enriched M37 module described in Li et al ( 18 [rid=R18] ). S12 [this file] ). 
CellWalker mapped 21.7% of eQTL-containing genes to a specific cellular context in the developing human brain, corresponding to 3,739 of the bulk-derived eQTLs ( Fig. 7A [rid=F7] ; Table S7 [this file] ; Methods [this file] ). To identify such ieQTLs, in which SNP-gene associations are modulated by the levels of a given module, we tested the interaction effect between genotype and module eigengenes on gene and isoform expression ( Fig. 7B [rid=F7] ; Methods [this file] ). Across all gene and isoform modules, 8,008 ieQTLs were identified after the permutation test (BH-corrected FDR<0.05; Methods [this file] ), in which 3,960 ieQTLs were specific to a single module ( Fig. 7C [rid=F7] ; Data S9 [this file] ). Finally, integrating disease GWAS, we identified significant colocalizations (CLPP>0.01) between ieQTLs and 22 SCZ GWAS loci, 13 of which are not found with bulk cA-eQTLs ( Table S5 [this file] ). 
See Methods [this file] for details. ( ) A schematic of module interaction ieQTL mapping and validation in cultured neurons and progenitors. ( ) Results from module ieQTL mapping.

context_description:
Study characteristics and acylcarnitine descriptions can be found in Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] and 2 [this file] , respectively. 
The analysis split ADNI participants into two clusters, 2 and 3, at the top of the tree, with significantly different levels of p-tau in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), glucose uptake measured by [ F] fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (FDG-PET), and the 13-item AD assessment scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-Cog. 13; Fig. 2b [rid=F2] - d [rid=F2] , Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). All associations remained significant ( Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ). 
Specifically, we examined acylcarnitine-related SNPs reported by Shin et al. as non-modifiable factors (SNP list is provided in Supplementary Table 5 [this file] , replication in ADNI in Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ) and modifiable acylcarnitine levels (i.e., residuals adjusted for genetic and other non-modifiable factors) to better understand their impact on subgroup separation. 
Genetic influences only accounted for a small proportion of variance ( Supplementary Table 7 [this file] - 9 [this file] ), except for one epistatic interaction effect of two SNPs: The interplay of rs17806888 (mapped to ) and rs924135 (mapped to ), both of which have been reported to affect succinylcarnitine levels , explained 32% of the initial partitioning of the data into cluster 2 and cluster 3 at the top of the tree ( Fig. 2j [rid=F2] and Supplementary Fig. 2 [rid=SD2] ). When we examined relations to AD, we observed that both single acylcarnitine-related SNPs and epistatic models were not strongly linked to AD and its biomarkers, although some associations were independently confirmed in the MayoLOAD and ROS/MAP studies ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [rid=SD2] and Supplementary Table 10 [this file] ). 
After cross-normalizing the different cohort datasets for better comparability ( Methods [rid=S6] and Supplementary Fig. 4 [rid=SD2] ), we fitted a multivariable linear model that regresses age on the fasting serum levels of acylcarnitines in the KORA cohort ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [rid=SD2] and Supplementary Table 11 [this file] ). When applied to the ADNI cohort, correlation dropped to 28% (cognitively normal participants only), which was very similar to what we observed when replicating the bioenergetic age computation process in AGES-RS (r = 29%, Supplementary Table 12 [this file] ). 
Bioenergetic age highlighted interesting relationships between subgroups and AD pathology throughout the tree ( Supplementary Table 13 [this file] ). This was further confirmed by significant associations of bioenergetic age with AD biomarkers across the A-T-(N)-(C) spectrum ( Supplementary Table 14 [this file] ), and consistent findings for cognitive function and grey matter volume in AGES-RS ( Supplementary Table 15 [this file] ). 
Specifically, bioenergetically younger individuals demonstrated a significantly slower decline over five years ( Supplementary Table 16 [this file] ). This result was replicated using longitudinal diagnosis data from the AGES-RS study ( Fig. 4d [rid=F4] , Supplementary Table 15 [this file] ), providing further evidence that younger bioenergetic age is protective against cognitive decline. 
We selected the grouping that had the most significant associations across three cognitive measures: ADAS-Cog 13, memory, and executive function ( Supplementary Table 17 [this file] ). 
The final dataset contained 140 metabolite measurements, covering 23 acylcarnitine species ( Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ), for 1,531 individuals. 
Data for 22 out of 23 acylcarnitines investigated in ADNI ( Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ) were available here, with the exception being levels of C4:1, which was not reliably measured in KORA. 
We obtained a list of 32 acylcarnitine-associated SNPs ( Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ) from a large GWAS study performed on a total of 7,824 individuals from the KORA and TwinsUK studies . 
To investigate robustness of the model, we performed 10-fold, 3 times repeated cross-validation ( Supplementary Table 11 [this file] ).

As expected, no difference was observed for WBGs between prenatal and postnatal stages ( = 0.27, Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, in GTEx data, we observed that nearest non-HRG genes are highly expressed in a majority of brain tissues while non-nearest HRGs are not ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
Specifically, and both encoding voltage-gated calcium channel subunits, are involved in CCS and contribute to risk for SCZ . is differentially expressed in SCZ patients ( = 0.03), and both and capture multiple Hi-C links in brain Hi-C data ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), contributing to the high PP of both genes in iRIGS. We also predicted two DNA binding proteins, SOX2 and SATB2 ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), which have important roles in neurogenesis and have been widely implicated in SCZ. Several of our predicted HRGs are miR-137 target genes, including the aforementioned , and three other genes, and . , a glutamate-gated ion channel protein and a key mediator of synaptic plasticity , has a pdDNM and multiple regulatory connections ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). , encoding Transcription Factor 4, participates in the initiation of neuronal differentiation by regulating the intrinsic excitability of prefrontal cortical neurons , and knockdown of alters the expression of genes important for developing prefrontal neocortex . is also linked with numerous DREs ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ) in iRIGS. 
We took a closer look at this region to gain more insights. captures 55 Hi-C links in brain Hi-C data ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ), while there is only one for . In GTEx data, is highly expressed in basal ganglia caudate, hypothalamus, basal ganglia nucleus accumbens, basal ganglia putamen and substantia nigra, but the expression in cortex and frontal cortex is rather low ( Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). is uniformly and highly expressed in all brain tissues ( Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). In BrainSpan data, shows constitutively high expression across all stages, and particularly higher expression at prenatal stages with a trajectory that peaks at the early-mid fetal stage, while shows lower expression across all developmental stages and no obvious pattern of transition between prenatal and postnatal stages ( Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
One pdDNM and a high number of regulatory links were observed for ( Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ), promoting it as the top gene predicted by iRIGS. 
We curated a list of 2263 confirmed druggable targets from multiple sources ( Methods [rid=S15] ), and found that 28 (27%) HRGs are targets of 198 FDA-approved, clinically investigational, or preclinical drugs ( Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] and Supplementary Table 7 [rid=SD2] ). In particular, we found that 5 HRGs ( and ) are targets of nervous system drugs ( Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ), corresponding to a statistically significant enrichment ( = 0.01, OR = 3.78).

In addition, we also observed that the 65 non-nearest HRGs are significantly enriched in 19 MPO gene sets ( Supplementary Table 5 [this file] ), while no significantly enriched gene sets were observed for the 65 nearest non-HRG genes ( Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ), providing strong and orthogonal support for iRIGS identified risk genes that are beyond the proximity to the GWAS index SNPs.

context_description:
Details of iRIGS can be found in Methods [rid=S15] and Supplementary Note [this file] . 
We performed iRIGS on these loci to identify risk genes of SCZ ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
We also tried other thresholds to define LBGs, and the enrichment patterns are similar ( Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
We found that NRGs are indeed connected to more DREs in Hi-C and FANTOM5 data ( Fig. 2b [rid=F2] , Supplementary Fig. 1 [rid=SD1] , Methods [rid=S15] , and Supplementary Note [this file] ). 
We therefore integrated them into iRIGS ( Methods [rid=S15] ) and predicted 104 high-confident risk genes (HRGs) in total ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
We found that non-nearest HRGs are more significantly enriched in the gene sets compared to nearest non-HRG genes ( Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ), suggesting that the 65 non-nearest HRGs identified by iRIGS are more likely to be true risk genes than their nearest counterparts. 
We highlighted these genes with extended supporting evidence and description in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . 
The distance of or to in the network is calculated using the random walk with restart (RWR) algorithm ( Supplemental Note [this file] ). We employed the Mahalanobis transformation to de-correlate the integrated multi-dimensional data so that any supportive genomic features can be properly incorporated ( Supplementary Note [this file] ). 
We adopted the Jensen-Shannon divergence to measure the tissue-specificity of each gene in each tissue ( Supplementary Note [this file] ). 
All the data used in this study are from public resources that were specified in Methods [rid=S15] and Supplementary Note [this file] . 
See main text and Supplementary Note [this file] for details.

context_description:
MNN outperforms RPCA and Harmony on both the UMAP inspection and cluster stability metrics measurement, we therefore set the mutual nearest neighbor (MNN) matching method in Monocle 3 as default, and Seurat’s reciprocal principal component analysis (RPCA) based integration and Harmony as alternatives (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Cells with consistent cell type annotations were combined with the CellRef Seed to form the LungMAP Human Lung CellRef (347,970 cells) (Fig. 2B [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Figs. 1 [this file] – 3 [this file] , “Methods”). 
Using the same approach, we constructed a cell type dictionary based on the LungMAP CellCards to define cell types in mouse lung during perinatal development, identified seed cells for each cell type (termed LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef Seed”), and constructed a CellRef for mouse lung development (denoted as LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef) using Drop-seq of mouse lungs ( = 95,658, 8 time points, 17 samples) from embryonic day 16.5 to postnatal day 28 (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] , Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM5] , 4 [rid=MOESM6] ). 
These tools provide highly interactive search, analyzing, and visualization functionalities for users to explore and reanalyze cell type and gene expression patterns provided by the LungMAP CellRefs (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). Users can also select and highlight cells of interest (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
Evaluation of the other three test data samples were shown in Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] . 
As shown in Fig. 5D–I [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] , predicted cell types were well separated and formed clusters. Cell-type-specific marker genes from CellCards were selectively expressed in each predicted cell type, supporting the concordance of the cell identities (Fig. 5E, F [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). The median values of all metrics are greater than 0.92 (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ), supporting the high consistency of the automated CellRef cell type prediction with the original cell annotations. Both the LungMAP human and mouse lung CellRefs achieved high cross validation performance with ~0.92 median F1 and MCC scores for the human lung CellRef and 0.98 median F1 and MCC scores for the mouse lung CellRef, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
We summarized the one-to-one mapped cell types and the unique cell types/states in the Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] . 
Similarly, when applying these stability metrics to CellRef and HLCA using their own data collections, CellRef produced slightly higher scores on SCCAF and TF-IDF; as well as a significantly higher score on cell re-assignment ( = 0.011) as compared to HLCA (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). scTriangulate leverages the computed stability scores to further assess the marginal importance of each annotation (CellRef and HLCA) using a cooperative game theory framework. scTriangulate predicted that 50% ( = 24/48) of the CellRef cell types to be of higher confidence (AEC, AF1, AF2, AM, ASMC, CD8 T, cDC1, cDC2, Ciliated, Goblet, Ionocyte, LEC, Platelet, pMON, Suprabasal, SVEC, VSMC), compared to 46% ( = 27/58) of the HCLA cell types (AT2, aCAP, Pericyte, Mesothelium, Peribronchial fibroblasts and Adventitial fibroblasts, etc.) (Fig. 8D [rid=Fig8] ). 
The overall distributions of iLISI scores in both CellRef and HLCA are not ideal, on average about 15% for CellRef, and 5% for HLCA, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ), likely due to that both atlases were constructed using large collections of heterogeneous data from different biological regions and conditions rather than a well-designed balanced cohort. Nevertheless, CellRef consistently outperforms HLCA on the measurements of iLISI, and has the cLISI scores close to 1, indicating a well separation of the CellRef cell types (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
Results supported the high accuracy, cluster stability, and marker specificity of our mouse lung reference cell types (Supplementary Fig. 12 [this file] ; mean AUC 95.8, mean SCCAF score: 0.970, mean Reassign score: 0.881, mean TFID10 score: 0.892).

context_description:
Using this guided approach and a cell type dictionary derived from LungMAP CellCards (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ), we identified 8,080 seed cells representing 48 normal human lung cell types, termed LungMAP Human Lung CellRef Seed (Fig. 2A [rid=Fig2] ). 
Evaluation of cell type annotations using CellRef cell type markers from Supplementary Data 2 [this file] . Percentages of cell type markers (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ) that are differentially expressed in their corresponding cell type predictions ( = 34 cell types) in ( ). 
The human lung CellRef cell type selective markers were generated by including dictionary marker genes (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ) and top selectively expressed markers for each cell type.
pub_title: Guided construction of single cell reference for human and mouse lung

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Data 3
context_description:
Using the same approach, we constructed a cell type dictionary based on the LungMAP CellCards to define cell types in mouse lung during perinatal development, identified seed cells for each cell type (termed LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef Seed”), and constructed a CellRef for mouse lung development (denoted as LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef) using Drop-seq of mouse lungs ( = 95,658, 8 time points, 17 samples) from embryonic day 16.5 to postnatal day 28 (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 3 [this file] , 4 [rid=MOESM6] ). 
In total, gene expression in 17 Drop-seq samples from eight time points (Supplementary Data 3 [this file] ) of mouse lung development were generated.
pub_title: Guided construction of single cell reference for human and mouse lung

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Data 4
context_description:
Using the same approach, we constructed a cell type dictionary based on the LungMAP CellCards to define cell types in mouse lung during perinatal development, identified seed cells for each cell type (termed LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef Seed”), and constructed a CellRef for mouse lung development (denoted as LungMAP Mouse Lung Development CellRef) using Drop-seq of mouse lungs ( = 95,658, 8 time points, 17 samples) from embryonic day 16.5 to postnatal day 28 (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 4 [rid=MOESM1] , Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM5] , 4 [this file] ). In total, 40 mouse lung cell types have been identified with the guidance of the mouse lung cell type dictionary (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ). 
We constructed a cell type dictionary for mouse lung (Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ) based on our constructed dictionary derived from the LungMAP CellCards.

AUCs values for each of the mapped cell types ( = 42) in the CellRef (orange) and HLCA (blue) calculated using the cell type selective marker genes identified by CellRef (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). 
Next, we performed the same analysis using the cell type marker genes identified by CellRef (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). 
Top-ranked cell type specific DEGs (ranked by fold change in average expression) were combined with the known markers genes to form the CellRef cell type selective marker gene list (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] , up to 10 genes for each of the 48 CellRef human lung cell types).
