title: 10.1038/ng.3168
pub_title: Pan-Cancer Network Analysis Identifies Combinations of Rare Somatic Mutations across Pathways and Protein Complexes - PMC

title: NIHMS644198-supplement-1.pdf
context_description:
We assembled a TCGA Pan-Cancer dataset of exome sequencing, array copy number, and RNA-seq data from 3,281 samples from 12 cancer types, analyzing single nucleotide variants (SNVs), small indels, and copy number aberrations (CNAs) in 19,424 transcripts ( Figure 1a [href=#F1] and Supplementary Figure 1 [href=this file] ). The resulting “star subnetworks” centered on the hot node ( Supplementary Figure 2 [href=this file] ; Online Methods) contain many neighboring genes that are not mutated at appreciable frequency and are of limited biological interest.
We introduce the HotNet2 (HotNet iffusion riented ubnetworks) algorithm to address the problem of finding significantly mutated subnetworks on large, broad mutation frequency spectrum datasets like Pan-Cancer ( Figure 1c [href=#F1] and Supplementary Figure 3 [href=this file] ). HotNet2 uses a modified diffusion process and considers the source, or directionality, of heat flow in the identification of subnetworks ( Supplementary Figure 4 [href=this file] ).
We combined the resulting subnetworks into 14 consensus subnetworks that were found across different gene scores and networks ( < 0.004, Supplementary Table 3 [href=#SD2] ), plus the condensin complex and CLASP/CLIP proteins ( Supplementary Figure 5 [href=this file] ) that were significant in individual interaction networks ( Supplementary Tables 6,7 [href=#SD2] ). We developed an online interactive viewer (see URLs and Supplementary Figure 6 [href=this file] ) for Pan-Cancer HotNet2 subnetworks.
The subnetworks and linker genes ( Figure 2a [href=#F2] ) include: portions of well-known cancer pathways such as TP53, PI3K, NOTCH, and receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs; Supplementary Figure 7 [href=this file] ), as well as pathways and complexes that have more recently been observed to be important in cancer such as SWI/SNF complex, BAP1 complex, NFE2L2-KEAP1 ( Supplementary Figures 8,9 [href=this file] ), and RUNX1-CBFB core binding complex ( Supplementary Figure 10 [href=this file] ). The fifth most mutated subnetwork (16.9% of samples) consists of MLL2 and MLL3 and the putative interacting protein KDM6A ( Supplementary Figure 11 [href=this file] ), and was highly mutated (28.9% of samples) in TCGA Pan-Cancer squamous integrated subtype . The MHC Class I subnetwork ( Supplementary Figure 12 [href=this file] ) is an example of the ability of HotNet2 ability to identify rarely mutated cancer genes; all of the genes in the subnetwork are mutated in fewer than 35 samples (1.1%), yet four of the five genes have recently been proposed as novel cancer genes . Additional analyses are in the Supplementary Note [href=this file] .
To obtain additional support for these genes we examined whether they had either an excess of inactivating mutations or a cluster of missense mutations in protein sequence (using NMC ) or in protein structure (using iPAC ; Supplementary Figures 13,14 [href=this file] and Supplementary Tables 21,22 [href=#SD2] ). We find that genes in HotNet2 consensus subnetworks are enriched for inactivating mutations ( < 0.0001) or mutation clusters ( < 0.0001) compared to genes not in subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 6–18 [href=#SD2] and Supplementary Note Section 5.1 [href=this file] ). Finally, we evaluated a subset of the mutations in these genes using RNA-Seq and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) data from the same samples, and found RNA-Seq and/or WGS reads that validated 39 mutations in these novel genes ( Supplementary Note Section 6 [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 23 [href=#SD2] ).
This exclusivity was largely due to LUAD samples with mutually exclusive and mutations ( Supplementary Figure 15 [href=this file] ).
The three largest subnetworks – including a subnetwork, a subnetwork, and a subnetwork – contain many well-known cancer genes ( Supplementary Tables 8–10 [href=#SD2] and Supplementary Figures 16,17 [href=this file] ).
The subnetwork also includes , which has a significant ( < 8×10 ) cluster of missense mutations ( Supplementary Figure 18 [href=this file] ).
We find that mutations in the SWI/SNF and BAP1 complexes show even greater mutual exclusivity ( =9.4×10 ) in KIRC because of mutations in additional genes in these complexes besides and , respectively ( Supplementary Note Section 5.8.1 [href=this file] ).
Finally, RNA-seq and whole-genome sequencing data from the same samples provide further validation of the somatic mutations in , , , , , and and show that some of these mutations are expressed ( Supplementary Note Section 6 [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 39 [href=#SD2] ).
Our analysis complements other recent Pan-Cancer analyses including studies that analyze only one type of aberration or restrict attention to recurrent aberrations ( Supplementary Note Section 8.3 [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 27 [href=#SD2] ).
We selected the threshold of 400 aberrations per sample as the derivative of the number of mutations per sample starts increasing rapidly beyond this value ( Supplementary Figure 19 [href=this file] ). Finally, we used only those genes that had at least 3 reads from RNA-seq data in at least 70% of samples of at least one of the cancer types, as described in The resulting dataset contained aberrations in 11,565 genes and 3110 samples ( Supplementary Figure 1 [href=this file] ). Additional details of the datasets are in the Supplementary Note [href=this file] .
While interaction networks have proven useful in analyzing various types of genomic data , statistically robust identification of significantly mutated subnetworks is a difficult problem with several major challenges ( Supplemental Note Section 1.1 [href=this file] ). HotNet2 addresses these challenges and identifies significantly mutated subnetworks of a genome-scale interaction network, using an insulated heat diffusion process that considers both the scores on individual genes/proteins as well as the topology of interactions between genes/proteins ( Supplementary Figure 3 [href=this file] ).
The insulated heat model can also described in terms of a random walk with restart ( Supplementary Note Section 1.2 [href=this file] ).
Since the diffusion matrix is not symmetric and in general ( ) ≠ ( ), the similarity ( , ) is also not symmetric ( Supplementary Note Section 1.2.1 [href=this file] ).
The statistical test is the same as the two-stage statistical test introduced in the original HotNet algorithm ( Supplementary Note Section 1.3 [href=this file] , Supplementary Figures 20–23 [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 28 [href=#SD2] ).
HotNet2 has two parameters β and δ, and selects values for both of these parameters using procedures. β is selected from the protein-protein interaction network, of any gene scores ( Supplementary Note Section 1.4.1 [href=this file] , Supplementary Figure 24 [href=this file] , and Supplementary Table 29 [href=#SD2] ). The value of δ is chosen such that large connected components are not found using the observed gene score distribution on random networks with the same degree distribution as the observed network ( Supplementary Note Section 1.4.2 [href=this file] , Supplementary Figure 25 [href=this file] , and Supplementary Table 30 [href=#SD2] ).
See Supplementary Figure 2 [href=this file] .
Expanding on this third point, when undirected diffusion algorithms like HotNet or related network propagation algorithms are run on large datasets containing a wide range of gene scores (e.g. the Pan-Cancer dataset), many of the resulting subnetworks are “hot” determined by a single high-scoring node and the immediate neighbors of this node ( Supplementary Figure 2 [href=this file] ).
The HotNet2 subnetworks also have a higher fraction of interactions with proteins other than a hot central node ( Supplementary Note Section 7.1 [href=this file] ). In short, the results show that HotNet2 achieves higher sensitivity and specificity than HotNet ( Supplementary Note Section 7.2 [href=this file] and Supplementary Figure 26 [href=this file] ).
We find that HotNet2 provides both new insights and a simpler summary of groups of interacting genes, and is a useful complement (or arguably a replacement for) other pathway tests ( Supplementary Note Section 8.1 [href=this file] ). We also show that HotNet2 has much higher specificity than HotNet, DAVID, and GSEA in identifying genes satisfying the 20/20 rule ( Supplementary Note Section 8.1.4 [href=this file] , Supplementary Figure 27 [href=this file] , and Supplementary Tables 34–36 [href=#SD2] ). Finally, we find that HotNet2 was more stable than HotNet in identifying 20/20 genes using cross-validation ( Supplementary Note Section 7.3 [href=this file] and Supplementary Figure 28 [href=this file] ).
We found that MEMo was unable to run on the Pan-Cancer mutation frequency dataset, consistent with the authors’ recommendation that MEMo should be run only on a small number of significant mutations (details in Supplementary Note Section 8.2 [href=this file] ).
We ran HotNet2 on each combination of gene scores (mutation frequency and MutSigCV -values; see Supplementary Note Section 2.2 [href=this file] ) and interaction networks (HINT+HI2012 , iRefIndex , and Multinet ; Supplementary Note Section 2.5 [href=this file] and Supplementary Figure 29 [href=this file] ). This procedure is described in Supplementary Note Section 1.5 [href=this file] .
Additional details of the statistical procedure are in Supplementary Note Section 1.3 [href=this file] .
Notable among the additional subnetworks identified when we remove the requirement for RNA-Seq expression is a subnetwork ( Supplementary Table 25 [href=#SD2] ) containing members of the telomerase complex (including and ) that has a well-studied role in cancer ( Supplementary Figure 30 [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 38 [href=#SD2] ).
pub_title: Pan-Cancer Network Analysis Identifies Combinations of Rare Somatic Mutations across Pathways and Protein Complexes - PMC

title: NIHMS644198-supplement-2.xlsx
context_description:
HotNet2 identified a significant number of subnetworks ( < 0.01 Supplementary Tables 1–2 [href=this file] ) for each of the two gene scores and three networks. We combined the resulting subnetworks into 14 consensus subnetworks that were found across different gene scores and networks ( < 0.004, Supplementary Table 3 [href=this file] ), plus the condensin complex and CLASP/CLIP proteins ( Supplementary Figure 5 [href=#SD1] ) that were significant in individual interaction networks ( Supplementary Tables 6,7 [href=this file] ).
Many of the subnetworks exhibit a significant enrichment for mutations in a subset of cancer types, including many previously unreported associations ( Supplementary Tables 6–18 [href=this file] ). In addition, the HotNet2 Pan-Cancer analysis provides a clearer and more robust summary of subnetworks and novel genes than HotNet2 analysis of individual cancer types ( Supplementary Table 19 [href=this file] ).
These subnetworks and linkers include a total of 147 genes, including many well-known cancer genes and pathways, but also including genes with mutations that are too rare to be significant by the single-gene tests ( Supplementary Table 20 [href=this file] ). Table 1 [href=#T1] lists a subset of promising candidates, with the full list and associated references in Supplementary Table 20 [href=this file] .
More information on these genes – as well as other candidate driver genes – is in Supplementary Table 20 [href=this file] .
To obtain additional support for these genes we examined whether they had either an excess of inactivating mutations or a cluster of missense mutations in protein sequence (using NMC ) or in protein structure (using iPAC ; Supplementary Figures 13,14 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Tables 21,22 [href=this file] ). We find that genes in HotNet2 consensus subnetworks are enriched for inactivating mutations ( < 0.0001) or mutation clusters ( < 0.0001) compared to genes not in subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 6–18 [href=this file] and Supplementary Note Section 5.1 [href=#SD1] ). Finally, we evaluated a subset of the mutations in these genes using RNA-Seq and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) data from the same samples, and found RNA-Seq and/or WGS reads that validated 39 mutations in these novel genes ( Supplementary Note Section 6 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 23 [href=this file] ).
Multiple pairs of genes within these subnetworks show co-occurring mutations ( Supplementary Table 24 [href=this file] ). We observe significant mutual exclusivity within 4 of our subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 25 [href=this file] ).
The three largest subnetworks – including a subnetwork, a subnetwork, and a subnetwork – contain many well-known cancer genes ( Supplementary Tables 8–10 [href=this file] and Supplementary Figures 16,17 [href=#SD1] ).
HotNet2 Pan-Cancer analyses also revealed a number of novel genes ( Supplementary Table 20 [href=this file] ) within these three subnetworks.
The sixth most mutated HotNet2 Pan-Cancer subnetwork (16.8% of samples) includes multiple members of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex ( Figure 3a [href=#F3] and Supplementary Table 12 [href=this file] ).
Another HotNet2 Pan-Cancer subnetwork (mutated in 7.1% of samples) overlaps the BAP1 complex ( Figure 3b [href=#F3] and Supplementary Table 13 [href=this file] ).
HotNet2 Pan-Cancer analysis identifies 4/5 members of the cohesin complex as a significantly mutated subnetwork (7.3% of samples, Figure 4a [href=#F4] and Supplementary Table 15 [href=this file] ).
The combined subnetwork is mutated in 4.2% of samples ( Figure 4b [href=#F4] and Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ). Finally, RNA-seq and whole-genome sequencing data from the same samples provide further validation of the somatic mutations in , , , , , and and show that some of these mutations are expressed ( Supplementary Note Section 6 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 39 [href=this file] ).
Some of these rarely mutated genes are inevitably false positive predictions of the analysis, but many (including , , , , , and others) exhibit either mutational clustering or protein interactions that support a role for the observed somatic aberrations ( Supplementary Tables 6–18 [href=this file] ).
Our analysis complements other recent Pan-Cancer analyses including studies that analyze only one type of aberration or restrict attention to recurrent aberrations ( Supplementary Note Section 8.3 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 27 [href=this file] ).
The statistical test is the same as the two-stage statistical test introduced in the original HotNet algorithm ( Supplementary Note Section 1.3 [href=#SD1] , Supplementary Figures 20–23 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 28 [href=this file] ).
HotNet2 has two parameters β and δ, and selects values for both of these parameters using procedures. β is selected from the protein-protein interaction network, of any gene scores ( Supplementary Note Section 1.4.1 [href=#SD1] , Supplementary Figure 24 [href=#SD1] , and Supplementary Table 29 [href=this file] ). We evaluated the sensitivity of the HotNet2 results to the value of β and found that varying β ±10% has only a minor effect on the results, with at most 7 genes (3.8% of total) added/removed from the subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 28 [href=this file] ). The value of δ is chosen such that large connected components are not found using the observed gene score distribution on random networks with the same degree distribution as the observed network ( Supplementary Note Section 1.4.2 [href=#SD1] , Supplementary Figure 25 [href=#SD1] , and Supplementary Table 30 [href=this file] ). We evaluated the sensitivity of the HotNet2 results to the value of δ, and found that varying δ ±5% changed at most 35 genes (12.3% of total) in the subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 29 [href=this file] ).
We found that HotNet2 returns >80% fewer hot stars/spiders than HotNet on the Pan-Cancer datasets ( Supplementary Table 31 [href=this file] ). This is a major difference between the algorithms and is one of the reasons why HotNet fails to find statistically significant results ( ≤ 0.01 for any subnetwork size ) on three of six runs ( Supplementary Table 32,33 [href=this file] ), while HotNet2 finds statistically significant results on all six runs.
We also show that HotNet2 has much higher specificity than HotNet, DAVID, and GSEA in identifying genes satisfying the 20/20 rule ( Supplementary Note Section 8.1.4 [href=#SD1] , Supplementary Figure 27 [href=#SD1] , and Supplementary Tables 34–36 [href=this file] ).
Most of the subnetworks (12/14) identified by HotNet2 were also found when we remove the requirement for RNA-Seq expression ( Supplementary Table 37 [href=this file] ). Notable among the additional subnetworks identified when we remove the requirement for RNA-Seq expression is a subnetwork ( Supplementary Table 25 [href=this file] ) containing members of the telomerase complex (including and ) that has a well-studied role in cancer ( Supplementary Figure 30 [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 38 [href=this file] ). We found only minor differences in the HotNet2 subnetworks ( Supplementary Table 39 [href=this file] ), demonstrating that our reported subnetworks are altered by somatic aberrations in these samples.

pub_title: Comprehensive characterization of claudin-low breast tumors reflects the impact of the cell-of-origin on cancer evolution

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
As gene expression analyses do not allow to accurately discriminate mesenchymal cancer cells from normal stromal cells, we used the allele-specific copy number analysis of tumors (ASCAT) copy number-based tumor purity estimation method to assess tumor cell fraction (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). To avoid any substantial bias due to non-tumor cell contamination, a stringent purity threshold was determined by applying Wilcoxon test, for which the degree of contamination of claudin-low tumors was not statistically different from that of non-claudin-low tumors, thus enabling a comparable distribution of tumors (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). Demonstrating an unexpected degree of diversity, only 35.6% of these tumors were classified as TNBCs (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ). This result was not due to the purity selection, as the percentage of TNBCs within all claudin-low tumors was similar before applying the purity threshold (Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). 
Only 17.8% were found in cluster 10, whereas 48.8% and 17.8% were found in integrative clusters 4 and 3, respectively, regardless of tumor purity when compared with non-claudin-low tumors (Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). After having previously removed germline copy number variations (CNVs), we analyzed B allele frequency (BAF) and log R ratio (LRR) profiles of single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) localized in genomic regions of deletion (LRR segment mean cutoff value < −0.4) (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 3a, c [this file] ). Consistent with these data, the analysis of somatic mutations highlighted the presence of several point mutations with a variant allele frequency higher than 0.4 (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] ). 
Of note, although these analyses were performed on tumors selected for their high tumor purity, similar data were obtained when studying the whole cohort of claudin-low tumors (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ), further strengthening the characterization of the three claudin-low subgroups. 
Of note, global gene expression signatures demonstrated that the CL2 and CL3 subgroups showed lower luminal- and basal-related signature scores, respectively, compared with luminal- and basal-like breast tumors, while exhibiting a significant enrichment in invasiveness-related signatures (Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). 
A claudin-low gene list of 137 genes discriminating the 3 claudin-low subgroups was thus created (Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). This expression-based classifier showed an accuracy of 91% when compared with the FGA-based classification using Gaussian finite mixture models (Supplementary Fig. 5c, d [this file] ). Validating the accuracy of our classifier, CL1, CL2, and CL3 tumors and cell lines showed low, moderate, and elevated FGA levels, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 6e, f [this file] ). Of note, we performed a pathway analysis of CL1 discriminant genes that revealed an enrichment in stem cell and pediatric cancer markers (Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] ). 
Differentially methylated gene analysis was next performed in claudin-low subgroups followed by pathway-enrichment analysis, using over 15,000 pathways available in MSigDB (HALLMARKS, C2, and C5 gene sets) (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). The CL1 subgroup had the highest score for stemness- ( , ) and EMT- (mesenchymal markers: , , ; epithelial markers: , ) related genes, whereas CL2 and CL3 displayed an intermediate score compared with CL1 tumors and with their relative luminal/basal counterparts (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
CL1 tumors mainly display hypomethylated genes that are related to a stemness phenotype, CL2 tumors are overall hypermethylated for genes associated with basal-like features, and CL3 tumors show more heterogeneous methylation profiles with both hypermethylated genes (linked to luminal phenotype) and hypomethylated genes (relative to basal-like characteristics) (see Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] for methodology). 
Additional gene expression analyses performed on METABRIC and TCGA cohorts using two different cellular signature deconvolution algorithms confirmed that these tumors were highly infiltrated by immune cells (Supplementary Fig. 9a–d [this file] ). Nevertheless, unsupervised clustering of microenvironment signatures (immune and non-immune cell subsets) did not allow to discriminate the different claudin-low subgroups (Supplementary Fig. 9e–h [this file] ). 
Supporting our previous results, CL2 and CL3 showed, among the three claudin-low subgroups, the highest score for luminal- (estrogen-related response) and basal-related (proliferation and DDR) signatures, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] ). Furthermore, both CL2 and CL3 showed an activation of the EMT process (Fig. 6a, b, g [rid=Fig6] ), coherent with the downregulation of hormone (in CL2) and proliferation/DDR (in CL3) signatures, compared with luminal and basal tumors, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 10 [this file] and Fig. 6g [rid=Fig6] ). Moreover, CL1 displayed a low proliferation activity and a low DDR (Supplementary Fig. 10a, b, e, f [this file] ), as well as a strong TP53 signaling pathway signature associated with a low frequency of mutations (Fig. 6c, d, g [rid=Fig6] ). 
When stratified by CL subgroups, variations in survival outcome were found, consistent with their presumed origin (Supplementary Fig. 11 [this file] ). 
These traits include (i) a high expression of the ZEB1 EMT-inducing transcription factor and of its target, the methionine sulfoxide reductase MSRB3; (ii) a frequent activation of the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway; (iii) a low activation of the DDR; and (iv) a low frequency of mutations (Supplementary Figs. 8 [this file] and 10 [this file] , and Fig. 6 [rid=Fig6] ). 
The use of a high-purity threshold for tumor selection allowed to circumvent the contamination bias related to the tumor-related centroid (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Finally, the nearest shrunken centroid classifier encompassed 137 genes whose expression discriminate the three FGA-related claudin-low subgroups in METABRIC cohort (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
As previously described for genome-wide expression–methylation quantitative trait loci analysis , genes for which methylation -values were negatively correlated with expression values (Spearman’s < 0 and FDR -value < 0.05) were selected for differential methylation analysis (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ).

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Data 1
context_description:
Gene expression signatures for MaSCs, LPs, and mL cells were generated based on the transcription profiles of subpopulations of normal human mammary epithelial cells isolated from reduction mammoplasty tissues, as shown in Morel et al. (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
The top 500 false discovery rate (FDR) -value ranked genes differentially expressed between one subpopulation (MaSC or LP, or mL cells) vs. the two others (FDR -value < 0.05) were used as transcriptomic signature for each of the three cell subpopulations (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ).

context_description:
This cohort (n=104) comprised neurotypical (healthy) controls (HC, n = 38), and individuals with SCZ (ISCZ, n=38), BD (n = 20) and MDD (n = 8) ( Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ) with a mean age of onset in the late 20s adolescence (mean 28.5/27.1/29.1 SCZ/BD/MDD). 
From the latter, we also included a cohort of Amish individuals suffering from BD/MDD and respective controls, see Supplementary Table 1 [this file] .
pub_title: Polygenic risk for schizophrenia converges on alternative polyadenylation as molecular mechanism underlying synaptic impairment

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Table 2. Summary of eQTL, caQTL and microRNA qTLs identified in this study
description: Supplement  2  Supplementary  Table  2.  Summary  of  eQTL,  caQTL  and  microRNA  qTLs  identified  in  this  study  Separate  Excel  file.
context_description:
Importantly, 55.4% of the identified eQTLs overlapped with eQTLs identified in adult human tissue from the prefrontal cortex (PFC) , supporting their relevance ( Fig. 1f [rid=F1] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). Nevertheless, 21.7% of the identified open chromatin peaks associated with caQTLs overlapped with eQTLs detected in bulk PFC. ( Fig. 1g [rid=F1] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, the overlap of QTLs across molecular features in iNs was limited, with 24.9% of eQTL overlapping with caQTLs ( Fig. 1l [rid=F1] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ). Moreover, 28 genes, 78 peaks and no microRNA with e/ca/miQTLs overlapped with GWAS risk loci for SCZ ( Fig. 1f [rid=F1] - h [rid=F1] and Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ).
pub_title: Polygenic risk for schizophrenia converges on alternative polyadenylation as molecular mechanism underlying synaptic impairment

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Table 3. Summary of differentially expressed genes (DEGs), microRNAs (DiffmicroRNA) and differential APA analysis (dAPA)
description: Supplement  3  Supplementary  Table  3.  Summary  of  differentially  expressed  genes  (DEGs),  microRNAs  (DiffmicroRNA)  and  differential  APA  analysis  (dAPA)  Separate  Excel  file.
context_description:
Following a detailed power evaluation ( Extended Data Fig. 3b [rid=F9] - d [rid=F9] ), we performed differential expression analysis and identified 467 transcripts (365 protein coding and 102 non-coding transcripts) (FDR≤0.01, ∣log FC∣≥0.4; Fig. 2a [rid=F2] and Extended Data Fig. 3e [rid=F9] , and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ), henceforth referred to as DEGs as well as 67 micro RNAs (FDR≤0.05; Fig. 2b [rid=F2] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
This analysis revealed widespread differences in APA, identifying 628 differential APA (dAPA) events ( Fig. 3c [rid=F3] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ) that resulted from an increased usage of either the distal or the proximal PAS to similar degree (14.29% of all genes with more than 1 polyadenylation site). 
Consistent with the observations in iNs, this analysis confirmed widespread dAPA in postmortem PFC from ISCZ ( Fig. 3e [rid=F3] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ) as well as substantial overlap with dAPA in iNs ( Fig. 3f [rid=F3] ). 
Strikingly, genes subject to dAPA in ISCZ were strongly enriched for synapse related processes such as glutamatergic neurotransmission, synaptic membrane components, synaptic plasticity or vesicle biology in both iNs and human PFC ( Fig. 4a [rid=F4] , b [rid=F4] , and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
RBP motif analysis in the UTRs of transcripts subject to dAPA identified numerous expressed RBPs with critical roles for neuronal biology such as QKI, ELAVL and RBM proteins ( Fig. 5c [rid=F5] and Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Similarly, we also corrected the R values for gender, batch and TechnicalPC1 using beta regression and used the residuals to compute the average difference in R values between the groups (ΔAPA, Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
Resulting enrichment scores and p-values for the set of transcripts with increased usage of the distal PAS are depicted in Fig. 5c [rid=F5] with p-values corrected for multiple testing using the q-value method and listed in Supplementary Table 3 [this file] .
pub_title: Polygenic risk for schizophrenia converges on alternative polyadenylation as molecular mechanism underlying synaptic impairment

context_description:
MAP2, RTF2 or Distal/Proximal UTR, Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) were used to calculate target specific relative expression as 2^(-(CT -CT )) giving rise to normalized transcript levels. 
Statistical testing of NRIs ( Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ) was conducted using by linear mixed models as implemented in the lme4 R package modeling diagnosis or treatment as fixed effect and batch as well as donor (for PSD95 analysis) as random effect. 
All well level density values used can be found in Supplementary Table 4 [this file] .

context_description: To identify how many of the direct SIRT2 targets are validated known SIRT2 substrates, we conducted an extensive literature review to curate experimentally validated SIRT2 substrates (Supplementary Table S4 [href=this file] ). title: Identification and validation of comprehensive characterization of colorectal cancer (CCCRC) classification.
caption: (a) The 61 tumor microenvironment (TME)-related signatures used to comprehensively characterize CRC. (b) Overlapping genes between 61 TME-related signatures. (c) The datasets used to identify and validate of CCCRC classification. (d) Univariate cox analysis and Kaplan–Meier method showing the ability of the 61 TME-related signatures to predict disease-free survival and overall survival in the CRC-AFFY cohort. (e) Difference analysis of metabolism signature scores between the four CCCRC subtypes in the CRC-AFFY cohort. (f) The information of clinicopathological characteristics and CCCRC subtypes in the CRC-AFFY and CRC-RNAseq cohorts. (g) Associations between clinicopathological characteristics and CCCRC subtypes. (h) Multivariate Cox proportional hazard regression analysis for disease-free survival and overall survival adjusting for the CCCRC subtypes and clinicopathological characteristics in the combined cohort (the CRC-AFFY and CRC-RNAseq cohorts). (1) A total of 254 hematoxylin and eosin (HE)-stained whole-slide images used to evaluate histological characteristics of CCCRC subtypes.
description: Supplementary  file  1.  Identification  and  validation  of  comprehensive  characterization  of  colorectal  cancer  (CCCRC)  classification.  (a)  The  61  tumor  microenvironment  (TME)-related  signatures  used  to  comprehensively  characterize  CRC.  (b)  Overlapping  genes  between  61  TME-related  signatures.  (c)  The  datasets  used  to  identify  and  validate  of  CCCRC  classification.  (d)  Univariate  cox  analysis  and  Kaplan–Meier  method  showing  the  ability  of  the  61  TME-related  signatures  to  predict  disease-free  survival  and  overall  survival  in  the  CRC-AFFY  cohort.  (e)  Difference  analysis  of  metabolism  signature  scores  between  the  four  CCCRC  subtypes  in  the  CRC-AFFY  cohort.  (f)  The  information  of  clinicopathological  characteristics  and  CCCRC  subtypes  in  the  CRC-AFFY  and  CRC-RNAseq  cohorts.  (g)  Associations  between  clinicopathological  characteristics  and  CCCRC  subtypes.  (h)  Multivariate  Cox  proportional  hazard  regression  analysis  for  disease-free  survival  and  overall  survival  adjusting  for  the  CCCRC  subtypes  and  clinicopathological  characteristics  in  the  combined  cohort  (the  CRC-AFFY  and  CRC-RNAseq  cohorts).  (1)  A  total  of  254  hematoxylin  and  eosin  (HE)-stained  whole-slide  images  used  to  evaluate  histological  characteristics  of  CCCRC  subtypes.
context_description:
According to the above biological framework, a total of 61 TME-related signatures were collected to form the TME panel ( Supplementary file 1a [this file] , Supplementary file 1b [this file] ), which ultimately established a holistic approach to thoroughly dissect the TME of CRC. 
Principal component analysis (PCA) indicated that after using the ‘ComBat’ function to remove batch effects, there was no significant batch effect in the merged cohorts of eight microarray datasets ( Figure 1—figure supplement 1A, B [rid=fig1s1] ) and two RNA sequencing datasets ( Figure 1—figure supplement 1C, D [rid=fig1s1] , Supplementary file 1c [this file] ). 
The stromal and tumor components significantly were correlated with decreased survival, particularly in the case of mesenchymal cells, endothelial cells, metastasis, differentiation, and EMT signatures ( Figure 1—figure supplement 1L [rid=fig1s1] , Supplementary file 1d [this file] ). 
Differences in the TME components between the CCCRC subtypes were also observed in the analysis of previously reported immune and stromal signatures obtained by the microenvironment cell populations (MCP)-counter, CIBERSORT, and ESTIMATE algorithm, and 10 classical oncogenic pathway activities and 86 metabolic pathway enrichment scores calculated by GSVA ( Figure 1—figure supplement 3A–E [rid=fig1s3] , Supplementary file 1e [this file] ). 
We analyzed the 86 metabolic pathways obtained from the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) database ( Supplementary file 1e [this file] ) and observed that the number of upregulated metabolic pathways of the C3 subtype was the lowest. 
We further analyzed the association of CCCRC subtypes with clinicopathological characteristics ( Supplementary file 1f [this file] , Supplementary file 1g [this file] ). Multivariate Cox proportional hazard regression analysis showed that the C4 subtype was an independent predictor of the best OS and DFS, whereas the C3 subtype was an independent predictor of the worst OS and DFS after adjustment for age, gender, tumor site, TNM stage, grade, adjuvant chemotherapy or not, MSI status, BRAF and KRAS mutations, and the CMS classification system in the combined cohort (the CRC-AFFY and CRC-RNAseq cohorts) ( Supplementary file 1h [this file] ). 
The 254 CRC samples in the TCGA-CRC dataset were categorized as these three phenotypes based on the abundance of lymphocytes and their spatial location with malignant epithelial cells ( Supplementary file 1i [this file] ). 
A total of 2196 samples were obtained from ten publicly available datasets ( Supplementary file 1c [this file] ). Detailed information on the sample size and the corresponding clinicopathological data of the CRC-AFFY and CRC-RNAseq cohorts are summarized in Supplementary file 1c [this file] and Supplementary file 1f [this file] . 
The 4525 genes from each of the 61 TME-related signatures are listed in Supplementary file 1a [this file] , as well as the source of each signature. 
A total of 254 WSIs were included after removing the WSIs with poor quality and without views of the IM ( Supplementary file 1i [this file] ). 
The markers for the six cell types are listed in the Supplementary file 1a [this file] and Supplementary file 3a [rid=supp3] .
pub_title: Comprehensive characterization of tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer via molecular analysis

(c) Lists of differentially expressed genes between each of the four subtypes and the remaining subtypes and between each subtype. (d) The correlation between all genes and the exclusion and dysfunction scores obtained from the Tumor Immune Dysfunction and Exclusion (TIDE) website. The  different  frequency  of  somatic  copy  number  alterations  between  the  four  CCCRC  subtypes  in  TCGA-CRC  dataset. context_description:
Among the frequently mutated genes (>5%), the mutation frequencies of (85.8%), (64.9%), and (46.7%) were the highest in the C1 subtype compared to the other subtypes (all p-value <0.05), followed by the C3, C2, and C4 subtypes, which are closely associated with the occurrence of CRC ( Figure 3A [rid=fig3] , Supplementary file 2a [this file] ). In terms of the differences in SCNA, the C1 subtype with the highest CIN level harbored significantly more amplified chromosomal regions (20q12, 20q13.12, 20q11.21, and 20q13.32) and deleted chromosomal regions (18q21.2, 18q22.1, and 18q12.3) (all p-value <0.05) ( Figure 3A, B [rid=fig3] , Supplementary file 2b [this file] ). The C4 subtype had the highest frequency of mutations in the cell cycle, HIPPO, MYC, NOTCH, PI3K, TGFB, and RTK–RAS pathways (all p-value <0.05) ( Figure 3C [rid=fig3] , Supplementary file 2c [this file] ). 
The lists of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between CCCRC subtypes were compiled in Supplementary file 2d [this file] . In addition, we also analyzed the correlations between all genes and the exclusion and dysfunction scores obtained from the Tumor Immune Dysfunction and Exclusion (TIDE) website, as well as the MSI expression signature, which provided a useful reference for subsequent research in the discovery of new therapeutic targets ( Supplementary file 2e [this file] ). 
Furthermore, we intersected all the positives for increasing gene expression from C1 to C4, C2, and C3 subtypes in the CRC-AFFY and CRC-RNAseq cohorts and obtained 20 CCCRC genes ( Figure 4E [rid=fig4] , Supplementary file 2f [this file] ), which were associated with TGF-beta signaling and infiltrating nerves. 
We obtained the GEP for 7766T cells from 12 patients with CRC, including four patients with the C1 subtype, one patient with the C2 subtype, two patients with the C3 subtype, and four patients with the C4 subtype ( Supplementary file 2g [this file] ). The markers of the T cell clusters were summarized in Supplementary file 2h [this file] . 
For instance, KDM1A and RAD21 are specific genes for C1 subtype, and it has been reported that interfering with them could activate interferon signaling and induce tumor intrinsic immunogenicity ( Deng et al., 2022 [rid=bib26] ; Nguyen et al., 2022 [rid=bib65] ; Supplementary file 2d [this file] ). In this study, the expression levels of SPP1 and SERPINB9 were found to be significantly positively correlated with the exclusion and dysfunction scores (TIDE score), respectively ( Supplementary file 2e [this file] ). 
A total of 12 CRC samples with bulk RNAseq and scRNAseq data were obtained from the GSE108989 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE108989) dataset ( Zhang et al., 2018 [rid=bib96] ; Supplementary file 2g [this file] ).

title: Clinical application of comprehensive characterization of colorectal cancer (CCCRC) classification system.
caption: (a) The 335 CCCRC subtype-specific and cancer cell-intrinsic gene markers used to construct the pre-clinical model. (b) The 71 human colorectal cancer cell lines grouped according to CCCRC classification system. (c) A total of 80 upregulated subtype-specific genes used to construct the CCCRC classifier. (d) The performance of the CCCRC classifier in the CRC-AFFY and the CRC-RNAseq cohort. Lists of 86 human metabolism-related signatures, 10 oncogenic signatures and terminally exhausted T cell signature. (e) Transcription factors and chromatin modifiers in colorectal cancer. (f) Publicly available CRC molecular classification systems. (g) The datasets used to reveal the therapy strategies for four CCCRC subtypes.
description: Supplementary  file  3.  Clinical  application  of  comprehensive  characterization  of  colorectal  cancer  (CCCRC)  classification  system.  (a)  The  335  CCCRC  subtype-specific  and  cancer  cell-intrinsic  gene  markers  used  to  construct  the  pre-clinical  model.  (b)  The  71  human  colorectal  cancer  cell  lines  grouped  according  to  CCCRC  classification  system.  (c)  A  total  of  80  upregulated  subtype-specific  genes  used  to  construct  the  CCCRC  classifier.  (d)  The  performance  of  the  CCCRC  classifier  in  the  CRC-AFFY  and  the  CRC-RNAseq  cohort.  Lists  of  86  human  metabolism-related  signatures,  10  oncogenic  signatures  and  terminally  exhausted  T  cell  signature.  (e)  Transcription  factors  and  chromatin  modifiers  in  colorectal  cancer.  (f)  Publicly  available  CRC  molecular  classification  systems.  (g)  The  datasets  used  to  reveal  the  therapy  strategies  for  four  CCCRC  subtypes.
context_description:
To further explore the treatment strategies of the CCCRC subtypes, we trained a pre-clinical model based on a filtered gene set comprised of 335 CCCRC subtype-specific and cancer cell-intrinsic gene markers ( Supplementary file 3a [this file] ). The 71 human CRC cell lines were classified into four CCCRC subtypes ( Supplementary file 3b [this file] ). 
We established the CCCRC classifier on the training set by utilizing multiple machine learning algorithms based on the GEP of 80 upregulated subtype-specific genes (Materials and methods, Supplementary file 3c [this file] ). Notably, the CCCRC classifier based on the xgboost algorithm displayed robust performance across gene expression platforms, Affymetrix and RNA-sequencing platforms, exhibiting a balanced accuracy of >80% for all subtypes ( Supplementary file 3d [this file] ). 
The 1660 genes assigned to 86 human metabolism-related pathways are listed in Supplementary file 3e [this file] . Ten oncogenic signatures containing 331 genes and the terminally exhausted T cell signature were retrieved from a previously published study ( Beltra et al., 2020 [rid=bib11] ; Sanchez-Vega et al., 2018 [rid=bib73] ; Supplementary file 3e [this file] ). 
The R package ‘RTN’ was used to reconstruct the transcriptional regulatory networks of regulons ( Robertson et al., 2017 [rid=bib69] ), including 31 transcription factors and 82 chromatin remodeling genes, that were associated with CRC ( Vymetalkova et al., 2019 [rid=bib85] ; Xu et al., 2021 [rid=bib91] ; Supplementary file 3f [this file] ). 
To classify CRC samples into different CRC subtypes according to the previously published gene classifier, gene lists for the four classifiers were extracted from relevant publications and summarized ( Supplementary file 3g [this file] ). 
Detailed information on the sample size and the corresponding treatment data of the therapy-associated datasets are summarized in Supplementary file 3h [this file] . 
The markers for the six cell types are listed in the Supplementary file 1a [rid=supp1] and Supplementary file 3a [this file] .

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
We sourced frozen post-mortem prefrontal cortex from four CdLS patients aged 19–48 years and six age-matched controls (Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). Three of the patients had heterozygous mutations in , the gene most frequently mutated in CdLS (ref. , Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a, b [this file] ). 
To characterise gene expression in CdLS patient neurons we isolated nuclei from the prefrontal cortex, stained with the neuronal marker NeuN (ref. ), and sorted NeuN positive and NeuN negative nuclei by flow cytometry (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). However, CAGE analysis of promoters showed separation of CdLS patient and control samples along the major principle component PC1, and revealed significant deregulation of 766 gene promoters in CdLS neurons (adj < 0.05; 358 upregulated, 408 downregulated; Supplementary Fig. 2a–c [this file] , Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). Gene promoters that were downregulated in CdLS neurons were enriched for the gene ontology (GO) terms synaptic signalling and organization, ion and neurotransmitter transport, axon development, behavior and cognition, while upregulated promoters showed no striking functional enrichment (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] , Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). RNA-seq identified 617 differentially expressed genes (adj < 0.05) in CdLS neurons, 310 genes were up- and 307 were downregulated (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). In close agreement with CAGE, genes that were downregulated by RNA-seq were related to synaptic transmission, signalling processes, learning and behaviour, and sphingolipid metabolism, while upregulated genes showed no striking functional enrichment (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Data 4 [this file] ). 
The direction of gene deregulation by RNA-seq and CAGE was highly correlated ( = 0.68, = < 2.2e-16 for genes found deregulated by RNA-seq or CAGE, and = 0.95, = < 2.2e-16 for genes found deregulated by both RNA-seq and CAGE; Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] ). 
RNA-seq of NeuN-negative nuclei showed upregulation of immune response genes that were not seen in NeuN-positive nuclei, including interferon response, JAK-STAT signalling, and the complement pathway (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] , Supplementary Data 5 [this file] , 6 [this file] ). There was significant overlap between changes in gene expression in human CdLS with published gene expression in heterozygous mouse brain at embryonic day 13.5 (e13.5; whole brain versus human CdLS NeuN positive and NeuN negative nuclei combined; = 1.32e-14, Odds ratio = 2.05) and with gene expression in cortical neurons in explant culture ( cortical neurons versus human CdLS NeuN positive neurons; Supplementary Data 7 [this file] ; = 8.38e-06, Odds ratio = 3.03). 
We established explant cultures from cortices at e14.5 under conditions that enrich for post-mitotic neurons and promote neuronal maturation (Fig. 2a [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 5a, b [this file] ). 
Constructs were tagged by V5 and t2a-fused GFP (ERt2-TEV) for identification of ERt2-TEV-expressing cells (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). ERt2-TEV remained cytoplasmic until nuclear translocation of ERt2-TEV was triggered, which occurred within minutes of 4-hydroxy tamoxifen (4-OHT) addition (Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). Addition of doxycycline leads to the expression of TEV protease with an exogeneous nuclear localization sequence (NLS-TEV, Supplementary Fig. 6a, b [this file] ). Induction of NLS-TEV depleted ~70% of RAD21-TEV within 24 h of doxycycline addition (Supplementary Fig. 6c [this file] ). 
RNA-seq 24 h after 4-OHT-induced nuclear translocation of ERt2-TEV identified 750 deregulated (adj < 0.05) genes, of which 463 were down- and 287 were upregulated (Fig. 2d [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Data 8 [this file] ). As observed in CdLS neurons, no striking enrichment was observed for upregulated genes (Fig. 2e [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Data 9 [this file] ). 
As observed for the nuclear translocation of ERt2-TEV, downregulated genes were enriched for adhesion, signalling, synaptic function and development (Supplementary Fig. 5d, e [this file] , Supplementary Data 10 [this file] , 11 [this file] ). There was extensive overlap between genes deregulated by acute cohesin depletion with genes deregulated in neurons (this study) and embryonic brain , but less so with genes deregulated in other mouse models of neuronal dysfunction (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
Reduced mRNA expression translated into reduced levels of protein in RAD21-TEV neurons, as illustrated for NLGN1, encoded by (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] , Supplementary Data 12 [this file] ). 
These shared ASD genes mediate important neuronal functions in cell adhesion ( ) signalling ( ), ion channels ( ), synaptic transmission ( ), transcription ( ) and sphingolipid metabolism ( ) (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
Gene expression changes in Rett syndrome, but not other human neurological diseases , showed significant overlap with neurons (Odds ratio = 2.06, = 4.64e-10; Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
Remarkably, comparison of RNA-seq during RAD21-TEV depletion (24 h) and after RAD21-TEV rescue (day 7) showed that the vast majority of genes that were found deregulated after 24 h (695 of 720 or 96.5%) were fully rescued upon restoration of cohesin levels (Fig. 4c, e [rid=Fig4] ; Supplementary Data 13 [this file] ). These experiments confirmed that rescue of gene expression required the restoration of RAD21 expression and was not due to the adaptation of neurons to reduced cohesin expression (Supplementary Fig 10 [this file] ; Supplementary Data 14 [this file] ). 
These included 14 genes implicated in ASD and shared between CdLS and NLS-TEV (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
Sequence data was analysed using the 4 Cseqpipe software suite with the setting of “-stat_type mean -trend_resolution 40,000”. 4C-seq primers are listed in Supplementary Data 15 [this file] .

title: No Title

context_description:
The parameters of each analysis step are summarized in Supplementary Table 3 [this file] . 
Summary statistics of age-at-onset (AAO) for LOAD cases and age-at-last-examination (AAE) for normal controls are presented in Supplementary Table 1 [this file] . The full name and accessibility of each study can be found in Supplementary Table 2 [this file] . 
The variance in AD explained by PRS maximizes at a -value threshold of 0.5 in participants from GERAD (Genetic and Environmental Risk for Alzheimer’s disease) [ 23 [rid=CR23] ] and 22 locally available ADGC (Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium) studies (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
Because our analytic approaches used only subsets of all available LOAD case–control GWAS data, we neither had nor anticipated having sufficient power to detect individual SNPs with genome-wide significant association with resilience (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
In the full samples from three locally downloaded replication studies (Alzheimer Disease Centers Wave 7 [ADC7], AddNeuroMed, and Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative stage GO/2/3 [ADNI-GO/2/3]; normal controls, = 1321; LOAD cases, = 943) (Table 1 [rid=Tab1] and Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ), we tested for correlations between PRSs and polygenic resilience scores.

S8c [this file] , Extended Data Fig. 2f [this file] ), including at different distance thresholds ( Fig. 2c [rid=F2] ). S8c [this file] , Extended Data Fig. 2f [this file] ). We describe detailed evaluations of these other predictors and baseline methods in Note S2 [this file] , Note S3 [this file] , Note S5 [this file] , and Note S7 [this file] . 
ENCODE-rE2G and ENCODE-rE2G perform comparably to other wellperforming models (both with enrichment = 28 at a recall of 15%) ( Fig. 2d [rid=F2] , Table S15 [this file7] ). We also examined fine-mapped eQTL variant-gene links from 11 other GTEx tissues that were represented in ENCODE biosamples ( Table S14 [this file6] ). Using the score threshold corresponding to 70% in the K562 CRISPR dataset, ENCODE-rE2G achieved an average enrichment of 6.5 across tissues (range: 3.5–11.4), similar than other predictive and baseline models, while achieving a stronger recall, identifying an average of 16% (range: 10–22%) of fine-mapped eQTL variants and linking them to the correct eGene ( Extended Data Fig. 3c [this file] , d [this file] ). 
These conclusions were supported by additional benchmarking analyses ( Extended Data Fig. 4 [this file] ). 
S2.1a [this file] ). 
Many ENCODE-rE2G enhancers show elevated levels of active chromatin marks, such as H3K27ac and DNase-seq (mean DNase-seq signal for candidate elements across biosamples = 3.27; mean for enhancers linked to at least one gene = 7.52) — but importantly, many do not (15.6% of enhancers have DNase-seq scores below the global median) ( Extended Data Fig 5h [this file] ). S2.1d [this file] ). In part for this reason, annotations of enhancers based on 1D chromatin state alone miss 33% (chromHMM) or 61% (cCRE Catalog) of ENCODE-rE2G enhancers, as well as 30% or 12%, respectively, of the validated enhancergene pairs from the Nasser ., 2021 unbiased CRISPR DHS tiling dataset ( Extended Data Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
As expected, many element-gene regulatory interactions were highly cell-type specific: 26.4% were present in only one biosample (mean = 34.49, median = 7 biosamples) ( Fig. 3e [rid=F3] ), and predicted regulatory interactions were much more specific than the activity of either the promoters or enhancers alone ( Extended Data Fig 5g [this file] , h [this file] ). 
As previously observed, fine-mapped variants underlying enhancers were often predicted to regulate multiple genes (average=3.4, max=56), including 62% that are linked to different genes in different cell types; this appears to be a fundamental property of enhancer-promoter regulation , and motivates combining locus-specific variant-to-gene information with orthogonal information about gene function ( Note S7 [this file] , Fig S7.1 [this file] ). 
This combination of ENCODE-rE2G and PoPS predicted a target gene for 3,528 out of 13,012 non-coding credible sets with a PIP > 0.1 fine-mapped variant spanning all traits; this included 5,851 out of 29.2K fine-mapped GWAS variants ( Table S13 [this file5] ), representing a 3.7-fold excess overlap compared to control variants (all distal noncoding variants detected in the 1000 Genomes project, =9.2 million) ( Fig. 4b [rid=F4] ). Other interesting examples at the and loci are reported in Note S7 [this file] ( Fig S7.2 [this file] ). 
We provide further analysis and guidelines regarding the value of adding new cell types to the ENCODE resource, assessing tissue-specificity of the ENCODE-rE2G biosample predictions, evaluating other combinations of ENCODE-rE2G and PoPS, and restricting our ENCODE-rE2G analyses to top disease-enriched biosamples for identifying possible cell types and target genes for GWAS loci in Note S7 [this file] ( Fig S7.1 [this file] . 
S4.1 [this file] - 2 [this file] , Note S4 [this file] , Note S5 [this file] ). 
These results are consistent with the importance of enhancer activity and 3D contact in enhancer regulation and highlight the utility of combining them as in the ABC model ( Fig. 2b [rid=F2] , c [rid=F2] , Fig S4.3 [this file] ). 
S11 [this file] ). S11a [this file] ). 
Out of 6 methods for estimating 3D enhancer-promoter contact frequency in the ABC model, we found that the best dataset was cell-type-specific ENCODE Hi-C (precision at 70% recall = 53.8%; Hi-C depth = 2 billion reads, 5-kb resolution), which outperformed other datasets including Hi-C (1 billion reads) or an inverse function of distance (precision at 70% recall = 50.4% or 31.8%, respectively) ( Fig. 5g [rid=F5] , Note S2 [this file] ). S2.1f [this file] , g [this file] ). 
Key additional features were related to promoter class and enhancerenhancer interactions ( Fig. 5b [rid=F5] , h [rid=F5] , Fig S4.4 [this file] ). 
S6.1b [this file] ) to have a fine-mapped eQTL variant in a distal accessible site ( Fig. S6.1a [this file] ). S6.1c [this file] - f [this file] ). Together, these observations support a model in which sequence-intrinsic features of the promoters of ubiquitously expressed genes make them less sensitive to distal enhancers (see Note S6 [this file] ). 
In each dataset, perturbations to individual enhancers on average reduced H3K27ac signal at other nearby enhancers, and the magnitude of the effect decreased as enhancer-enhancer distance increased ( Fig. 6g [rid=F6] , h [rid=F6] , Extended Data Fig. 8 [this file] ). 
S6.1b [this file] ), possibly because they contain built-in motifs for activating transcription factors that buffer them against distal enhancers . 
The CRISPR datasets still have a relatively small number of positive examples; were designed with certain biases in enhancer and gene selection; do not distinguish from effects; are conducted largely in a single cell type (K562); and are underpowered to detect regulatory interactions with small effect sizes ( ., <25%) (see Note S1 [this file] ).

context_description:
We constructed two logistic regression classifiers to predict CRISPR-validated element-gene pairs using different combinations of molecular features ( Tables S1 [this file] , S3 [rid=SD5] ). 
We used this pipeline to evaluate ENCODE-rE2G and 574 other models ( Table S1 [this file] ), including (i) the ABC model, which we re-computed here natively in hg38 using various combinations of ENCODE assays to estimate enhancer activity and enhancer-promoter 3D contact; (ii) previous machine learning models that infer enhancer-gene regulation, including EpiMap , GraphReg , CIA , Enformer , and EPIraction ; and (iii) simple baselines such as linking elements to the closest expressed transcription start site (TSS) or gene, linking elements to genes solely on the basis of loops or domains from 3D contact measurements, or correlating distal element and promoter accessibility across cell types.

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description: We constructed two logistic regression classifiers to predict CRISPR-validated element-gene pairs using different combinations of molecular features ( Tables S1 [rid=SD3] , S3 [this file] ). Specifically, we included features related to (i) chromatin state (quantitative DNase-seq signals at the element and promoter), (ii) 3D contact frequency (averaged from ENCODE Hi-C in 35 diploid biosamples to capture cell-type-invariant features of genome organization); (iii) the Activity-by-Contact (ABC) model , which multiplies enhancer activity and 3D contact frequency; (iv) genomic position ( ., distance from element to promoter); (v) promoter class ( ., whether the gene is uniformly and ubiquitously expressed across cell types ( ., a “housekeeping” gene)); and (vi) information about nearby enhancers ( ., the activity of all other elements within 5 kb of the perturbed element) ( Table S3 [this file] ). In the ENCODE-rE2G model, we sought to evaluate the utility of additional assays available in Tier 1 ENCODE cell types, and expanded to include a total of 47 features derived from DNase-seq, histone ChIP-seq, cell-type specific ENCODE Hi-C, and ChIA-PET experiments, as well as features from additional predictive models such as EpiMap and GraphReg that jointly analyze many datasets ( Table S3 [this file] ).

caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Colon carcinomas showed substantial MLL1 expression at all tumor stages (T0–T4), scored from weak to moderate and strong (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). These analyses showed no significant changes in expression across tumor stages (Supplementary Fig. 1b [this file] ). Patients of stages I-III and stage IV were stratified in three groups based on the level of expression (MLL1 low, medium, and high, Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] ). High levels were associated with shorter survival and increased risk of disease relapse (Supplementary Fig. 1c, d [this file] ). Immuno-staining for β-catenin revealed high levels of nuclear β-catenin, indicative of high Wnt signaling, in a major portion of the analyzed tumors (Supplementary Fig. 1e [this file] ). Across all tumor stages, carcinomas with high levels of nuclear β-catenin showed strong expression of MLL1 (Fig. 1b [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1f, g [this file] ). 
Mll1 is gradually lost towards the differentiated compartment (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] and Supplementary Fig. 1h [this file] ). A crypt–villus gradient was also observed for H3K4 tri-methylation (H3K4me3) (Supplementary Fig. 1i [this file] ). We observed a similar distribution of Mll1, Ki67, and H3K4me3 in the mouse colon (Supplementary Fig. 1j–l [this file] ). 
The dysplastic tissue in the β-cat ; Mll1 intestines showed an expansion of Lgr5-GFP stem cells (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] , upper picture, Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ) and an increase in the stem cell genes , , and (Supplementary Fig. 2b [this file] ). The stem cell expansion in β-cat tumorous intestines was associated with an increase in Mll1 protein levels (Supplementary Fig. 2c [this file] , the mutant β-catenin allele is marked by an arrow, quantification is shown below). Specifically, tumor cells with high levels of β-catenin expressed high nuclear levels of Mll1 (Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] ; green arrows mark β-catenin cells, white arrowheads indicate β-catenin cells). Equal recombination was observed at day 5 in 25% of crypts (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] , upper row, quantification in f). Subsequently, the mutant cells in β-cat ; Mll1 mice expanded at day 10 and formed LacZ dysplasia at day 30 (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] , middle and lower left pictures, quantification in f). In contrast, β-cat ; Mll1 mice showed a gradual reduction of LacZ cells down to 10% over time (Supplementary Fig. 2e [this file] , lower right picture, quantification in f). At 30 days, the β-cat ; Mll1 mice exhibited crypts with LacZ long-lived Paneth cells interspersed with non-mutant (LacZ ) stem cells (Supplementary Fig. 2g [this file] , marked by an arrow). Furthermore, we observed crypts that were normally shaped and depleted of Mll1 but with nuclear β-catenin (β-cat ) and positive for Lgr5-GFP; they exhibited a slight reduction in proliferation, as seen by a decrease in the incorporation of BrdU (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] , lower picture, Supplementary Fig. 2h, i [this file] ). Apoptosis was not detected in β-cat ; Mll1 crypts (Supplementary Fig. 2j [this file] ). 
All β-cat organoids grew independently of R-spondin1 (Supplementary Fig. 2k [this file] ). β-cat induced a strong expansion of Lgr5-GFP stem cells (Fig. 2d, e [rid=Fig2] , second panel). Single β-cat ; Mll1 cells re-formed spheroid-shaped organoids over many passages with high efficiency (Supplementary Fig. 2l [this file] ), demonstrating the proliferative potential and self-renewal capacity of Mll1-deficient β-cat cells. From the seventh passage on, β-cat ; Mll1 cells formed less organoids, which were smaller and acquired a thick-walled shape (Supplementary Fig. 2m [this file] ), indicating differentiation and progressive exhaustion of stemness upon loss of Mll1. 
Under non-oncogenic conditions without genetic stabilization of β-catenin, mutant Mll1 stem cells produced progeny up to 20 days after the induction of mutagenesis, as seen by LacZ lineage tracing in Mll1 mice (Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] , quantification on the right). From 20 days onwards, Mll1 crypts were progressively lost, but a substantial number of Mll1 crypts persisted beyond 50 days after induction (Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] , quantification on the right). 
Genes specific for enteroendocrine and tuft cells did not undergo major changes (Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] ). β-cat ; Mll1 stem cells exhibited a strongly increased expression of , a transcription factor essential for secretory lineage determination , and its target gene , which instructs secretory cell differentiation in Paneth and goblet cells (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] ). 
To investigate the essential role of Mll1 in the stemness of human colon tumors, we established stable, doxycycline-inducible shMLL1 single-cell clones of the human colon adenocarcinoma cell lines Ls174T and DLD1, which exhibited a strong reduction of MLL1 (Supplementary Fig. 4a–d [this file] ). The ablation of MLL1 did not affect the expression of other MLL family members (Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ). A significant growth reduction was detected only after four passages and a total of 10–14 days of culture (Supplementary Fig. 4f, g [this file] ). We found that MLL1 protein was strongly increased in 3D (non-adherent, self-renewing) sphere cultures of human Ls174T cells compared to adherent cultures, while the expression of the family member SETD1A was not changed (Supplementary Fig. 4h [this file] , quantification on the right). In contrast to the 2D culture, the ablation of MLL1 in 3D sphere cultures had a rapid effect on the growth and self-renewal of the tumor cells: secondary sphere formation of shMLL1 cells was reduced by 80% in Ls174T and by 60% in DLD1 cells, compared to control cells (Fig. 4a [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 4i [this file] , quantifications on the right). Residual shMLL1 spheres exhibited minimal MLL1 expression and reduced proliferation, as shown by staining for Ki67 (Supplementary Fig. 4j [this file] ). shMLL1 spheres were negative for the apoptosis marker cleaved Caspase-3 (Supplementary Fig. 4k [this file] , western blot on the right). 
The residual xenografts showed a strong reduction of MLL1 (Supplementary Fig. 4l [this file] , quantification below) and H3K4me3 (Supplementary Fig. 4m [this file] , upper panel), and significantly fewer proliferating cells (Supplementary Fig. 4m [this file] , middle panel, quantifications on the right). The apoptosis marker cleaved Caspase-3 did not increase in shMLL1 Ls174T tumors (Supplementary Fig. 4m [this file] , lower panel, western blot on the right). The shMLL1 human Ls174T xenografts and sphere cells showed enhanced differentiation with an increase in the expression of the Paneth cell-specific genes and and the goblet cell markers and (Supplementary Fig. 4n [this file] ), as was also observed in the β-cat mouse tumor model. An increase in expression was also observed in DLD1 sphere cells (Supplementary Fig. 4o [this file] ). The expression of the differentiation-associated cell cycle inhibitor was upregulated in shMLL1 Ls174T xenografts and spheres (Supplementary Fig. 4p, q [this file] , quantifications on the right). 
Comparison of the differentially expressed genes with a signature of Mll1-ablated fibroblasts revealed deregulation of MLL1 target genes such as and (Supplementary Fig. 4r [this file] , Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ). A volcano plot of the deregulated genes overlaid with this signature showed a predominant downregulation of stem cell genes upon knockdown of MLL1; these included , , , and the Wnt-regulated gene (Supplementary Data 3 [rid=MOESM6] and Fig. 4d [this file] ). The selective regulation of Wnt-dependent stem cell genes was also observed in DLD1 human colon cancer cells (Supplementary Fig. 4s [this file] ). 
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) revealed high H3K4me3 and low H3K27me3 levels at the transcription start sites (TSS) of the MLL1-regulated stem cell genes , , and (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). Ablation of MLL1 shifted the epigenetic state of the stem cell genes from transcriptionally permissive (H3K4me3) to repressed (H3K27me3) (Fig. 5a [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). Global levels of H3K4 and H3K27 methylation were not changed (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). We identified MLL1 binding to the promoters of the intestinal stem cell genes , , and (Fig. 5b [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 5c, d [this file] ). Strongly reduced binding of MLL1 was observed in shMLL1 Ls174T and DLD1 cells (Fig. 5b [rid=Fig5] and Supplementary Fig. 5c–e [this file] ). 
Primer sequences used for ChIP-qPCR are given in Supplementary Information (Supplementary Table 1) [this file] . 
Primer sequences used for qRT-PCR are listed in Supplementary Information (Supplementary Table 2) [this file] . 
Transcriptome analyses in human CRC were carried out on 2207 samples that were available in two public repositories (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ): (i) RNA seq (version 2) data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) project ( http://cancergenome.nih.gov/ (http://cancergenome.nih.gov/) ) were downloaded from the legacy version of the NCI Genomic Data Commons (GDC) repository . 
The RNA sequencing data from FACS-isolated Lgr5-GFP intestinal stem cells (Fig. 3b, d [rid=Fig3] and Supplementary Fig. 3c [this file] , Supplementary Data 1 [rid=MOESM4] ) have been deposited in the Gene expression omnibus under accession number GSE148394 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE148394) . The RNA sequencing data from shMLL1 Ls174T colon cancer cells (Fig. 4c, d [rid=Fig4] and Supplementary Fig. 4r [this file] , Supplementary Data 2 [rid=MOESM5] ) are available in the ArrayExpress database under accession number E-MTAB-8152 (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/arrayexpress/experiments/E-MTAB-8152/) . The human colon cancer data referenced during the study (Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ) are available in public repositories from the TCGA website ( TCGA-COAD (https://www.cancer.gov/about-nci/organization/ccg/research/structural-genomics/tcga) , TCGA-READ (https://www.cancer.gov/about-nci/organization/ccg/research/structural-genomics/tcga) ) and in the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) at NCBI ( GSE14333 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse14333) , GSE33113 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse33113) , GSE39582 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse39582) , GSE38832 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse38832) , GSE44076 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse44076) , GSE13294 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse13294) , GSE18088 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse18088) and GSE2109 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gds/?term=gse2109) ).

caption: Click here for additional data file.
description: Click  here  for  additional  data  file.
context_description:
We constructed a linear regression model to investigate the correlation between CNVs and the age of death (AOD) of AD cases based on copy number profiles and meta-information of 1,127 North American white individuals from the ROSMAP AD cohort ( Chibnik et al., 2018 [rid=ref12] ; De Jager et al., 2018 [rid=ref15] ; Mostafavi et al., 2018 [rid=ref42] ; Lee et al., 2023 [rid=ref32] ) ( Supplementary Table S1 [this file] and Supplementary Figure S1 [rid=SM2] ), while sex and disease status were treated as covariates (Methods 4.5, Figure 2 [rid=fig2] ). 
We found all 10 AOD-correlated CNVs with low frequency in both AD and healthy control groups, and they showed no significant frequency difference in both groups ( Supplementary Table S2 [this file] ). They also showed rare frequency in human populations ( Supplementary Table S2 [this file] ). 
Based on the linear additive model with sex and disease status as covariates, there were 110 genes identified with their expression level significantly correlated with copy number dosage of the 10 AOD-correlated CNVs under the FDR threshold at 5%, forming 125 CNV-Gene pairs ( Supplementary Table S3 [this file] ). 
There were 2,056, 1,294, and 2,774 AOD-correlated genes identified based on cogdx, braaksc, and ceradsc respectively, under the genome-wide FDR threshold of 0.05 ( Supplementary Table S4 [this file] ). 
We further constructed correlation network for above CNV-gene-AOD pairs. ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] ; Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ; Methods 4.9). 
Differential expression analysis showed and had no difference between the AD and normal groups indicating that and ’s contribution to longevity was independent of AD status ( Supplementary Table S8 [this file] ). 
The original contributions presented in the study are included in the article/ Supplementary material [this file] , further inquiries can be directed to the corresponding author.
pub_title: Effects of copy number variations on longevity in late-onset Alzheimer’s disease patients: insights from a causality network analysis

context_description:
We constructed a linear regression model to investigate the correlation between CNVs and the age of death (AOD) of AD cases based on copy number profiles and meta-information of 1,127 North American white individuals from the ROSMAP AD cohort ( Chibnik et al., 2018 [rid=ref12] ; De Jager et al., 2018 [rid=ref15] ; Mostafavi et al., 2018 [rid=ref42] ; Lee et al., 2023 [rid=ref32] ) ( Supplementary Table S1 [rid=SM1] and Supplementary Figure S1 [this file] ), while sex and disease status were treated as covariates (Methods 4.5, Figure 2 [rid=fig2] ). These findings each maintained a false discovery rate (FDR) of less than 0.05 ( Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Copy number dosage had a significant influence on AOD and that was consistent with our correlation result between these 10 CNVs and AOD, except mCNV62126 ( Supplementary Figure S3 [this file] ). 
The transcriptomic profile was further adjusted for AD pathological traits using limma R package ( Ritchie et al., 2015 [rid=ref46] ) to exclude bias from disease status ( Supplementary Figure S4 [this file] , Methods 4.8).
