context_description:
We identified 13 distinct, robust co-expression modules, including 7 modules enriched for microglial genes, but varying in their relationship to disease, cell type, and temporal trajectories; we call these microglial neurodegeneration-associated modules, MNMs ( Figures 1 [rid=F1] , S1 [this file] , and S2 [this file] ; Table S1 [rid=SD2] ). We compared them with six independent microglia-specific gene expression datasets from transgenic mouse models and humans with AD pathology to identify overlapping patterns of gene expression ( Figures 1B [rid=F1] , S1C [this file] – S1E [this file] , and S2F [this file] ; Table S2 [rid=SD3] ), supporting their generalizability. 
We confirmed that the MNMs include expected traits indicative of neuroimmune activity, including: (1) known neuroregulatory pathways, such as complement activation ( Schafer et al., 2013 [rid=R74] ), Toll-like receptor (TLR), and interleukin-1β (IL-1β) ( Heneka et al., 2013 [rid=R32] ; Figure 1E [rid=F1] ); (2) strong association with tau pathology, a neuronal driver of neurodegeneration ( Figures 1F [rid=F1] and S2A [this file] ); and (3) high overlap with the conserved neuroinflammatory module we identified in our prior study (NAI; Swarup et al., 2019 [rid=R85] ; Figures S2B [this file] and S2C [this file] ). 
In addition, all MNMs are preserved in three different transgenic mouse models expressing human mutations ( Swarup et al., 2019 [rid=R85] ; Figure S2D [this file] ) and in microglial-specific datasets from mouse models expressing ( Srinivasan et al., 2016 [rid=R80] ) and ( Wang et al., 2015 [rid=R90] ) mutations, with the exception of M_UP3, which is only weakly preserved in one of the two datasets from mice expressing early AD mutations ( Figure S2E [this file] ). A few modules display variability in their differential expression in different transgenic models, suggesting that they may be conditional on mutational interactions with disease-stage and disease-specific pathology, or possibly by other technical factors distinguishing these mouse models ( Figure S2F [this file] ). 
Finally, we observed an increased expression of genes involved in viral response and type II IFN response represented by M_UP3 ( Figures 1E [rid=F1] , 2A [rid=F2] , 2B [rid=F2] , and S2G [this file] ). 
We identified the earliest interconnected MNM genes present in pre-symptomatic disease tissue and called them early MNM sub-modules, reasoning that casual disease pathways should enrich among the earliest MNM components in disease ( Figure S3 [this file] ; STAR Methods [rid=S10] ). We confirmed significant associations using exome array data ( Chen et al., 2015 [rid=R9] ), replicating significant associations between AD and M_UP3 (β= 0.19, p < 0.001), FTD and early_UP1 (β= 0.25, p < 0.001), and FTD and early_DOWN1 (β= 0.15 p < 0.001) ( Figure S3G [this file] ). 
Consistent with these causal relationships defined by genetic enrichment, we were able to demonstrate that the expression of genes involved with viral defense, including the type I IFN response and dsRNA binding, were highly associated with the level of pathological tau phosphorylation in the brains of TPR50 mice ( Figures S3H [this file] – S3J [this file] ). 
We found that gene overexpression has inverse effects on modules A and B ( Figure 4D [rid=F4] ; 2,161 genes; STAR Methods [rid=S10] ), which we also confirmed at the levels of gene connectivity ( Figure S4A [this file] ) and PPI ( Figure S4B [this file] ). These patterns were confirmed in 12 independent transcriptome datasets ( Figures S4D [this file] – S4I [this file] ), indicating that these two modules represent robust, early microglia responses mediating opposing signaling pathways. 
Module A includes protein complexes and pathways of microglial innate neuroimmune activation, including the NLRP3 inflammasome ( , , , , and ) ( Ahmed et al., 2017 [rid=R2] ; Ising et al., 2019 [rid=R38] ; Lučiūnaitė et al., 2019 [rid=R54] ), TLRs ( , , , and ), and nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) targets ( Figures 4E [rid=F4] , 4G [rid=F4] , and S4A [this file] ). Supporting this interpretation, we found that purified pathological Aβ, an extracellular inducer of pro-inflammatory microglial activity ( Lučiūnaitė et al., 2019 [rid=R54] ), stimulates NAct in microglia ( Figures 4F [rid=F4] and S4C [this file] ). In contrast, module B includes viral and stress response genes, drivers of immune suppression ( [PD-L1], , , , and ), and the senescence marker, ( Figures 4H [rid=F4] and S4A [this file] ). 
Several features of NSupp suggest that in the context of tauopathy it may also represent an immunosuppressive type of IFN-β signaling in disease-associated microglia that are expressing inhibitory immune checkpoint genes (e.g., [PDL-1], , and ) ( Snell et al., 2017 [rid=R78] ; Wykes and Lewin, 2018 [rid=R94] ) and inhibitors of immune hyperactivity (e.g., ; Basters et al., 2018 [rid=R4] ; Taylor et al., 2018 [rid=R87] ; Figures 4G [rid=F4] , 4H [rid=F4] , and S4A [this file] ). 
NAct is activated by extracellular stimuli working through TLR and related receptors ( Figures 4E [rid=F4] , 4F [rid=F4] , S4A [this file] , and S4C [this file] ). 
Then, as tau pathology leads to chromatin and nucleotide dysregulation before neuronal loss, nucleotide damage signals activate dsRNA receptors to trigger a microglial type I IFN response that drives the expression of NSupp pathways involved in stress response, exosome, and viral entry ( Figure 4H [rid=F4] ), while suppressing the specific microglial immune attack pathways represented by NAct, including the NLRP3 inflammasome and TLR1 and −2 signaling ( Figures 4E [rid=F4] and S4A [this file] ). As disease progresses to include frank neurodegeneration, microglia undergo additional dynamic states, including increased type II IFN signaling, exogenous antigen presentation, T cell regulation, and cell death ( Figures 1E [rid=F1] , 2A [rid=F2] , 2B [rid=F2] , and S2G [this file] ). 
We pre-treated human-induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived microglia ( Haenseler et al., 2017 [rid=R29] ; STAR Methods [rid=S10] ) with IFN-β and tested the ability of fibrillar Aβ, a NAct activator ( Figures 4F [rid=F4] and S4C [this file] ), to induce the secretion of IL-1β, a prominent member of the NAct pathway in these human cells ( Figures 4E [rid=F4] and 4G [rid=F4] ). 
Another prediction based on the mouse microglia module trajectory analysis ( Figure 2 [rid=F2] ) is a delayed, biphasic type II IFN response with early suppression and late increase (M_DOWN1, M_UP3; Figures 1C [rid=F1] , 1E [rid=F1] , 2A [rid=F2] , 2B [rid=F2] , and S2G [this file] ). Remarkably, we observed concordance between disease-associated signaling pathways represented in M_UP3 and microglia from patients with FTD-Pick’s; in particular in type II IFN, a specific activator of M_UP3 ( Figures 2A [rid=F2] , 2B [rid=F2] , 6C [rid=F6] , and S2G [this file] ). Significantly upregulated in bvFTD microglia are genes that can stimulate IFN-γ production ( , , , and ) ( Renkl et al., 2005 [rid=R66] ) and genes that mediate IFN-γ response ( , , , and ; Figures 6C [rid=F6] , 6D [rid=F6] , and S5E [this file] ). 
We find that both dsRNA detection and IFN pathways are highly correlated with pathological tau burden in brain ( Figures S3H [this file] – S3J [this file] ) and both the cytosolic dsRNA receptor (MDA5) and RIG1 pathway are hubs of the NSupp module ( Figure 4H [rid=F4] ). 
The significance of intramodular connectivity was assessed for each module using a permutation test (10,000 permutations), and all modules were confirmed to have permuted p value < 0.001. “Early submodules,” described in Figures 3 [rid=F3] and S3 [this file] , were derived by re-clustering M_UP1 and M_UP2 genes to generate “earlyUP” modules, or M_DOWN1, M_DOWN2 and M_DOWN3 genes to generate “earlyDOWN” modules, using the 3 month of age frontal cortex TPR50 gene expression data ( Swarup et al., 2019 [rid=R85] ). “NSupp and NAct,” described in Figures 4 [rid=F4] and 5 [rid=F5] , were derived from re-clustering the M_UP1 and M_UP2 genes, keeping only genes with annotated PPI in either Bio-grid ( Stark et al., 2006 [rid=R82] ) or Inweb databases ( Rossin et al., 2011 [rid=R69] ), using the same gene expression data used for the consensus WGCNA analysis (purified microglia from the Tg4510 model and frontal cortex TPR50 dataset (6 months of age)). 
Each cluster was then annotated as a major cell type using mean expression of groups of cell type marker genes, including the microglial markers CD74, CSF1R, C3 ( Mathys et al., 2019 [rid=R58] ), PTPRC, and DOCK8 ( Kelley et al., 2018 [rid=R42] ) ( Figure S5A [this file] ). 
In addition, to check that our findings were representative of group effects rather than driven by a few individuals, we compared all disease and control samples for average gene expression and total number of microglia contributed to the analysis ( Figure S5E [this file] ). 
For all boxplots, the center line is at the median and the upper and lower lines are at the 75 and 25 percentiles, respectively ( Figures 4I [rid=F4] , 5C [rid=F5] , 5F [rid=F5] , 5K [rid=F5] , S3B [this file] , S3C [this file] , S4G [this file] – S4I [this file] , and S5C [this file] ). Results of tissue culture experiments show each sample data point as a separate dot, the center line at the group mean, and error bars showing s.e.m. ( Figures 5D [rid=F5] , 5G [rid=F5] , and 5I [rid=F5] ) The barplot in Figure S2G [this file] has the center line at the group mean and error bars as s.e.m. In Figure S5D [this file] , the center line of the boxplot is the sample mean, the upper and lower lines are the 75 and 25 percentiles, respectively, and each dot is the average gene expression among the microglia from one subject, with the size of the dot proportional to the number of microglia contributing to the final analysis from that subject. 
See also Figure S1 [this file] .

context_description:
We identified 13 distinct, robust co-expression modules, including 7 modules enriched for microglial genes, but varying in their relationship to disease, cell type, and temporal trajectories; we call these microglial neurodegeneration-associated modules, MNMs ( Figures 1 [rid=F1] , S1 [rid=SD1] , and S2 [rid=SD1] ; Table S1 [this file] ). 
To further explore the early microglial response in disease, we re-clustered only the genes from M_UP1 and M_UP2 to identify additional co-expression relationships among them ( Figure 4A [rid=F4] , Module A and Module B; Table S1 [this file] ). 
We next used the CMAP database to find candidate drivers of NSupp and NAct ( STAR Methods [rid=S10] ), identifying genes that regulate the viral activation of type I IFN among the top drivers of NSupp and suppressors of NAct ( ; Marazzi et al., 2012 [rid=R56] ; Table S1 [this file] ). 
For our analysis, we used the mean “connectivity scores” which is calculated from the combining data generated independently in 9 cell lines (see Table S1 [this file] ).

context_description:
We compared them with six independent microglia-specific gene expression datasets from transgenic mouse models and humans with AD pathology to identify overlapping patterns of gene expression ( Figures 1B [rid=F1] , S1C [rid=SD1] – S1E [rid=SD1] , and S2F [rid=SD1] ; Table S2 [this file] ), supporting their generalizability. 
To explore their preservation across neurodegenerative dementias, we tested module preservation in multiple mouse and human disease datasets (total n = 525 samples from 17 datasets; STAR Methods [rid=S10] ; Table S2 [this file] ), finding significant preservation in transcriptome data from post-mortem human brain tissue from AD ( Allen et al., 2016 [rid=R3] ), FTD ( Chen-Plotkin et al., 2008 [rid=R10] ; Swarup et al., 2019 [rid=R85] ), and PSP ( Allen et al., 2016 [rid=R3] ) patients ( Figure 1G [rid=F1] ). 
Samples were balanced age (mean: 68 years old -Pick’s, 66 years old -control), PMI (mean: 15.98 hours – Pick’s, 12.78 hours - control) and tissue RNA integrity number (RIN; mean: 6.1 -Pick’s, 5.6 -controls) ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
Additional publicly available datasets were used throughout the study for validation or comparison ( Table S2 [this file] ; and Key Resources Table [rid=T1] ). 
One outlier sample was identified based on abnormal frequencies of major cell types and divergent gene expression patterns, and was removed from the analysis ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
While RIN, PMI and age were not significantly different between case and control subjects (Mann Whitney U test; Table S2 [this file] ); sex and brank bank were not evenly split across groups (UCSF brain bank –bvFTD = 70%, control = 12%; male sex –bvFTD = 62%, controls = 50% ( Table S2 [this file] ).

pub_title: Profiling allele specific gene expression in brains from individuals with autism spectrum disorder reveals preferential minor allele usage - PMC

title: NIHMS1534152-supplement-1.docx
context_description:
We compiled ~40 million possible variants based on the union of SNPs called from RNA-seq data ( Supplementary Fig. 1a [href=this file] ) and SNPs already identified from microarray probe sets and the 1000 Genomes (Methods). To collect transcriptome wide genotyping data from our brain samples, we performed imputation from genotyping array and RNA-seq based genotyping (Methods; Supplementary Fig. 1b [href=this file] and 1c [href=this file] ), and ancestry was identified for all samples (Methods; Supplementary Fig. 1d [href=this file] ).
The values of excluded covariates showed balanced distributions between control and ASD ( Supplementary Fig. 1e [href=this file] ; Methods).
As expected, SNPs within the same haplotype blocks show similar allelic expression patterns ( Supplementary Fig. 1f [href=this file] and 1g [href=this file] ).
Although this database contains data from mostly non-neural tissues, genes manifesting ASE in our study showed significant overlap with those in dbMAE ( Supplementary Fig. 2a [href=this file] ). For example, the overlap between genes showing ASE in the two cortical regions, BA9 and BA41 is extremely high (odds ratio (OR)=221.00 and p-value<2.2e-16; Supplementary Fig. 2b [href=this file] ), whereas the degree of overlap between two more developmentally and evolutionarily distinct brain regions, cortex and cerebellum, is substantial, but lower than in the two more similar cortical regions (between BA9 and vermis: OR=49.00 and p-value<2.2e-16; between BA41 and vermis: OR=72.54 and p-value<2.2e-16).
For further external validation, we applied the specific methods and pipeline used in the primary analysis of GTEx ( Supplementary Fig. 2c [href=this file] ).
The distribution of expression of imbalanced alleles was significantly shifted lower than balanced alleles (Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) test, p-value<2.0e-16, the means of log (RPSM): 0.37 vs 0.71; Supplementary Fig. 2d [href=this file] ). Genes showing evidence for ASE were also preferentially enriched for neuronal and astrocyte markers ( Fig. 2b [href=#F2] and Supplementary Fig. 2e [href=this file] ). Remarkably, across all three brain regions, ASE genes are enriched for genes previously shown to be down-regulated in postmortem brain from patients with ASD ( Supplementary Fig. 2f [href=this file] ).
Similar to controls, idiopathic ASD cases showed tissue specific ASE across the three brain regions ( Fig. 3a [href=#F3] , Supplementary Fig. 3a [href=this file] , and Supplementary Fig. 3b [href=this file] ).
Genes exhibiting control-specific ASE are significantly enriched for pathways related to growth cone and synapse ( Supplementary Fig. 3c [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 4 [href=#SD6] ). Though there are fewer idiopathic ASD-specific ASE genes than control-specific ASE genes, those showing idiopathic ASD-specific ASD are significantly enriched for pathways involved in transport ( Supplementary Fig. 3d [href=this file] and Supplementary Table 4 [href=#SD6] ). Genes exhibiting ASE in both idiopathic ASD and controls show significant enrichment in genes harboring ASD risk variants ( Supplementary Fig. 3e [href=this file] ; OR=1.68, p-value=5e-04 for ASD1; OR=3.83, p-value=0.001 for ASD2). However, control-specific and idiopathic ASD-specific ASE genes do not show any enrichment with either the rare ASD risk variants or common variants from GWAS data ( Supplementary Fig. 3e [href=this file] ).
Controls had a higher density of balanced alleles than ASD cases while idiopathic ASD cases showed more imbalanced alleles ( Supplementary Fig. 4a [href=this file] and Fig. 4a [href=#F4] ). However, controls showed significantly more major allele MAE for low frequency alleles (minor allele frequency (MAF)<0.05) compared to idiopathic ASD ( Supplementary Fig. 4b [href=this file] ). These patterns were recapitulated in the pseudoautosomal region (PAR) of the chromosome X ( Supplementary Fig. 4c [href=this file] ).
We next investigated whether the differential ASE pattern was related to the MAF genome-wide ( Fig. 4b [href=#F4] and Supplementary Fig. 4b [href=this file] ).
Although MAE SNPs were observed across the genome ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=this file] ), there was an approximately 2-fold enrichment on chromosome 15 harboring a number of known imprinted loci ( Supplementary Table 5 [href=#SD2] ). This genome-wide enrichment pattern persisted when SNPs were analyzed at individual genes ( Supplementary Fig. 6a [href=this file] and 6b [href=this file] ).
For example, genes showing minor allele MAE showed no overlap with astrocyte markers , PSD , or ASD-specific down-regulated genes ( Supplementary Fig. 6c [href=this file] ). Like genes that manifest ASE ( Fig. 2c [href=#F2] ), major allele MAE genes show significant enrichment with genes associated with the rare ASD risk variants ( Supplementary Fig. 6d [href=this file] ). However, MAE genes in control and ASD showed some enrichment with common variants from GWAS data of BPD and SCZ ( Supplementary Fig. 6d [href=this file] ).
This analysis identities only two genomic regions, 14q32 (chr14:101302,638–101,544,745) and 15q11 (chr15:25,223,730–25,582,395), which are known imprinted loci that have many small splice junctions ( Fig. 6 [href=#F6] ) and show continuous high expression ( Supplementary Fig. 7 [href=this file] ) as single transcript units .
The snoRNA targeting sites were located significantly proximal to alternatively spliced junctions of their target genes in ASD ( Supplementary Fig. 8a [href=this file] ), and their splicing changes show significant correlations with the expression changes of their specific snoRNAs ( Supplementary Fig. 8b [href=this file] and 8c [href=this file] ). When one snoRNA has two different targets, their splicing changes also show strong correlation ( Supplementary Fig. 8d [href=this file] ).
Compared with the previously published RNA-seq based genotyping methods by Quinn et al. , these genotyping parameters show much higher accuracy with sensitivity exceeding 95% ( Supplementary Fig. 1b [href=this file] ) and specificity in the range of 90–95% ( Supplementary Fig. 1c [href=this file] ; see Quinn at el. for accuracy tests).
We categorized our samples into European, Mexican, Asian, African, and ambiguous groups ( Supplementary Fig. 1d [href=this file] ).
In BA9 samples, the distributions of the covariate values were balanced between control and ASD ( Supplementary Fig. 1e [href=this file] ).
We calculated deviations of log (fold change) values (the beta values of allele covariate from the group based ASE identifications) per haplotype block in cortex and compared their distributions with normal distributions ( Supplementary Fig. 1f [href=this file] and 1g [href=this file] ). For further validation, we compared ASE genes identified in our study with those present in dbMAE ( https://mae.hms.harvard.edu/ [href=https://mae.hms.harvard.edu/] ) using Fisher’s exact test ( Supplementary Fig. 2a [href=this file] ). Like GTEx data, we calculated ASE rates per tissue ( Supplementary Fig. 2c [href=this file] ).
We compared their log (RPSM) values using KS tests ( Supplementary Fig. 2d [href=this file] ).
We visualized their distributions using ggplot2 R package ( http://ggplot2.org/ [href=http://ggplot2.org/] ) and compared them between control and idiopathic ASD at autosome ( Fig. 4a [href=#F4] and Supplementary Fig. 4b [href=this file] ) and chromosome X ( Supplementary Fig. 4c [href=#SD7] ).
For major and minor allele MAE SNPs, we visualized them on the different lines ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Profiling allele specific gene expression in brains from individuals with autism spectrum disorder reveals preferential minor allele usage - PMC

title: NIHMS1534152-supplement-2.pdf
context_description:
Although MAE SNPs were observed across the genome ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [href=#SD1] ), there was an approximately 2-fold enrichment on chromosome 15 harboring a number of known imprinted loci ( Supplementary Table 5 [href=this file] ).
Compared to chromosome 14, chromosome 15 exhibited a substantially higher minor allele MAE fraction in both ASD and dup15q than controls (3.9- and 1.6-fold, respectively; chi-square test p-values<2.2e-16 and 0.0184, respectively; Fig. 5c [href=#F5] and Supplementary Table 5 [href=this file] ).

title: NIHMS1534152-supplement-3.xlsx
context_description:
For investigation of group-level ASE patterns across cases and brain regions, 1,163,249 heterozygous SNPs in 21,929 genes were used following quality control (Methods), and their significance was quantified using a linear mixed model to account for sample variation and covariates ( Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ; Methods).
Though most sample information was already published , we provided it again including further information ( Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ).
To increase their SNP calling accuracy, we optimized bam files following the recommended GATK pipeline ( Supplementary Fig. 1a [href=this file] ).
To ensure if groups were balanced with respect to these covariates, we removed samples based on age (≦7), brain banks (The UK Brain Bank for Autism and Related Developmental Research and the MRC London Neurodegenerative Diseases Brain Banks), and SNP annotation (mysterious) ( Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ) . GC content was tested using AT and GC dropout values from Picard ( https://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/ [href=https://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/] ; Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] ).
The detailed description of brain samples is provided in Supplementary Table 1 [href=this file] .

Genes exhibiting ASE in both idiopathic ASD and control are enriched in phosphoprotein, RNA splicing, and neuron projection pathways ( Fig. 3e [href=#F3] and Supplementary Table 4 [href=this file] ). Genes exhibiting control-specific ASE are significantly enriched for pathways related to growth cone and synapse ( Supplementary Fig. 3c [href=#SD1] and Supplementary Table 4 [href=this file] ). title: NIHMS1534152-supplement-7.xlsx
context_description:
For known ASD risk gene list (SFARI gene), we selected genes from category 1, 2, and 3 corresponding to gene scoring criteria ( https://gene.sfari.org/autdb/GS_Home.do [href=https://gene.sfari.org/autdb/GS_Home.do] ); Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ) The gene list was previously used at the previous publication .
For this gene set enrichment studies, we also used known imprinted genes ( www.geneimprint.com [href=http://www.geneimprint.com/] ), PSD , FMRP target , HuR target , and RBFOX1 target genes , cell marker genes (neuron, astrocyte, oligodendrocyte, microglia, and endothelial), expression up- and down-regulated genes in ASD cortex ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ). HuR target gene list was collected from photoactivatable ribonucleoside crosslinking and immunoprecipitation (PAR-CLIP) data instead of RNA binding proteins immunoprecipitation complementary DNA array (RIP-chip) data since PAR-CLIP data identified RNA binding proteins binding sites more precisely than RIP-chip ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ).
For the variant data, we used the risk genes containing rare likely gene disrupting mutations in SCZ, ID, and ASD from the dataset of Iossifov et al. ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ). For the risk gene list, we analyzed gene set enrichment with different FDR cutoffs (FDR≦0.01, 0.01<FDR≦0.05, and 0.05<FDR≦0.1) and found the highest enrichments using the most stringent FDR cutoff. of FDR≦0.01, which we report in our study ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ).
For both studies, brain expressed genes were used as background genes that have more than 10 allele counts ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ).
We visualized their distributions using ggplot2 R package ( http://ggplot2.org/ [href=http://ggplot2.org/] ) and compared them between control and idiopathic ASD at autosome ( Fig. 4a [href=#F4] and Supplementary Fig. 4b [href=#SD1] ) and chromosome X ( Supplementary Fig. 4c [href=this file] ).
We also include gene lists that we used for gene set enrichment and GO analysis that includes brain expressed gene that we used for our study ( Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ).

context_description:
All 19 patients had cfDNA collected at or close to the time of first debulking surgery or laparoscopic biopsy (baseline), and a subset (n=10) had radiographically confirmed disease recurrence along with cfDNA collections post-recurrence and during therapy ( Supplementary Figure 1 [this file] ). See Supplementary Figure 1 [this file] for clinical details, treatment history and sample collections for all 19 patients. 
From the 19 patients included in this study we generated scWGS data from 19,454 cells (range 200-2015 cells per patient, Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ) with mean coverage of 0.089X (range 0.002-0.392X per cell, Supplementary Figure 2). We inferred the clonal composition at the time of diagnosis based on copy number data ( Methods [rid=S11] ), with the aim of following these clones over time as patients received chemotherapy, maintenance therapies and experienced disease recurrences using cfDNA ( Supplementary Figure 3 [this file] ). 
We then merged cells from each clone and re-computed copy number at 10kb resolution using a new Hidden Markov Model (HMM) based copy number caller, ( Methods [rid=S11] ). improves the resolution of pseudobulk clone copy number profiles and enables more precise matching between copy number and SVs ( Supplementary Figure 4 [this file] ). 
For each patient, we constructed a panel of mutations comprising a mix of clonal and subclonal somatic SNVs/SVs (≥100 SVs per patient, Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ) and a small number of germline single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) for QC purposes. 
Clone-specific SVs inferred by scWGS analysis were present in all patients with at least 200 cells (18 patients, average n=144, range 29-361 Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ). 
See Supplementary Figure 5 [this file] for the scWGS data for these 10 patients. For all patients, ctDNA VAF of truncal SVs decreased during initial chemotherapy, as patients responded to therapy with decreased burden and decreased serum CA-125 levels ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] & Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] ). All patients were positive for ctDNA at the time point closest to first recurrence (defined as average VAF across the panel exceeding LOD ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] & Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] )). In 6 patients with sufficient plasma samples, ctDNA was detected prior to clinically confirmed disease recurrence but subsequent to completion of initial chemotherapy: 002 (76 days), 004 (26 days), 009 (184 days), 045 (109 days), 075 (233 days), 081 (314 days) ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] & Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] ). 
Copy number profiles from these data were consistent with predictions derived from scWGS derived copy number profiles and ctDNA clone frequencies ( Supplementary Figure 7a [this file] – c [this file] ). In patient 045, the locus (chr19q) was enriched at baseline, and (chr1q) at recurrence ( Supplementary Figure 7d [this file] ), while in patient 107, and a region on chr20q were enriched at recurrence as expected ( Supplementary Figure 7e [this file] ). Clone frequencies across time for patient 045 showed highly similar patterns for SVs ( Supplementary Figure 7f [this file] ) and SNVs ( Supplementary Figure 7g [this file] ) and were consistent using these two distinct sets of genomic features for all patients ( Supplementary Figure 7h [this file] , R=0.93, p<10 , Pearson correlation). 
In 6/10 patients (002, 006, 014, 045, 081, 107; see Fig. 4 [rid=F4] & Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] ), multiple clones were detected in post-recurrence plasma samples, highlighting that chemo-resistance may be polyclonal in many patients. In 4 of these cases (009, 045, 081 and 107), clones that were not detected in cfDNA or were detected at minor frequencies at baseline became dominant at first recurrence, suggesting that although multiple clones may become chemo-resistant, some have relative fitness advantages in the context of treatment ( Fig. 4 [rid=F4] & Supplementary Figure 6 [this file] ). Notably, while the presence of multiple resistant clones was a common observation, the overall diversity, as quantified by Shannon entropy, decreased in the final timepoint relative to baseline in 8/9 cases (p=0.027, t-test, Supplementary Figure 6h [this file] ). The number of clones detected also decreased at the final time point relative to baseline (p=0.086, t-test, Supplementary Figure 6i [this file] ).
pub_title: Tracking clonal evolution of drug resistance in ovarian cancer patients by exploiting structural variants in cfDNA

title: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Analysis of residuals (method estimate—ABSOLUTE estimate) suggested close concordance with ABSOLUTE estimates for MethylCIBERSORT, with larger deviations only seen when samples were of very high purity (>80%), while other methods tended to overestimate tumour cell content in samples of low purity (Supplementary Figure 1a [href=this file] ), resulting in statistically significant differences in distributions (FDR < 2.2e−16).
We also compared the mRNA expression of a panel of cellular lineage markers with MethylCIBERSORT estimates and found significant associations for multiple cell types (Supplementary Figure 1b [href=this file] ) even though they are derived from different samplings of the same tumour.
For nine of these we were able to compare our predictions of tumour purity with ABSOLUTE estimates and observed strong correlations and significantly lower error margins compared to LUMP and ESTIMATE (Supplementary Figure 2a, b [href=this file] ). Further, we observed a robust preservation of positive correlations between MethylCIBERSORT and marker expression pan-cancer (Supplementary Figure 2c [href=this file] ), again with the caveat that the samples were taken from different aliquots of the tumour. We therefore compared estimates pertaining to fresh frozen and matched FFPE samples ( = 21 from three tumours) and recorded very high correlations, indicating our method is applicable also to the archival material (Supplementary Figure 2d [href=this file] ).
Among the genomic alterations we identify (for a full list of predicted driver events see Supplementary Data 8 [href=this file0] ), it is likely that some establish, while others are selected for, in different immune microenvironments. The positive correlation between EGFR levels (which are themselves correlated with EGFR phosphorylation (activation), Supplementary Figure 3 [href=this file] ) and the glycolytic signature is maintained across TCGA when matched RPPA profiles and RNA-seq data are compared (Fig. 5f [href=#Fig5] ).
Signature features were derived from 450k profiles using the aforementioned heuristic (delta-Beta and FDR cutoffs) with a maximum of 100 features per cell type for a wide range of tumour types, using cell lines allocated to the corresponding tissue in GSE68379 [href=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE68379] (Table S10 [href=this file] ) and the aforementioned infiltrating cell types.
pub_title: Pan-cancer deconvolution of tumour composition using DNA methylation - PMC

context_description:
Using limma-trend analysis, we identified 458 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between the hot and cold clusters at a fold-change of greater than 2 (FDR < 0.01, Supplementary Data 1 [href=this file] , genes highlighted in bold). In extended analyses of all genes at FDR < 0.01 (Supplementary Data 1 [href=this file] ), multiple other genes, including the Class 1 MHC gene (FC = 1.39), PD-1 ligand (FC = 1.62) and , which encodes SMA (FC = 0.68), are also differentially expressed between the two clusters, the latter validating fibroblast estimates from MethylCIBERSORT (Fig. 2a [href=#Fig2] ).
Fas-ligand ( ), an upstream activator of pro-apoptotic signalling through Caspase 8 is also upregulated in the immune hot tumours, further highlighting the importance of this pathway (Supplementary Data 1 [href=this file] ).

title: NIHMS1656683-supplement-2.xlsx
context_description:
In the discovery phase, we performed a PWAS by integrating AD GWAS results (N=455,258) with 376 human brain proteomes profiled from the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dPFC; Supplementary Table 1a [href=this file] ) using the FUSION pipeline . The PWAS identified 13 genes whose -regulated brain protein levels were associated with AD at false discovery rate (FDR) p<0.05 ( Figure 1 [href=#F1] , Table 1 [href=#T1] , Extended Data Figure 1a [href=#F2] , Supplementary Table 2 [href=this file] ).
A confirmatory PWAS was performed using the same AD GWAS and an independent set of 152 human brain proteomes profiled from the dPFC ( Supplementary Table 1b [href=this file] ) . Correlation between the protein weights in the discovery and confirmatory datasets was high (median 0.85, interquartile range 0.21; Supplementary table 3 [href=this file] ). Ten of these 13 proteins could be tested and all 10 proteins replicated in the confirmatory PWAS ( Table 1 [href=#T1] ; Extended Data Figure 1b [href=#F2] ; Supplementary table 4 [href=this file] ).
We found 9 of 13 genes consistent with being causal ( Table 2 [href=#T2] ; Supplementary Table 5 [href=this file] ). SMR results suggest that the -regulated protein abundance mediates the association between genetic variants and AD for all these 13 genes, but HEIDI results argue against a causal role for 4 genes due to linkage disequilibrium ( Table 2 [href=#T2] ; Supplementary Table 6 [href=this file] ).
Full results for TWAS is in Supplementary tables 17 [href=this file] - 18 [href=this file] . “ ” in “TWAS significant” column refers to genes with 0.05 <TWAS nominal p <0.1. refers to genes not within 1Mb window of SNPs with p < 5E-08 identified in Jansen et. al.
That analysis found the 13 original PWAS-significant genes and 6 additional significant genes at FDR p<0.05 ( , , ; Supplementary table 7 [href=this file] ). Moreover, results from COLOC and SMR/HEIDI tests found the same evidence of causality as the original findings except that was now consistent with causality by both COLOC and SMR/HEIDI compared to mixed findings before ( Supplementary tables 8 [href=this file] - 9 [href=this file] ). The 6 additional genes were not consistent with being causal by COLOC ( Supplementary Table 8 [href=this file] ).
The PWAS of clinical AD identified 4 genes, ALS 7 genes, PD 17 genes, neuroticism 72 genes, height 662 genes, BMI 395 genes, and WHRadjBMI 244 genes ( Supplementary Tables 10 [href=this file] - 16 [href=this file] ).
The 888 transcriptomes were mainly from the frontal cortex donated by participants of European descent ( Supplementary table 1c [href=this file] ), and quality control was analogous to that of the proteomes to remove technical and clinical characteristics before estimating the effect of genetic variants on mRNA expression. The AD TWAS identified 40 genes whose genetically regulated mRNA expression levels were associated with AD at FDR p<0.05 ( Extended Data Figure 3 [href=#F4] ; Supplementary table 17 [href=this file] ). Among the 11 potentially causal genes identified at the protein-level, five genes, , , , , and showed at least nominal significance with similar directions of association with AD as seen at the protein-level ( Table 3 [href=#T3] ; Supplementary table 18a [href=this file] ).
For the 5 genes with evidence at both the transcript and protein levels, results from SMR test for two molecular traits suggested their protein abundance is mediated by mRNA expression ( Supplementary table 18a [href=this file] , b [href=this file] ). For the three genes with suggestive evidence for -regulated mRNA’s association with AD ( , , and ), only had evidence to suggest protein expression is mediated by mRNA expression level ( Supplementary table 18a [href=this file] , b [href=this file] ).
Using human single-cell RNA-sequencing data profiled from the dPFC we found cell-type specific enrichment for expression of 6 of the 11 causal genes at FDR p-value < 0.05 (adjusted for 17,775 genes). , , , and were enriched in excitatory neurons, whereas showed enrichment in oligodendrocytes and in astrocytes and microglia ( Extended Data Figure 4 [href=#F5] ; Supplementary table 19 [href=this file] ).
Principal component analysis was performed to compare genetic ancestry of these individuals to CEU from 1000 Genomes Project ( Extended Data Figure 5 [href=#F6] ; Supplementary Table 20 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Integrating human brain proteomes with genome-wide association data implicates new proteins in Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis - PMC

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
To illustrate the overall workflow, we present a toy example showing a simple schematic view and the order of major computation steps in CWAS-Plus ( Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] ). 
Additionally, we examined the memory usage of CWAS-Plus with an increasing number of samples and found an approximately linear increase ( Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ). 
Our observations revealed that variants from most clusters exhibited a higher percentage of variants in higher score bins than non-RNVs ( Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ), indicating that CWAS-Plus prioritized more pathogenic variants within the broader pool of noncoding variants. 
CWAS-Plus demonstrated significant case enrichment (OR = 1.3; = 5.7 10 , 95% CI: 1.1–1.6), while Sei, Enformer, and STAARpipeline showed no significant case enrichment ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] , Supplementary Table 6 [rid=sup2] ). 
CWAS analyses for variants showed highly consistent estimates between the variant-level and sample-level tests ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] , Supplementary Table 7 [rid=sup2] ). 
Our extended analysis comparing the ability to identify risk variants revealed that only CWAS-Plus demonstrated significant case enrichment in risk variant carriers, whereas Sei, Enformer, and STAARpipeline did not ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ).
pub_title: CWAS-Plus: estimating category-wide association of rare noncoding variation from whole-genome sequencing data with cell-type-specific functional data

title: No Title
caption: No description
context_description:
CWAS-Plus was 50 times faster than CWAS, highlighting its superior computational speed ( Fig. 2A [rid=f2] , Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ). 
The scalability of the CWAS-Plus package was tested for run with an increasing number of samples ( Fig. 2B [rid=f2] , Supplementary Table 2 [this file] ) and datasets ( Fig. 2C [rid=f2] , Supplementary Table 3 [this file] ). 
The results showed that noncoding, including intergenic ( = 0.20%, = 1.3 10 ; Supplementary Tables 4 [this file] and 5 [this file] ) and 5’ UTR ( = 0.15%, = 1.1 10 ), categories were significantly enriched ( Fig. 3B [rid=f3] ). 
CWAS-Plus demonstrated significant case enrichment (OR = 1.3; = 5.7 10 , 95% CI: 1.1–1.6), while Sei, Enformer, and STAARpipeline showed no significant case enrichment ( Supplementary Fig. 4 [rid=sup1] , Supplementary Table 6 [this file] ). 
CWAS analyses for variants showed highly consistent estimates between the variant-level and sample-level tests ( Supplementary Fig. 5 [rid=sup1] , Supplementary Table 7 [this file] ). 
Since no single category fully explained AD risk associated with rare noncoding variants, we conducted a risk score analysis to identify predictors among diverse categories ( Fig. 4A [rid=f4] , Supplementary Tables 8 [this file] and 9 [this file] ). 
Set 3 showed the highest performance, outperforming set 1, followed by set 2 ( = 0.08%, = 5.5 10 for set 1; = 0.17%, = 4.3 10 for set 2; = 0.33%, = 3.7 10 for set 3; Fig. 5B [rid=f5] , Supplementary Table 10 [this file] ).
pub_title: CWAS-Plus: estimating category-wide association of rare noncoding variation from whole-genome sequencing data with cell-type-specific functional data

context_description:
CSF samples from 88 individuals in the replication cohort included 20 healthy controls, 37 patients with mild, symptomatic AD (either prodromal AD with mild cognitive impairment or early stage AD dementia with positive AD biomarkers), and 31 with other (non-AD) neurological disease (Additional file 1 [this file] : Tables S1 and S2). 
Samples were thawed at room temperature and protein concentrations measured by the bicinchoninic acid assay (BCA) method (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S2). 
The mass spectrometer was set to collect in PRM mode with an inclusion list consisting of each peptide (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3). 
The summed product ions peak areas were considered as raw peptide peak area (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3), which was normalized by external reference heavy peptide standards to correct for MS signal and sample loading variance (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4). The sum of all peptides belonging to the same protein was calculated and normalized by the average of global pooled (GIS) samples (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S5). Protein normalized ratios were then regressed by age and gender, and centered to mean zero (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S6) prior to statistical analyses. 
For proteins, standard Student’s t-test, or one-way ANOVA test were used to calculate significance (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S7). 
In the discovery TMT dataset, the Bicor rho correlation, and Student’s significance p values, were calculated using the WGCNA R package using the bicor And P value function, comparing normalized protein sum of peptide measurements by MS to selected traits obtained on paired cases by ELISA measurements of total Tau, phospho-Tau (pT181), β-amyloid, and ratio of Tau/Aβ (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S8). 
These three logistic regression classifiers for each protein were trained using a five-fold cross validation procedure and the performance of these classifiers was assessed on the testing set using the AUC of the ROC curve (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S9). 
The latter group were cognitively impaired, but negative for Aβ and Tau biomarker status (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1 and S2). Nearly all of the 41 proteins were significantly correlated with Aβ, Tau or phosphorylated Tau (pTau) ELISA levels in the discovery cohort (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] b and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S8). 
All protein correlations and p-values are provided in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S8 
All targeted peptides and CVs following batch normalization are provided in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S4. Peptide measurements were summed for proteins with more than one peptide quantified to generate a single protein measurement (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S5). 
S3 and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S7). 
To assess the degree to which any of these CSF proteins could predict clinical diagnosis, a logistic regression classifier was employed (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S9). 
All protein AUCs are provided in Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S9.
pub_title: Targeted mass spectrometry to quantify brain-derived cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease

caption: Additional file 2: Figure S1.  Overview of PRM targeted experiment.  (A)  Schematic of the workflow of the targeted PRM analyses of the replication cohort. Samples (n = 98 total) including 37 AD, 20 Controls, 31 non-AD dementia cases, and 10 pooled global internal standards (GIS) were randomized (e.g. diagnosis, age and sex) into four batches.  (B)  The raw and normalized peak areas (based on intensities) of reference peptides  L AS V S V S R ,  LA S V S VSR , Y V Y V AD V AA K , Y V Y V AD VAAK ,  VV GGL V A LR ,  VV GG LV A LR ,  LL S L GAGEF K , and  LL S L GAGE FK  (heavy amino acids were labeled with underline) across the first and second injection of 98 samples (including 10 GIS samples). Prior to mass spectrometry analyses, the 88 CSF sample digests were randomized and divided into 4 batches (Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig. We selected 94 peptides across each of the 41 targets proteins based on empirically generated proteomics data from control and AD CSF patients [ 6 [rid=CR6] ] (Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig. Finally, to assess the accuracy of the label-free PRM measurements heavy labeled isotopic standards (AQUA™ Pro, ThermoFisher) were included for a subset of peptides and the light/heavy ratios compared to the normalized peak area (Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig. 
The technical coefficient of variation (CV) of each peptide was calculated based on a pooled standard of all samples ( = 10 replicate injections) following batch normalization (Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig. After summing the values for a protein measurement, the average CV for each protein was ~ 25% (Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig. 
This included Tau (MAPT) and neurofilament light and medium chain proteins (NEFL and NEFM) (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] b and Additional file 2 [this file] : Figure S3). 
Notably, 26 of the 41 CSF markers quantified in this study, mapped to one of these five biomarker panels [ 6 [rid=CR6] ] (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] b, Additional file 2 [this file] : Fig.

title: mmc1.pdf
context_description:
To test whether a similar approach could be applied to hematopoietic stem cells, we used multiparameter flow cytometry to sort phenotypically defined long-term HSCs and MPPs obtained from human bone marrow biopsies ( Notta et al., 2016 [href=#bib28] ) and then clonally expanded them to obtain sufficient DNA for WGS analysis ( Figures 1 [href=#fig1] A and S1 [href=this file] ). The majority of the somatic mutations in these cultures displayed a variant allele frequency (VAF) clustered around 0.5, which indicates that these mutations were shared by all cells in the culture and therefore present in the originally expanded stem cell ( Figure S2 [href=this file] ). These accumulated mutations are discarded based on the low VAF ( Figure S2 [href=this file] ). We performed WGS on DNA from 18 HSCs/MPPs derived from adult marrow biopsies of 5 healthy donors, ranging from 26 to 63 years of age ( Table S1 [href=this file] ). Independent validations using single-molecule molecular inversion probes (smMIPs) of a subset of the identified somatic mutations revealed an overall confirmation rate of approximately 91% ( Tables S2 [href=this file] and S4 [href=#mmc3] B).
Nonetheless, cells of the same donor shared only a limited number of mutations (60 out of 11,082 base substitutions; Table S1 [href=this file] ), indicating that mutagenesis did occur independently during the lifetime of each assessed cell.
The strongest factor in our PCA (PC1) separates cells with either high or low contribution of signatures 1 or 5 ( Figure S3 [href=this file] ), which are signatures that were previously defined in a pan-cancer analysis ( Alexandrov et al., 2013b [href=#bib3] ) and reported to act in a “clock-like” manner.
Directions of signature contributions between samples are indicated on the x and y axis; see Figure S3 [href=this file] .
The presence of a third pattern, reflecting a recently defined signature 32 ( Inman et al., 2018 [href=#bib16] ), separates the mutation spectra in HSPCs from stem cells of the other human tissues (PC2; Figures 3 [href=#fig3] A and S3 [href=this file] ). Although the etiology of signature 32 is unknown, base substitutions specific for this signature were associated with a transcriptional strand bias in the HSPCs ( Figures 3 [href=#fig3] D and S4 [href=this file] ), consistent with activity of transcription-coupled repair ( Pleasance et al., 2010 [href=#bib32] ).
Remarkably, the absolute contribution of all three signatures to the base substitution load in normal HSPCs was similar as those in a previously reported acute myeloid leukemia (AML) dataset ( Welch et al., 2012 [href=#bib36] ; Figure 3 [href=#fig3] E; p = 0.97; chi-square test; Figure S4 [href=this file] B and S4C), indicating that the genesis of this malignancy does not necessarily require enhanced mutagenesis.
Sample B (26-year-old donor, male, white) was extracted at Boston Children’s Hospital, whereas samples A (33-year-old, male, white), C (55-year-old, female, hispanic), D (63-year-old, male, white), and E (41-year old, female, African American) were obtained from AllCells ( Table S1 [href=this file] ). 10-20 mL of whole bone marrow aspirate were drawn into a 60cc syringe containing heparin (80 U/mL of BM) from a unique puncture in the posterior iliac crest.
Representative examples of sorted populations are shown in the Figure S1 [href=this file] B.
When 70% or more of the reads with the same UMI had the same nucleotide, then the UMI was counted as valid as described( Yu et al., 2018 [href=#bib40] ) Mutation positions with less than 20 valid UMI’s were filtered out, and the rest mutations with higher than 0 VAF were counted as validated ( Table S2 [href=this file] ).
pub_title: Somatic Mutations Reveal Lineage Relationships and Age-Related Mutagenesis in Human Hematopoiesis - PMC

context_description:
We did not observe non-synonymous or truncating mutations in cancer driver genes for hematological neoplasms ( Ju et al., 2017 [href=#bib19] ), excluding selective clonal outgrowth of cells in culture ( Table S3 [href=this file] ).
Nevertheless, comparing somatic mutation load in 72 known driver genes for hematological neoplasms ( Ju et al., 2017 [href=#bib19] ) revealed that the normal blood progenitors are depleted for potential cancer driver mutations (0 mutations in 72 genes out of 22 genomes; Table S3 [href=this file] ) compared to the AML samples (28 mutations in 72 genes out of 24 genomes; p < 0.05; one-sided binomial test; Welch et al., 2012 [href=#bib36] ).

context_description:
Independent validations using single-molecule molecular inversion probes (smMIPs) of a subset of the identified somatic mutations revealed an overall confirmation rate of approximately 91% ( Tables S2 [href=#mmc1] and S4 [href=this file] B).
To evaluate the ability of our reconstructed map to explain lineage relationships in the bone marrow, we genotyped each base substitution defining a branch in 125 additional HSCs and MPP clones from the same donor ( Table S4 [href=this file] A).
Clone-specific smMIPs were designed as described( Hiatt et al., 2013 [href=#bib15] , Yu et al., 2018 [href=#bib40] ), ( Table S4 [href=this file] B).
For all of these early embryonic base substitutions primers were designed for amplicon-base re-sequencing in the mature populations and HSC and MPP clones as described above ( Table S4 [href=this file] A).

See also Figure S2 [rid=figs2] and Table S1 [this file] . 
The vast majority (> 95%) of European ancestry HD chrs carry a canonical CAG repeat region with an uninterrupted CAG repeat followed by CAACAG ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] B; Table S1 [this file] ). 
On CAA-loss chrs, the CAG repeat is followed by CCG CCT CAGCTTCCT and on CAACAG-duplication chrs, it is followed by CAA CAG CAA CAG CCG CCA CCG CCT CAGCTTCCT Sequencing of samples not tagged by rs764154313 or rs183415333 confirmed correct PCR-assay genotyping of the uninterrupted CAG sequence on canonical chrs and showed that the vast majority carry CAA CAG CCG CCA CCG CCT CAGCTTCCT after the CAG repeat ( Table S1 [this file] ). Indeed, the sequences of a selection of other HD and normal chrs revealed a wide variety of rarer non-canonical sequence variations ( Table S1 [this file] ). 
See also Figure S3 [rid=figs3] and Tables S2 [rid=mmc2] and S3–S5 [this file] . 
Pathway enrichment compared to GWA123 again pointed in GWA12345 (and GWA45) to mismatch repair but did not support mitochondrial regulation ( Table S3 [this file] ). In 77 DNA repair gene sets ( Pearl et al., 2015 [rid=bib59] ), the strongest enrichments were related to mismatch repair ( Tables S4 [this file] and S5 [this file] ). In a broader test of 14,210 pathways with 10 or more gene members, 77 pathways were significant after Bonferroni correction in GWA12345 ( Table S6 [this file] ).

title: media-1.pdf
context_description:
Briefly, samples from the full cohort were genotyped across multiple Illumina microarray platforms (see Supplemental Methods [href=this file] ) and underwent a standard quality control (QC) protocol to remove low-quality and low-frequency variants.
Samples were further excluded based on RNA-seq quality metrics (see Supplemental Methods [href=this file] ), low RIN score, discrepancies between self-reported sex and chromosome Y gene expression, and missing genotype data.
Four different meQTL mapping regression models were fit: (1) a “baseline” model to test for association between genetic variants and DNAm β-values across both smoking cases and controls; this model included age at death, sex, estimated non-neuronal cell-type proportion, PC1 for DNAm array negative control probes, PC1 for imputed genotypes, and PC2 for imputed genotypes as covariates (see Supplemental Methods [href=this file] for model selection details); (2) a smoking cases–only model similar to the baseline model; (3) a smoking controls–only model similar to the baseline model; and (4) an interaction model to test for associations of a genetic variant-by-smoking status interaction with DNAm β-values. Additional details of each model are provided in the Supplemental Methods [href=this file] .
The covariates included in each model were age at death, sex, exon mapping rate, ribosomal RNA mapping rate, PC1 for imputed genotypes, PC2 for imputed genotypes, and four latent variables estimated by PEER v1.3 to account for additional unmeasured sources of confounding (see Supplemental Methods [href=this file] for model selection details).
For a given probe, the colocalization test region spanned all genetic variants that were 1) included in the meQTL mapping for the probe and 2) tested in the GSCAN GWAS ( Figure S1 [href=this file] ).
Of the significant 41,695 unique CpGs, only five demonstrated strong evidence of an interaction with smoking ( Table 2 [href=#T2] , Figure S2 [href=this file] ) based on Bonferroni correction (significance threshold of 0.05/41,695=1.2e-6).
pub_title: Smoking-informed methylation and expression QTLs in human brain and colocalization with smoking-associated genetic loci - PMC

title: No Title
caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
Consistent with previous results, HARs were significantly enriched in putative regulatory elements active prenatally (fetal adrenal gland, brain, kidney, lung, and muscle) , the strongest enrichment being observed in fetal brain (Fig. 1a [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] ). We observed strong enrichment in predicted enhancer states, as well as H3K27ac, H3K4me1, and H3K4me2 marks, indicating that HARs are enriched in developing brain enhancers, more so than in adult brain (Supplementary Fig. 1b, c [this file] ). Further, HARs were enriched in regulatory elements that were significantly more likely to be accessible in the germinal (neurogenic) zones of the developing cortex , highlighting their potential role in cortical neurogenesis (Supplementary Fig. 1d [this file] ). 
We were able to assign 638 and 717 HARs to 972 and 1021 genes using contacts defined by three-dimensional chromatin conformation in cortical plate (CP, neocortical laminae containing post-mitotic neurons) and germinal zone (GZ, neocortical laminae consisting primarily of neural progenitors) in the fetal brain, respectively (Methods; Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] ) . When combined with intragenic HARs, we were able to assign 1028 HARs to 1648 putative target genes (Supplementary Tables 1 [this file] – 2 [this file] , Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] , subsequently referred to as putative target genes for HARs). 
The putative target genes of HARs are enriched for genes that regulate pathways involved in human brain development, regionalization, dorsal-ventral patterning, cortical lamination, and proliferation of neuronal progenitors (Fig. 1d [rid=Fig1] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ), suggesting that multiple aspects of human brain development are subject to human-specific regulation. 
Although this overlap is significant ( = 2.09 × 10 , OR = 2.5, Fisher’s exact test) and implicates a high confidence core set of target genes (Supplementary Table 1 [this file] ), most target genes are discordant (Fig. 1c [rid=Fig1] ), which may be due to differences between tissue specific gene regulation, or methodologic factors. 
We found that HARs interacted with 823 and 467 protein-coding genes in ES cells and IMR90 cells, respectively (Supplementary Fig. 4a, b [this file] ). The majority of genes (~60%) interacted with HARs in a cell type-specific manner, again highlighting the cell type specific nature of chromatin interactions, consistent with the notion of tissue specific gene regulation (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] ). Notably, many genes known to play major roles in cerebral cortex development and dorsal–ventral/anterior–posterior pattern specification, including , , , , , and , interacted with HARs in the developing cortex (Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ), consistent with the model that chromatin contact maps in developing brain will likely provide more biologically relevant targets for human brain evolution than other tissues. 
Also check Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] . 
In contrast, HGEs interact with genes involved in collagen metabolism, TOR signaling, immune function, and lipid storage, and HLEs interact with genes involved in oxygen transport, autophagy, and thymus development (Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] ). 
HGE- and HLE-associated genes show a pattern of more gradual upregulation throughout prenatal development, manifesting their highest expression after the peak of neuronal migration, during the period of synaptic formation and gliogenesis (Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] ). 
Indeed, HAR-, HGE -, and HLE-associated genes are also under purifying selection when compared with the genome background (Methods; Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). 
Genes associated with other human evolved elements do not show any deviation of expression -scores, indicating that they do not show stage-specific enrichment in human compared with rhesus macaque (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
HAR - and HLE-associated genes do not exhibit significant changes in breakpoints in the genes they regulate (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ), indicating that the activity of different classes of human evolved regulatory elements manifest distinct developmental trajectories. 
Indeed, we observed that HAR- and HGE -associated genes are enriched with LoF-intolerant genes that harbor de novo mutations in ASD (ASD constrained genes) and DD risk genes (Fig. 2f [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). Relative to HGE , genes putatively regulated by HARs show more enrichment in ASD constrained genes and de novo LOF variation, whereas HGE appear more enriched for constrained DD genes, or genes harboring LOF mutations in DD (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] . 
However, HAR genes appear more likely to be disrupted in ASD, while HGE genes are more substantially enriched in constrained or LOF DD genes although enriched in constrained ASD genes (Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
This leads to a set of 10,000 ORs for each tissue type, which was plotted in Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] . 
As some of these regions were overlapping, we ended up having 109,408 randomly selected genomic regions with matched GC content and length as HARs (Supplementary Table 4 [this file] ), which we used to construct a null distribution. 
Human-specific genes were obtained from Bakken et al. (Table S10 [this file] ), Sousa et al. (Table S5 [this file] ), and Brawand et al. (Table S1 [this file] ). 
To further confirm that this enrichment is not merely due to their genomic features, we performed a disease enrichment analysis for HAR-associated genes compared with other genes associated with evolutionary conserved elements (3,083,588 evolutionary conserved elements with phastCons score >0.40 (similar to most HARs) were mapped to 16,676 protein-coding genes), and HGE -associated genes over genes associated with fetal brain enhancers (186,304 enhancers reported in Reilly et al. were mapped to total 15,693 protein-coding genes), where we obtained similar results (Supplementary Fig. 5c [this file] ). 
To experimentally validate Hi-C predicted candidate target genes of HARs, we chose HARs that (1) overlap with H3K27ac marks in fetal brain and (2) interact with developmentally important genes expressed in human neural progenitors (Supplementary Fig. 8 [this file] ), and that are 3) predicted to regulate only one gene. RNA was extracted by miRNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) and the expression level of putative target genes ( , , and ) was measured by qPCR (LightCycler 480 SYBR Green I Master, Roche) and normalized to . gRNA and primer sequences for both genomic DNA and qPCR are described in Supplementary Table 3 [this file] . 
Promoter-based interaction maps for fetal brain and adult brain are available in Supplementary Tables 22 [this file] – 23 [this file] of Won et al. and the PsychENCODE knowledge portal, respectively.

title: Click here for additional data file.
context_description:
A full list of Abs used in all experiments is shown in Supplemental Fig. 4G [href=this file] .
In our aged mouse HMPV model, aged mock-infected CD4 T cells had increased expression compared with young CD4 T cells, but there was no difference in CD19 B cells ( Supplemental Fig. 1A [href=this file] ). We also found that upregulation of PD-1 during HMPV infection was specific to CD8 T cells with no difference in PD-1 on CD4 T or CD19 B cells between young and aged HMPV-infected mice ( Supplemental Fig 1B [href=this file] ). PD-1 expression robustly increased with infection in young mice but stayed elevated in aged mice in both mock and HMPV infection ( Fig. 1E [href=#fig01] ). scRNAseq data revealed no difference in (TIM-3), , or (2B4) inhibitory receptor expression on CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 1C [href=this file] – 1E [href=this file] ), which we confirmed at the protein level in mock-infected mice via flow cytometry ( Supplemental Fig. 1F [href=this file] ).
There were no significant differences in PD-L1 or PD-L2 expression between ages in mock- or HMPV-infected groups across numerous innate immune cell types ( Fig. 1I [href=#fig01] and Supplemental Fig. 1G [href=this file] ), with the exception of a small increase in PD-L2 expression in aged mock interstitial macrophages ( Supplemental Fig. 1G [href=this file] ). We also found no difference between ages in (PD-L1) ( Fig. 1J [href=#fig01] ) or in (PD-L2) ( Supplemental Fig. 1H [href=this file] ) in the lung myeloid cell scRNAseq dataset ( 8 [href=#r8] ).
PD-1 blockade had no significant impact on the production of HMPV-specific lung CD8 T cells, based on tetramer staining with the HMPV viral epitope H2-D/K N (N11) ( Fig. 2D [href=#fig02] , 2E [href=#fig02] ), and also did not impact the T CD8 T cells that expressed TOX and EOMES ( Fig. 2F [href=#fig02] , 2G [href=#fig02] ; Supplemental Fig. 1I [href=this file] – 1K [href=this file] ).
We confirmed PD-1 expression was absent on CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 2A [href=this file] ). There was no significant difference in weight loss ( Supplemental Fig. 2B [href=this file] ) or viral titer ( Supplemental Fig. 2C [href=this file] ) in aged mice. No difference was seen in TIM-3 expression between aged and WT mice ( Supplemental Fig. 2D [href=this file] , 2E [href=this file] ). However, LAG-3 expression was increased ( Supplemental Fig. 2F [href=this file] , 2G [href=this file] ) on CD8 tet T cells. PD-1 absence did not significantly affect the expression levels or absolute cell numbers of CD44 and CD62L on CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 2H [href=this file] , 2K [href=this file] ). We found no significant differences in the frequency or absolute cell number of CD4 Foxp3 , T-bet , GATA3 ( Supplemental Fig. 2I [href=this file] , 2L [href=this file] ), or Th1/Th2 ratio between genotypes ( Supplemental Fig. 2J [href=this file] ).
We next assessed whether this increase in CD8 T cell function was comparable to the increase in function we observed in young T cells compared with young WT T cells both in this study and in our previous studies ( Supplemental Fig. 2M [href=this file] ) ( 12–15 [href=#r12] ).
We confirmed the identity of transplanted T cells by assessing PD-1 expression on CD45.2 CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 3A [href=this file] ). There was no difference in weight loss or viral burden between the four groups ( Supplemental Fig. 3B [href=this file] , 3C [href=this file] ). We also assessed engraftment of recipient (CD45.1) and donor (CD45.2) total CD3 lymphocytes, CD4 T cells, and CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 3D [href=this file] ). lymphocytes engrafted better than B6 lymphocytes ( Supplemental Fig. 3D [href=this file] – 3G [href=this file] ), especially in bulk CD3 ( Supplemental Fig. 3E [href=this file] ) and CD8 T lymphocytes ( Supplemental Fig. 3G [href=this file] ), as previously observed ( 15 [href=#r15] ).
To remove irradiation as a confounding variable, we performed an adoptive transfer of young or aged CD8 T cells into young recipients along with young WT CD4 T cells and B cells ( Supplemental Fig. 4A [href=this file] ). When we compared the function of young and aged CD8 T cells in this model, we observed that young CD8 T cells were still more functional in granzyme B and IFN-γ production than aged CD8 T cells ( Supplemental Fig. 4B [href=this file] – 4D [href=this file] ).
Fig. 4E [href=this file] ). Viral replication may have been limited in this rechallenge by anti-HMPV Ab responses in all groups ( Supplemental Fig. 4F [href=this file] ).
The online version of this article contains supplemental material [href=this file] .

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S5
caption: No description
context_description:
See also Figure S1 [this file] . 
For further validation, by randomizing the set of tropisms, the LDA loses all its discriminating power ( Figure S1 [this file] A). Supporting the robustness of the clustering, we obtained the same performance by using another reduced list of human viruses from ViralZone ( Hulo et al., 2011 [rid=bib34] ; Figure S1 [this file] B; Table S1 [rid=mmc2] ). 
As shown in Figure S1 [this file] , we observed that RNA folding, as determined by the minimum free energy, was also non-randomly distributed among tropisms. 
This analysis was replicated with the other list of viruses from ViralZone, leading to comparable predictive outcomes ( Figure S2 [this file] ; p < 0.01, permutation test in Table S2 [rid=mmc3] ). In concordance, a LDA of the average SDA of each virus across tissues can similarly separate different clusters of viral tropism based on their translational efficiencies ( Figure S2 [this file] ). 
See also Figures S2–S5 [this file] . 
The results showed similar predictive performances compared to TCGA ( Figure S3 [this file] ). 
As a result, we observed that the SARS-CoV-2 proteome is especially adapted to the upper respiratory airways and alveoli but also to other tissues such as the gastrointestinal tract and brain ( Figures S4 [this file] and S5 [this file] ; Table S3 [rid=mmc4] ; see STAR Methods [rid=sec4] ). 
However, as suggested by Figure S1 [this file] , many other and overlapping forces, such as mRNA stability, frameshift motifs, transcriptional regulation, or codon-dependent immune responses, are also known to shape the composition of coding sequences ( Bergman and Tuller, 2020 [rid=bib10] ; Li et al., 2012 [rid=bib39] ). 
In particular, we found that SARS-CoV-2 is highly adapted to the upper respiratory tract and the alveoli ( Figure S4 [this file] C), which is in agreement with recent single-cell transcriptomic studies reporting the expression of ACE2 in the nasal goblet and ciliated cells as well as the type-2 alveolar epithelial cells ( Sungnak et al., 2020 [rid=bib66] ; Ziegler et al., 2020 [rid=bib83] ). In terms of the evolution of the new coronavirus, given the similarity of SARS-CoV-2 SDA with the phylogenetically closest bat coronavirus ( Figure S5 [this file] B), it seems that a translational selection to increase SDA would have acted before the putative zoonosis from bats or other intermediate hosts. 
We assigned each virus to its corresponding tropism ( Table S1 [rid=mmc2] ) in order to find the linear combination of tissue adaptation features that maximized differences between viral target tissues ( Figure S2 [this file] ; Table S2 [rid=mmc3] ). 
We then computed the SDA of viral proteins from the three pandemic coronaviruses of the last two decades SARS-CoV ( Drosten et al., 2003 [rid=bib19] ), MERS-CoV ( Zaki et al., 2012 [rid=bib75] ), and SARS-CoV-2 ( Zhou et al., 2020a [rid=bib81] ), as well as the common flu-causing influenza A virus (H1N1) along the respiratory tract ( Figure S4 [this file] A). For this reason, we also extended our translational analysis to all the 23 tissues of the TCGA dataset ( Figure S5 [this file] A). 
Moreover, given that the tropisms not only depend on the translational adaptation to the host, but also on the expression of the required entry receptors, we measured the respective receptors of each virus ( Figure S4 [this file] B; Table S3 [rid=mmc4] ). 
In an attempt to elucidate the translational selection that could have benefitted the evolution of the new coronavirus, we also compared the SDA adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 to those of close phylogenetic strains ( Figure S5 [this file] B): the human-infecting SARS-CoV and the bat coronavirus RatG13, with 79.6% and 96.2% of sequence identity, respectively ( Zhou et al., 2020a [rid=bib81] ).

context_description:
Publicly available genomic data comprised a total of 502 human-infecting viruses, distributed among 35 families and covering all 7 Baltimore categories ( Table S1 [this file] ). Their corresponding coding sequences constituted a total of 6,087 viral proteins ( Table S1 [this file] ), for which we determined the relative codon usage (RCU; i.e., the contribution of each synonymous codon to the amino acid it encodes; see STAR Methods [rid=sec4] ). 
Supporting the robustness of the clustering, we obtained the same performance by using another reduced list of human viruses from ViralZone ( Hulo et al., 2011 [rid=bib34] ; Figure S1 [rid=mmc1] B; Table S1 [this file] ). 
Also, for some viruses, multiple genotypes and variants are represented in the NCBI database, although they actually do showcase differences in codon usage ( Table S1 [this file] ; Figure 1 [rid=fig1] ). 
Table S1 [this file] contains all human-infecting viruses and their associated metadata. 
The coding sequences of human-infecting viruses from RefSeq were downloaded from the Codon/Codon Pair Usage Tables (CoCoPUTs) project release as of June 9, 2020 ( Alexaki et al., 2019 [rid=bib4] ; Athey et al., 2017 [rid=bib5] ; Table S1 [this file] ). 
We assigned each virus to its corresponding tropism ( Table S1 [this file] ) in order to find the linear combination of codon features that maximized differences between viral target tissues. 
We assigned each virus to its corresponding tropism ( Table S1 [this file] ) in order to find the linear combination of tissue adaptation features that maximized differences between viral target tissues ( Figure S2 [rid=mmc1] ; Table S2 [rid=mmc3] ).

title: Table S2. Random Forest Dataset, related to Figure 2

Feature weights describing the components of the Linear Discriminant Analysis (Figure S2). tRNA isoacceptor quantification in Reads Per Million (RPM) of the set of 7 tissue-wide cell lines using Hydro-tRNA-sequencing. context_description:
Therefore, taking the average of all healthy samples across each of the 23 TCGA cancer types, we determined the estimated translational efficiencies of viral proteins in different human tissues ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
The resulting performance of the models, based on the area under the curve (AUC) of their receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, ranges 0.79–0.92 ( Figure 2 [rid=fig2] A), which is clearly higher than the no-skill model of 0.5 (p < 0.01, permutation test in Table S2 [this file] ). This analysis was replicated with the other list of viruses from ViralZone, leading to comparable predictive outcomes ( Figure S2 [rid=mmc1] ; p < 0.01, permutation test in Table S2 [this file] ). 
Refer to Table S2 [this file] for full TCGA cancer type names. 
To evaluate the adaptation of the viral proteins to the SDAw of human tissues, we computed their average SDA to each of the 23 TCGA tissues ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
In addition, we also validate the predictive potential of the model by performing a permutation test over 100 randomizations of the tropism labels of the dataset ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
For the dataset of Hydro-tRNaseq of human cells, we computed the average viral RtAI to each of the seven cell lines ( Table S2 [this file] ). 
We assigned each virus to its corresponding tropism ( Table S1 [rid=mmc2] ) in order to find the linear combination of tissue adaptation features that maximized differences between viral target tissues ( Figure S2 [rid=mmc1] ; Table S2 [this file] ).
pub_title: Translational adaptation of human viruses to the tissues they infect

context_description:
As a result, we observed that the SARS-CoV-2 proteome is especially adapted to the upper respiratory airways and alveoli but also to other tissues such as the gastrointestinal tract and brain ( Figures S4 [rid=mmc1] and S5 [rid=mmc1] ; Table S3 [this file] ; see STAR Methods [rid=sec4] ). 
The SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 sequences were directly downloaded from GenBank ( Table S3 [this file] ; NCBI RefSeq: NC_045512.2 (NC_045512.2) ; GenBank: MN996532.1 (MN996532.1) ). 
We initially reconstructed tRNA expression profiles along the respiratory tract making use of the spatial information associated with healthy TCGA samples from head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSC), lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) and lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) ( Table S3 [this file] ). 
Moreover, given that the tropisms not only depend on the translational adaptation to the host, but also on the expression of the required entry receptors, we measured the respective receptors of each virus ( Figure S4 [rid=mmc1] B; Table S3 [this file] ).

context_description:
Following preprocessing and quality control, our dataset consisted of 59,588 tissue-covered spots, with each spot capturing RNA from an average of 3.7 nuclei and detecting an average of 2,361 genes ( Supplementary Figure 1a [this file] – d [this file] ). This analysis revealed significant correlations between the two data modalities, suggesting that immunofluorescent staining can be reliably combined with the Visium ST protocol ( Supplementary Figure 2a [this file] – d [this file] ). 
Comparing layer-specific transcriptional signatures derived from our dataset with those derived from a published DLPFC ST dataset with H&E-based manual layer annotation showed a strong correlation, confirming the concordance of our clustering-based annotation with classical histopathological annotation ( Supplementary Figure 3a [this file] ) . Furthermore, using our layer annotations and plaque locations, we found a higher rate of plaques in the deeper layers (L4 - L6) compared to the upper layers (L1 - L3), ( Supplementary Table 2 [rid=SD3] ; Supplementary Figure 3b [this file] – e [this file] ), similar to previously published results . 
Metallothioneins showed the highest transcription levels in the nuclei of astrocytes, although they were also transcribed by other cell types at lower levels ( Supplementary Figure 4a [this file] ). The upregulated gene was almost exclusively transcribed by astrocytes in our human gray matter DLPFC data ( Supplementary Figure 4a [this file] ). 
The predicted abundances of excitatory neuronal subpopulations reflected the cortical laminar structure, consistent with the layer-specific annotations of these subpopulations from the Allen Brain Map ( Supplementary Figure 5a [this file] – d [this file] ). Consistently, Ast.5 exhibited a reactive-like transcription signature in the snRNA-seq data with high levels of and expression ( Supplementary Figure 4b [this file] ), two of the four genes significantly upregulated at neuritic plaques . 
At a cellular level, astrocytes are known to exhibit the highest levels of metallothionein expression in the human brain ( Supplementary Figure 4 [this file] ), but other cell types may also contribute. 
GFAP MFI values per spot ( Supplementary Figure 2 [this file] ) were calculated in ImageJ (1.54f) by mapping spot coordinates to raw images.
