title: Label-free quantification of proteins in human central nervous system (CNS) myelin and white matter homogenate by two different data acquisition modes.
caption: Identification and quantification data of detected myelin-associated and homogenate proteins. Tryptic peptides derived from two technical replicates (replicate digestion) per five biological replicates were analyzed by liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC-MS) (10 runs per condition in total). Proteins (false discovery rate [FDR] < 1%; two peptides/protein) and peptides (FDR < 1%; ≥6 amino acids) were identified by database search against the UniProtKB/SwissProt mouse database using ProteinLynx Global Server (PLGS). Data were postprocessed with the software package ISOQuant to calculate absolute in-sample amounts for each detected protein based on the TOP3 approach. Reported abundance values are defined as the relative amount of each protein with respect to the sum over all detected proteins (ppm, parts per million [w/w] of total protein). Typical contaminant proteins like albumin, hemoglobins, keratins, and trypsin were filtered. Tables are sorted by description (column D) in alphabetical order.
description: Figure  1—source  data  1.  Label-free  quantification  of  proteins  in  human  central  nervous  system  (CNS)  myelin  and  white  matter  homogenate  by  two  different  data  acquisition  modes.  Identification  and  quantification  data  of  detected  myelin-associated  and  homogenate  proteins.  Tryptic  peptides  derived  from  two  technical  replicates  (replicate  digestion)  per  five  biological  replicates  were  analyzed  by  liquid  chromatography–mass  spectrometry  (LC-MS)  (10  runs  per  condition  in  total).  Proteins  (false  discovery  rate  [FDR]  <  1%;  two  peptides/protein)  and  peptides  (FDR  <  1%;  ≥6  amino  acids)  were  identified  by  database  search  against  the  UniProtKB/SwissProt  mouse  database  using  ProteinLynx  Global  Server  (PLGS).  Data  were  postprocessed  with  the  software  package  ISOQuant  to  calculate  absolute  in-sample  amounts  for  each  detected  protein  based  on  the  TOP3  approach.  Reported  abundance  values  are  defined  as  the  relative  amount  of  each  protein  with  respect  to  the  sum  over  all  detected  proteins  (ppm,  parts  per  million  [w/w]  of  total  protein).  Typical  contaminant  proteins  like  albumin,  hemoglobins,  keratins,  and  trypsin  were  filtered.  Tables  are  sorted  by  description  (column  D)  in  alphabetical  order.
context_description:
When assessing myelin by MS , we quantified 332 proteins ( Figure 1—source data 1 [this file] ; labeled in green in Figure 1a [rid=fig1] ) with a false discovery rate (FDR) of <1% and an average sequence coverage of 39.6%. When using the ultra-definition (UD)MS mode, in which ion mobility spectrometry enables an additional separation of peptides after chromatography and before mass measurement, we identified and quantified 835 proteins with an average sequence coverage of 37.0% ( Figure 1—source data 1 [this file] ; labeled in blue in Figure 1a [rid=fig1] ). 
See Figure 1—source data 1 [this file] for datasets. ppm, parts per million. ( ) Scatter plot comparing the log -transformed relative abundance of proteins identified in myelin by MS against their abundance as identified by UDMS . 
See Figure 1—source data 1 [this file] for datasets. n = 5 biological replicates analyzed as two technical replicates each. 
Next, we compared our human ( Figure 1—source data 1 [this file] ) and mouse myelin ( Jahn et al., 2020 [rid=bib28] ) proteome datasets (by MS or UDMS ) with the averaged vdW-normalized mRNA abundance profile of MOL in the respective same species.

title: Parameters applied for scRNA-seq individual dataset quality control and integrative analysis.
caption: No description
description: Figure  3—source  data  1.  Parameters  applied  for  scRNA-seq  individual  dataset  quality  control  and  integrative  analysis.
context_description:
To this aim, we retrieved previously published scRNA-seq datasets from the CNS of humans ( Jäkel et al., 2019 [rid=bib29] ; Zhou et al., 2020 [rid=bib71] ; Lake et al., 2018 [rid=bib34] ; Habib et al., 2017 [rid=bib23] ; Grubman et al., 2019 [rid=bib22] ; Wheeler et al., 2020 [rid=bib62] ) and mice ( Falcão et al., 2018 [rid=bib18] ; Wheeler et al., 2020 [rid=bib62] ; Marques et al., 2016 [rid=bib36] ; Saunders et al., 2018 [rid=bib48] ; Zeisel et al., 2018 [rid=bib69] ; Zeisel et al., 2015 [rid=bib68] ; Ximerakis et al., 2019 [rid=bib64] ) and evaluated all cells designated as oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPCs), newly formed oligodendrocytes (NFOs), and MOL from nondiseased subjects ( Figure 3—figure supplement 1a and b [rid=fig3s1] , Figure 3—source data 1 [this file] ). Indeed, only 132 cells designated as NFO were comprised in the available human scRNA-seq datasets, considerably fewer compared to 10,391 NFO recovered from the mouse datasets ( Figure 3—source data 1 [this file] ). 
For quality control, each of the retrieved datasets was analyzed using the Seurat R package (version 3.1.4; Butler et al., 2018 [rid=bib6] ) in an analysis pipeline, including validating sequencing quality, filtering for outlier cells (as specified in Figure 3—source data 1 [this file] ), log-normalizing the expression matrix with a scale factor 10,000, high variable gene selection and data scaling, linear dimensionality reduction using principal component analysis (PCA), and neighboring embedding using UMAP to ensure accurate cell type annotation and detect any potential batch effect. Specific parameters applied to individual datasets and the number of recovered cells are listed in Figure 3—source data 1 [this file] .

All ENCODE accessions used are listed in Supplementary Table S2 [this file] .

We then calculate the fraction of unique peaks shown in Figure 1 [rid=F1] A and Supplementary Figure S2 [this file] as: 
All ChIP-seq targets and cell types used in Epitome are listed in Supplementary Table S2 [this file] . 
However, Epitome can make predictions in a query cellular context using other assays that measure chromatin accessibility, such as ATAC-seq (see Supplementary Figure S14 [this file] ). 
This maximum genomic distance of 12 kb was determined through hyperparameter search using validation chromosome 7 (See Supplementary Figure S12a [this file] ). Without the CASV, Epitome is not able to provide cell type specific predictions for , as shown in Supplementary Figure S12a [this file] . 
However, ATAC-seq can also be used to compute the CASV (See Supplementary Figure S14 [this file] ). 
Training on multiple cell types allows Epitome to generalize well to new cell types, and allows Epitome to achieve similar precision to methods that see the cell type being evaluated during training ( Supplementary Figures S10 and S11 [this file] ). This procedure is visualized in Supplementary Figure S4 [this file] , where at each iteration, the choice of cell types used in and the cell type used for are rotated through until the model has converged. 
Supplementary Figure S16 [this file] visualizes changes in validation and training loss for a subset of 18 ChIP-seq targets in a joint Epitome model trained for 2000 iterations, where training loss is calculated as the mean sigmoid cross entropy across 10 000 randomly selected training regions, and the validation loss is calculated as the mean sigmoid cross entropy across all 200 bp regions on chromosome 7 that have epigenetic signal from at least one of the 18 ChIP-seq targets. 
For Epitome, we found 5 and 0 to be the most optimal patience and min-delta, respectively, after tuning and comparing the hyperparameters shown in Supplementary Figure S15b [this file] . 
Supplementary Figure S15a [this file] compares the model accuracy (auPRC) with and without the early stopping method on 85 ChIP-seq targets. 
Information regarding each algorithm and the features used for each method are listed in Supplementary Table S1 [this file] . We compared these methods by predicting binding sites for 77 TFs and chromatin modifiers in 40 held out cell lines, tissues, and primary cells, enumerated in Supplementary Table S6 [this file] . 
We additionally used motifs published by Kheradpour ( 50 [rid=B50] ), available at http://compbio.mit.edu/encode-motifs/ (http://compbio.mit.edu/encode-motifs/) (See Supplementary Table S5 [this file] for a list of motifs used). 
All combinations considered are listed in Supplementary Table S6 [this file] . In total, we trained 323 DeFCoM models. auPRC and pAUC scores for both methods can be found in Supplementary Table S7 [this file] . 
Therefore, we only compare Epitome and DeFCoM in regions overlapping motifs, shown in Figure 2 [rid=F2] B and Supplementary Figure S8 [this file] . 
This is demonstrated in Supplementary Figure S7 [this file] , which shows comparisons of pAUC and auPRC when evaluated on all 200 bp regions on chromosomes 8 and 9. While it is generally a simple classification problem to predict nonbinding in genomic loci with no measured regulatory activity, it is harder to predict nonbinding in regions that have some epigenetic signal. pAUC and auPRC values used to generate Figure 2 [rid=F2] using this sampling technique on chromosomes 8 and 9 can be found in Supplementary Table S8 [this file] . Example ROC and PR curves are shown in Supplementary Figure S9 [this file] . 
We used all motifs as those used to train DeFCoM, available in Cis-BP database and Kheradpour ( 49 [rid=B49] , 50 [rid=B50] ) ( Supplementary Table S5 [this file] ). 
Evaluations of Epitome and DeepSEA are shown in Supplementary Figures S10 and S11 [this file] . We selected all 200 bp regions for evaluation as defined in Defining the test set to compare Epitome, Catchitt and Avocado. pAUC and auPRC values used to generate Supplementary Figure S10 [this file] can be found in Supplementary Table S9 [this file] . 
Supplementary Figure S5 [this file] shows the ratio of ChIP-seq peaks that do not overlap any motif for a TF or chromatin modifier of interest. We considered all motifs specified in Supplementary Table S5 [this file] . TFs, chromatin modifiers, and cell types evaluated are listed in Supplementary Table S6 [this file] . Ratios used to generate Supplementary Figure S5 [this file] can be found in Supplementary Table S10 [this file] . 
Heatmaps shown in Supplementary Figure S12 [this file] were generated using Seaborn ( 53 [rid=B53] ). 
Supplementary Figure S14 [this file] shows that Epitome models that are trained on DNase-seq and validated using ATAC-seq perform comparably when validated using DNase-seq. 
listed in Supplementary Table S4 [this file] . 
We therefore compared Epitome and DeFCoM by evaluating the ability of each method to predict TFBS overlapping motifs for 77 TFs and chromatin modifiers across 40 cell lines, primary cells, and tissues ( Supplementary Table S6 [this file] ). 
This is demonstrated in Supplementary Figure S5 [this file] , which shows that the ratio of ChIP-seq peaks that do not overlap any motif for a TF in question can range from 0.45 to 1.0 for the 77 TFs and chromatin modifiers we evaluated (see Evaluation of motif overlap of ChIP-seq peaks for 77 transcription factors and chromatin modifiers in 40 cell types). To compare to these methods, we first evaluated chromosome wide predictions of Epitome, Avocado, and Catchitt, on all 77 TFs and chromatin modifiers across 40 cell lines, primary cells, and tissues ( Supplementary Figure S6 [this file] ) on held-out chromosomes 8 and 9 in Figure 2A [rid=F2] , for a total of 264 comparisons. While joint Epitome models perform similarly in terms of pAUC and better for many instances in terms of auPRC compared to single Catchitt models ( Supplementary Figure S6a [this file] ), Avocado performs poorest on these metrics (Figure 2A [rid=F2] ). Supplementary Figure S6b [this file] additionally shows that for many cases, single Epitome models perform better than jointly trained Epitome models. As shown in Supplementary Figure S16 [this file] , different ChIP-seq targets trained in a joint model converge at different iterations during training. 
Supplementary Figure S10 [this file] shows that even though DeepSEA trains using a given test cell line and Epitome does not, Epitome performs comparably to DeepSEA in both pAUC and auPRC. Supplementary Figure S11 [this file] show receiver operating characteristic curves and precision-recall curves for these methods in all four held out cell lines from ENCODE. 
This observation is most easily observed in change in AUC as wider genomic contexts are considered, shown in Supplementary Figure S12a [this file] . Supplementary Figure S12b and c [this file] shows that when histone modifications are trained on more than 10 cell types, performance decreases as wider genomic contexts are considered. 
This is also a common use case that a query cellular context has been partially characterized with multiple experiments, including chromatin accessibility and various histone modifications ( Supplementary Figure S3 [this file] ). 
Although the Epitome model primarily uses DNase-seq to compute the CASV and train its models, we show in Supplementary Figure S14 [this file] that Epitome can accurately predict histone modifications and TFBS when using ATAC-seq during evaluation in the CASV when Epitome has been trained using DNase-seq. 
Figure 5D [rid=F5] and Supplementary Figure S13a [this file] show Epitome predictions for H3K27ac at 72 h in peak and non-peak regions respectively. 
Figure 1 [rid=F1] A and Supplementary Figure S1 [this file] similarly show that across 152 ChIP-seq and DNase-seq experiments, the fraction of unique peaks discovered in each cell type used in Epitome decreases as more cell types are characterized for a given experiment. 
These results are shown in Supplementary Figure S3 [this file] , and show that many histone modifications, including H3K27ac, H3K27me3, and H3K4me1 and H3K4me2, are frequently collected, along with at least one other additional ChIP-seq target of interest. 
As shown in Figure 2 [rid=F2] and Supplementary Figure S6b [this file] , models that are trained individually on epigenetic events of interest often outperform models trained jointly.
pub_title: Epitome: predicting epigenetic events in novel cell types with multi-cell deep ensemble learning

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S6 and Table S1
caption: No description
description: Document  S1.  Figures  S1–S6  and  Table  S1
context_description:
Finally, instead of using a supporting read threshold to filter as most methods do, Anchored-fusion incorporates a model with a deep neural network called the HVLD model to filter out false positive fusions that may be caused by artificial factors during the experimental process ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] B and S1 [this file] ). 
For example, the classical BCR-ABL1 fusion gene contains a 47 bp short homologous sequence with chromosome 5 near its fusion breakpoint, which causes some supporting evidences at that location to be incorrectly matched or filtered out due to multiple alignments ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] C and S2 [this file] ). As a result, the supporting sequencing reads of the DUX4 fusion gene are matched to hundreds of loci, leading to few supporting evidences or even the erroneous removal of the fusion event ( Figures 1 [rid=fig1] D and S3 [this file] ). 
For all test cases, we took the real fusions downloaded from Pan-Cancer Analysis of Whole Genomes as positive samples ( Figure S4 [this file] ). 
The fusion breakpoints identified by each tool among the fusion partners are listed in Table S1 [this file] . 
The fusion gene with the breakpoint at 1,905,943 is derived from RRMM1 and RRMM2, and the one with the breakpoint at nucleotide 1,902,353 is derived from SMM0 ( Figures 6 [rid=fig6] B and S5 [this file] ). 
The specific process of obtaining training and testing data is shown in Figure S4 [this file] . 
Randomly selecting negative samples and using the entire set for training showed no significant differences in performance. ( Figure S6 [this file] ).
pub_title: Anchored-fusion enables targeted fusion search in bulk and single-cell RNA sequencing data

title: Document S1. Figures S1–S9
caption: No description
context_description:
By extension, compounds targeting the same proteins should induce similar transcriptional signatures, which in turn can shed insight into its MoA ( Figure S1 [this file] ). 
The most comprehensive such evaluation to date, the Kinome-Binding Resource (KBR), measured the affinity of 230 clinically relevant kinase inhibitors across 255 kinases. [xref] [rid=bib18] While restricted to this protein class, this dataset is well-suited to benchmarking methods aimed at predicting drug polypharmacology by providing criteria for the evaluation of systems pharmacology approaches ( Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Interestingly, SC1 and SC2 scores revealed distinct distribution profiles: on average, most predictions were statistically significantly enriched on the top 10 target metric (SC1) but not on the entire list enrichment (SC2) ( Figures S3 [this file] A and S3B) 
Figures S3 [this file] C and 3D summarize the results of this analysis, with each box showing a team’s bootstrapped scores, and the color of the box indicating the Bayes factor relative to the top performer. Using this criteria, Team Atom and Team Netphar were confirmed as the top performers in SC1 and SC2, respectively ( Figures S3 [this file] C and S3D), while team SBNB was a close second in SC2 (Bayes factor 3–5). 
This analysis ( Figures S3 [this file] E and S3F) changed the ranking of some teams in SC1, most notably Team Theragen, whose original second place fell to ninth place when non-KBR targets were not pre-filtered. 
To better understand the models and the difference in their performances, we examined sub-challenge scores on an individual drug basis ( Figures S3 [this file] G and S3H). 
To address this question, we evaluated the ratio between the scores of the top three winning teams when either DrugBank or KBR targets were used as bona fide high-affinity targets of the 32 drugs used in the challenge ( Figure S4 [this file] ). While the scores based on DrugBank targets were consistently higher (Netphar, 3:2; SBNB, 4:2; and Atom, 1.7:1.4), they all showed positive enrichment within the prediction vector ( Figure S4 [this file] ). 
We compared the ranked performance of each prediction using these various databases as gold standards (KBR/Kinome, ChEMBL, DrugTargetCommons, KinomeScan, and DrugBank) to evaluate the stability of the predictions with different ground truths ( Figure S5 [this file] ). 
To evaluate the general relationships between kinase targets and mRNA programs, we assessed the correlation of the KBR-reported with transcriptional hallmarks (as detailed in Supplemental information [this file] ) across 84 drugs present in both databases ( Figure 4 [rid=fig4] D). 
Drug sensitivity training data was obtained from DrugComb, a curated database that includes batch-corrected drug sensitivities for both single drugs and drug combinations. [xref] [rid=bib27] In addition to the commonly used IC (half maximum inhibitory concenration), DrugComb provides an AUC-based relative inhibition (RI) metric, [xref] [rid=bib35] which captures both the potency and efficacy of drug responses ( Figure S6 [this file] A). 
Examining correlations between predicted and gold-standard targets, we found that adding drug sensitivity data significantly improved prediction accuracy relative to transcriptional data alone ( Figure S6 [this file] B). Performance improvements were driven by several individual drugs whose targets were poorly predicted based on perturbational profile data only, including sunitinib, crizotinib, and crenolanib ( Figure S6 [this file] C). 
This addresses two major reasons for clinical trial failures: lack of safety and efficacy. [xref] [rid=bib37] [xref] [rid=bib38] Failure rates may be substantially reduced if compound MoAs could be assessed more accurately and comprehensively ( Figures S1 [this file] A and S1B). 
Most of the experimental approaches rely on direct binding assays, such as ATP competitive pull-down, [xref] [rid=bib18] affinity purification [xref] [rid=bib39] [xref] [rid=bib40] or affinity chromatography assays. [xref] [rid=bib41] These labor-intensive methods are generally limited to the identification of high-affinity binding targets rather than the full protein repertoire responsible for compound activity in a tissue and are often restricted to a specific protein family, such as protein kinases ( Figure S1 [this file] A). Thus, critically relevant targets outside of these relatively narrow confines may be missed, as shown by the recent reclassification of the MET tyrosine receptor kinase inhibitor tivantinib as a microtubule inhibitor. [xref] [rid=bib42] Indeed, drug polypharmacology is emerging as a critical concept that increasingly impacts the mechanistic understanding of a drug’s disease-specific impact, for instance via a field effect mediated by multiple targets rather than by their primary, high-affinity binding target ( Figure S1 [this file] B). 
More recently, systematic gene expression profiling (GEP) following compound perturbations in cell lines [xref] [rid=bib8] [xref] [rid=bib11] [xref] [rid=bib23] [xref] [rid=bib50] has furthered the development of computational methods for MoA analysis ( Figure S1 [this file] B). 
The objective benchmark used in this challenge is the Kinome-Binding Resource (KBR), a systematic set of ATP-competitive binding assays assessing the ability of 230 candidate kinase inhibitor molecules to bind to one of 255 protein kinases ( Figure S2 [this file] ). 
A critical issue emerging from the evaluation of individual prediction performance and individual databases is that the concept of is still poorly defined and inconsistent ( Figure S2 [this file] ). 
Indeed, the fact that the perturbational signature significantly contributed to correct target inference suggests that downstream transcriptional regulators represent a valuable reporter assay that can distinguish the MoA of different compounds ( Figures 4 [rid=fig4] and S6 [this file] ). 
While we did not observe major differences between model performances based on modeling strategy, generally, similarity-weighted average methodologies performed best in SC2 ( Figures S7 [this file] and S8 [this file] ), while neural-network-based methodologies performed best in SC1 ( Figure S9 [this file] ). 
In the post-challenge phase of this study, we re-evaluated the performance of each team ( Figure S3 [this file] ) by repeating this analysis but omitting the kinase filtering step described above. 
Detailed computational procedure Figure S4 [this file] 
Detailed algorithm for winning team “SBNB” ( Figure S8 [this file] ): 
Detailed algorithm for winning team “ATOM” ( Figure S9 [this file] ):
pub_title: A community challenge for a pancancer drug mechanism of action inference from perturbational profile data

title: Table S1. Metadata on drug libraries used in this study, related to Figures 1C and 1D which list these 32 drugs

description: Table  S1.  Metadata  on  drug  libraries  used  in  this  study,  related  to  Figures  1C  and  1D  which  list  these  32  drugs  This  table  includes  Drug  Name,  identifier  codes,  disease-indication,  pathway  information,  FDA  approval  status  and  maximum  concentration  in  serum.
context_description:
In the CTD2 Pancancer Drug Activity DREAM Challenge, participants were asked to use DREAM-provided and publicly available pharmacogenomic datasets—including cell-line-matched DRCs and gene expression profiles of drug-naive and -perturbed cells (perturbational profiles)—to predict compound binding proteins (high-affinity targets) of 32 anonymized drugs ( Figure 1 [rid=fig1] A, Table S1 [this file] ). 
In order to optimize the clinical translation potential of the perturbation databases, we used the CMax, defined as the maximum plasma concentration after the administration of the drug at the maximum tolerated dose in patients, (whenever available from published pharmacokinetic studies), as an upper bound for the perturbation studies ( Table S1 [this file] ). 
Sidebar annotations of canonical drug-targets were defined based on the DrugBank definitions of drug-targets as detailed in Table S1 [this file] . 
To better understand the type of inhibitors that models performed the best on we calculated the enrichment of each drugbank target kinases (as defined in Table S1 [this file] ) over the ranked 32-drug vector in Figures 4 [rid=fig4] A and 4B using the aREA algorithm in the viper package in R. [xref] [rid=bib12]  To visualize the kinases sampled by the Klaeger et. al [xref] [rid=bib18] definitions of drug-targets we color-coded individual kinase-nodes within the Human Kinome phylogenetic tree obtained from the CORAL tool. [xref] [rid=bib64] Kinases measured in the Kinome-dataset were color coded based the Kinase group that they were a member of as defined in Manning et al. [xref] [rid=bib31]  To better understand the relationships between individual kinases and down-stream transcriptional programs we calculated the correlation matrix between the Kinome Kd’s (250 kinases x 84 drugs) and the pan-cancer transcriptional signature PANACEA-data (50 signatures x 84 drugs) across 84 overlapping drugs that occurred in both datasets.
pub_title: A community challenge for a pancancer drug mechanism of action inference from perturbational profile data

On average, each tissue contained 66,395 cells (ranging from 2,638 cells in PBMCs to 287,269 in the heart) and 24,064 genes (ranging from 13,714 genes in PBMCs to 33,694 in the heart and kidney) ( Supplementary Table S1 [this file] ).

title: media-1.xlsx
description: Table S1. Major cell type significant gene markers.
context_description:
From the snRNAseq data, we identified major cell types across all three regions from all donors, including oligodendrocytes, oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs), astrocytes, ependymal cells, microglia, macrophages, vascular cells, glutamatergic neurons and GABAergic neurons ( Fig 1E [href=#F1] , 1F [href=#F1] and Table S1 [href=this file] ). We observed oligodendrocyte and CD44-high astrocyte enrichment in the white matter adjacent to cortical gray matter ( Fig. 1I [href=#F1] ), and also confirmed that our cortical glutamatergic neuron subsets ( Table S2 [href=this file] ) localized to grey matter layers predicted by Azimuth human motor cortex reference ( Fig 1J [href=#F1] and 1K [href=#F1] ).
In donors with primary or secondary demyelination, however, we found only the GABA_6_CCK_LAMP5 subtype lower in the DLPFC in donors with primary demyelination and secondary demyelination ( Fig. 2A [href=#F2] , 2B [href=#F2] Table S3 [href=this file] ).
From a global perspective, we identified genes such as Myelin basic protein ( ) and Alpha-crystallin B ( ) differentially expressed in oligodendrocytes between control and demyelination groups ( Fig 2E [href=#F2] , Table S4 [href=this file] ). We then clustered oligodendrocytes into subgroups ( Fig 2F [href=#F2] , 2G [href=#F2] , Table S5 [href=this file] ) and examined compositional differences across brain regions and demyelination states ( Table S6 [href=this file] ). Genes distinguishing this Oligo_0_MOBP compared to other oligodendrocyte subgroups showed enrichment of expression programs related to cellular morphogenesis and axonogenesis ( Fig S1A [href=#SD2] , Table S7 [href=this file] ), suggesting a myelinating phenotype for this subgroup.
Analysis of these two subgroups showed enrichment of marker genes associated with distress or dysregulation by means of active protein folding, response to temperature stimulus and response to unfolded protein ( Fig S1B [href=#SD2] , S1C [href=#SD2] , Table S8 [href=this file] and S9 [href=this file] ).
We next performed the same analysis on oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs), where we identified subgroups and genes differentially abundant between control and demyelination groups ( Fig 2M [href=#F2] , 2N [href=#F2] , 2O [href=#F2] , Table S10 [href=this file] , S11 [href=this file] ). In our MS donors, we observed higher proportions of subgroup OPC_2_TPST1_ARHGEF3 in NAWM; this subgroup showed enrichment of expression programs related to cell projection organization ( Fig 2P [href=#F2] , S1J [href=#SD2] , Table S12 [href=this file] ).
Taking all microglia together, we identified genes - including and - differentially expressed between control and both demyelination groups ( Fig 3A [href=#F3] , Table S13 [href=this file] ), which also distinguish subgroups of microglia identified by clustering analysis ( Fig 3B [href=#F3] , 3C [href=#F3] , Table S14 [href=this file] ).
GO analysis of genes distinguishing these two clusters pointed to processes such as immune cell differentiation, proliferation, migration and reactive inflammatory response pathways respectively ( Fig S2A [href=#SD3] , S2B [href=#SD3] and Table S15 [href=this file] , S16 [href=this file] ). This suggests the existence of a microglial signature - enriched for genes associated with inflammatory activation ( Fig S2C [href=#SD3] , Table S17 [href=this file] ) - that is present in non-lesional tissue specifically in MS-associated demyelination. By contrast, we observed a fourth microglial cluster, Micro_2_SOCS6_MYO1E, which showed enrichment only in the secondary demyelination group, again in all 3 brain regions ( Fig 3G [href=#F3] , Fig S2D [href=#SD3] , Table S18 [href=this file] ), suggesting that this signature may be a unique hallmark of demyelination accompanying diseases such as AD.
pub_title: Human disease-specific cell signatures in non-lesional tissue in Multiple Sclerosis detected by single-cell and spatial transcriptomics - PMC

Genes distinguishing this Oligo_0_MOBP compared to other oligodendrocyte subgroups showed enrichment of expression programs related to cellular morphogenesis and axonogenesis ( Fig S1A [href=this file] , Table S7 [href=#SD1] ), suggesting a myelinating phenotype for this subgroup.
Analysis of these two subgroups showed enrichment of marker genes associated with distress or dysregulation by means of active protein folding, response to temperature stimulus and response to unfolded protein ( Fig S1B [href=this file] , S1C [href=this file] , Table S8 [href=#SD1] and S9 [href=#SD1] ). This suggests the existence of a microglial signature - enriched for genes associated with inflammatory activation ( Fig S2C [href=this file] , Table S17 [href=#SD1] ) - that is present in non-lesional tissue specifically in MS-associated demyelination. By contrast, we observed a fourth microglial cluster, Micro_2_SOCS6_MYO1E, which showed enrichment only in the secondary demyelination group, again in all 3 brain regions ( Fig 3G [href=#F3] , Fig S2D [href=this file] , Table S18 [href=#SD1] ), suggesting that this signature may be a unique hallmark of demyelination accompanying diseases such as AD.
pub_title: Human disease-specific cell signatures in non-lesional tissue in Multiple Sclerosis detected by single-cell and spatial transcriptomics - PMC

The flowchart of deriving stemness index (mRNAsi) was shown in 
 [this file] . The R code was shown in 
 [this file] . The stemness signatures of the predictive model were shown in 
 [this file] . 
After constructing the predictive model in PCBC stem cell samples and applying it in NJHNCC, we obtained the stemness index ( 
 [this file] ). 
Some 2,925 differential expressed genes were obtained by differential gene expression analysis of RNA-seq data from NJHNCC (Wilcoxon test, FDR <0.05), including 1,294 upregulated genes and 1,631 downregulated genes ( 
 [rid=f2] and 
 [this file] ). 
Unsupervised hierarchical clustering showed that gene modules were obtained ( 
 [rid=f2] ) with soft threshold β = 10 and scale-free R = 0.9 ( 
 [this file] ). 
Details of the eight candidate stemness-related genes were shown in 
 [this file] . 
Also, we explored the relationship of co-expressed genes in the STRING database and it showed that they had significant correlations with other genes ( 
 [rid=f5] and 
 [this file] ). 
In addition, genes in the module that negatively related to stemness were also analyzed and the result showed that they were related to extracellular matrix organization ( 
 [this file] ). 
The expressions of stemness-related genes in HNSCC and adjacent normal oral epithelial tissues were evaluated by qRT-PCR ( 
 [this file] ).

caption: Supplementary Information
context_description:
In hybrid clusters, the 5% sensitivity corresponded to 97.4% specificity in a receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis (AUC = 0.58, Supplementary Fig. 1A [this file] ). 
First, while this threshold (cluster closeness score = 2.56) may permit false-positives if the simulated phosphosites only contain negatives, we observed many of the clusters containing activating or recurrent mutations with cluster closeness scores close to the threshold (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). While hybrid clusters involving driver genes showed a higher density at the higher-score mode, driver gene status did not guarantee high scores (Supplementary Fig. 1B [this file] ). The 5% score threshold showed a sensitivity = 0.17 and specificity = 96.0% in distinguishing hybrid clusters with driver genes (Supplementary Fig. 1C [this file] ). Finally, we examined the score distribution using 200 bins on both the simulated vs. observed clusters, finding multiple peaks and alternative thresholds, for example, thresholding using one of the higher local minima retained only the top 2.28%, or the top 216 clusters (Supplementary Fig. 1D [this file] ). Cluster closeness scores for all identified clusters are provided herein to prioritize a more stringent set of clusters (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). 
HotPho generated a final high-confidence set of 906 mutation-only, 127 phosphosite-only, and 474 hybrid clusters based on the top 5% cluster closeness score threshold (“Methods”, Supplementary Data 1 [this file] ). Phosphosite-only clusters are found in fewer instances: ANXA5, CLIP1, FLNB, GPI, HSPD1, PEBP1, and PTK2 each harbored two (Supplementary Fig. 2A [this file] ). 
The Ensembl transcripts used for mapping of the protein coordinates are described in Supplementary Data 1 [this file] . 
The top hybrid clusters of each protein—identified by the highest cluster closeness score—may span mutations and phosphosites that are far from one another in the linear distance (Fig. 2c [rid=Fig2] , Supplementary Fig. 2B [this file] ). The list of 48 mutations contained mutations of interest in PDE1B (5 mutations), SRSF7 (4 mutations), and PTPN12 p.S275F/C that co-localized with p.S275 and co-clustered with p.S39/p.T40 (Supplementary Data 2 [this file] ). 
Among the 1,255 co-clustered phosphosites, 291 sites directly overlap and 356 sites are proximal (within 2 amino acid residues linearly) to their co-clustered mutations (Supplementary Data 1 [this file] , Fig. 2b [rid=Fig2] ). 
We then examined whether proteins containing hybrid clusters are enriched in specific biological pathways curated by WikiPathways and the NCI-Nature Pathway Interaction Database using Enrichr (Supplementary Data 3 [this file] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] , “Methods”). 
Mapping residues to PFAM domains, we identified 26 PFAM domains significantly enriched for mutations and phosphosites in hybrid clusters when comparing to the background of all mapped mutations and phosphosites (Supplementary Data 4 [this file] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] , “Methods”). Another two top PFAM domains are protein tyrosine kinase and protein kinase domains (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). Notably, some kinase-domain clusters showed conserved mutation/phosphosite patterns across homologs, such as FGFR2 and FGFR3 (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] ). 
We found 29 hybrid clusters containing 90 of these activating mutations in 17 genes, suggesting the functional relevance of the 54 co-clustering phosphosites (Supplementary Data 5 [this file] ). 
We specifically examined these clusters on protein structures (Fig. 3b [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
We calculated the frequency of each of the co-clustering mutations within each of the TCGA cancer cohorts and identified their spatially adjacent phosphosites (Supplementary Data 6 [this file] ). We found that co-clustering phosphosites of the most recurrent mutations aggregate in proteins, including CTNNB1, HRAS, IDH1, KRAS, NRAS, PIK3CA, and TP53 (Fig. 3a [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] ). 
Using the TCGA Reverse Phase Protein Arrays (RPPA) dataset for each of the 33 cancer types, we conducted a differential expression analysis to search for protein/phosphoprotein markers expressed at different levels in carriers of clustered mutations (“Methods”), identifying 24 significant (FDR < 0.05, linear regression) gene-cancer associations (Fig. 4b [rid=Fig4] , Supplementary Data 7 [this file] ). mutations in hybrid clusters are significantly correlated with higher p53 protein expression in 14 cancer types, most strikingly in UCEC, BRCA, COAD, and OV, consistent with the previously reported -effect of functional TP53 missense mutations . 
To further validate these findings, we conducted similar analyses of the mutational impact on protein expression using global proteomics datasets from retrospective and prospective CPTAC cohorts of breast, ovarian, and colorectal cancers (2 cohorts/cancer) each comprised of 78–126 samples (“Methods”, Supplementary Data 8 [this file] , Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ). Other notable findings include that mutations in cluster 1357.1 are associated with high ESR1 in ovarian cancer, whereas mutations in cluster 756.0 (Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] ) are associated with high AKT1 proteins. 
By considering missense mutations (1) directly overlapping phosphosites, (2) proximal to phosphosites, and (3) co-clustering with phosphosites, we noticed that considering co-clustering mutations contribute significantly to the fraction of potentially functional mutations in many cancer genes including , , and (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] ). 
We then examined whether the co-clustered mutations show significant enrichment of activating mutations compared to the other mutations on a gene-by-gene basis (Fig. 5a, b [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Data 9 [this file] ). 
First, using a multivariate logistic regression model corrected for the mutated gene, we found that the number of co-clustering mutations was not significantly associated with the mutation functionality in either the BAF3 ( = 0.91) or MCF ( = 0.40) cell line (Supplementary Fig. 9A [this file] ). But, when adding the phosphosite co-clustering status to the regression model, the mutation functionality was no longer associated with recurrence ( > 0.21), but strongly associated with the co-clustering status in both BAF3 ( = 1.4e−10) and MCF10A ( = 1.5e−4) cell lines (Fig. 5c, d [rid=Fig5] , Supplementary Fig. 9A [this file] ). 
We also obtained similar results when comparing cell lines with co-clustered missense mutations versus other non-synonymous mutations (Supplementary Data 10 [this file] ). 
Of the 1255 co-clustered phosphosites, 259 were detected in at least one of the 5 cohorts (Fig. 6a [rid=Fig6] , Supplementary Data 11 [this file] ). 
Finally, we conducted a systematic literature review of co-clustering phosphosites regulated or implicated in cancer (“Methods”), finding 25 unique phosphosites across 18 proteins that were experimentally linked to cancer (Supplementary Data 12 [this file] ). 
Among the 1255 co-clustering phosphosites, only 25 were previously known to be associated with cancer (Supplementary Data 12 [this file] ). 
Currently, we only observed a handful of examples where a single tumor sample carries both of the co-clustering phosphosites and mutations in existing quantitative phosphoproteomics cohorts, precluding systematic investigations of their correlative relationships (Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] ). 
To resolve the multi-modal distribution of cluster closeness scores, we further compared the score distributions for 299 mutation-enriched cancer driver genes versus other genes using a ROC curve analysis (Supplementary Fig. 1B, C [this file] ). 
We further evaluated the sensitivity, specificity, and ROC curves using different threshold of the Cc score (Supplementary Fig. 1D [this file] ).

Primers were specific for the different genes, and sequences are shown in Supplementary Tab. 4 [this file] . 
The membrane was then placed in a 50-mL tube and incubated over night with the primary antibody (see Supplementary Tab. 3 [this file] ; dissolved in 5 % milk 0.05 % Tween TBS) at 4 °C on a roller bank. The following day, the membrane was washed three times 5 min in 0.05 % Tween TBS, after which it was incubated with the secondary antibody (see Supplementary Tab. 3 [this file] ), also diluted in 5 % milk 0.05 % Tween TBS (1 h, RT, on roller bank). 
The sequences were specific for 3R and 4R and are shown in Supplementary Tab. 4 [this file] . All primer sequences are shown in Supplementary Tab. 4 [this file] . 
The primary antibodies (see Supplementary Tab. 3 [this file] ) were diluted in 5% goat serum 0.1% Triton-X TBS, and the slices incubated overnight at 4°C in a humidified chamber. The following day, slices were washed in TBS three times, followed by incubation with the respective secondary antibodies (see Supplementary Tab. 3 [this file] ), which were diluted in 2% BSA TBS (1h, RT). 
Furthermore, mRNA analysis using NanoString technology and PCR corroborated the absence of murine tau expression in htau-KI mice (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] c, d) and 5xFADxhtau-KI crossbreds (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] b). 
Interestingly, for 3R/4R tau protein, a relative ratio of approx. 1 was observed in 7-month-old mice (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] d, Supplementary Fig. 2 [this file] a–d), resembling the human 3R/4R tau protein ratio. 
The comparison of WT, htau-KI, 5xFAD, and 5xFADxhtau-KI models revealed that a large fraction of variation in gene expression observed between WT and 5xFADxhtau-KI could be attributed to the 5xFAD model (Supplementary Fig. 1 [this file] , Supplementary Tab. 1 [this file] , 2 [this file] ). 
At 7 months, multiple pathways in the 5xFADxhtau-KI model showed a significant enrichment when compared to the 5xFAD model (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] a). Among these pathways, genes in the KEGG oxidative phosphorylation (oxphos) pathway were coordinatively upregulated in the presence of htau-KI (5xFADxhtau-KI) when compared to the 5xFAD model (mmu190, enrichment score= 0.69, adjusted -value= 0.0058) (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] , Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] a). In contrast, genes in the oxphos pathway (hsa190, enrichment score= −0.59, adjusted -value= 0.0025) were downregulated in deceased AD patients from the MSBB cohort when compared to non-demented controls (Supplementary Fig. 3 [this file] b–d) (see also: https://agora.ampadportal.org/genes (https://agora.ampadportal.org/genes) for detailed human gene expression profiles). 
At 13 months of age, multiple pathways, which are linked to extracellular matrix and immune function, are downregulated in the 5xFADxhtau-KI model while the calcium and oxytocin signaling pathways are upregulated when compared to the 5xFAD model (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] a). The ECM-receptor interaction is upregulated (hsa04512, enrichment score= 0.67, FDR-adjusted -value= 0.0088) in the TCX brain region from the Mayo cohort associated with the TCXblue co-expression module (Fig. 3 [rid=Fig3] ) and downregulated in the 5xFADxhtau-KI model (mmu04512, enrichment score= −0.72, FDR-adjusted -value= 0.011) (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] a, b). Among the genes, which showed decreased expression in the 5xFADxhtau-KI model compared to the 5xFAD model, were multiple AD candidate genes (Supplementary Fig. 4 [this file] c), which are significantly upregulated in AD patients compared to controls. is an integrin that facilitates cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, which has been shown to act as a transcriptional hub gene for inflammatory AD modules [ 41 [rid=CR41] ]. has been highlighted as an important hub gene in an integrated proteomic and transcriptomic study in the ROS/MAP cohort [ 42 [rid=CR42] ]. 
Quantification of overall plaque deposition revealed no statistically significant differences in the total plaque area between 5xFAD and 5xFADxhtau-KI at 7 and 13 months of age (Fig. 4 [rid=Fig4] c, Supplementary Fig. 5 [this file] b-f). In addition, the inflammatory phenotype expected for 5xFAD mice could also be seen in 5xFADxhtau-KI crossbreds, but not in htau-KI, as studied by astroglial (GFAP, Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] a, c) and microglial (Iba-1, Supplementary Fig. 6 [this file] b, d) staining. 
Additionally, we analyzed the distance covered by an animal to reach the platform (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] a, b) and swim speed (Supplementary Fig. 7 [this file] c, d) as score for cognitive learning curves as they also reflect the actual spatial learning abilities.

context_description:
The very highest relative modularity density measures are prone to instability as the raw values approach zero, which makes the raw values more reliable for that case (see Supplement [this file] ). 
S 4 [this file] ), or with edge weights between clusters held constant (Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig. S5), see Supplement [this file] for details on these tests. 
Differences in NMI and ARI are due to the large number of unclassified nodes from WGCNA (see Supplement [this file] ). 
Sinai brain bank, see Supplement [this file] ). 
Contrary to their name, the gold-standard cell types may not be independent definitions, as they are sometimes generated by clustering (see Supplement [this file] ). 
Correspondence to ground truth was highly dataset dependent: 3 datasets averaged ~ 10% difference between the methods, while on 4 datasets, SE2 correspondence by ARI was only ~ 50% of Seurat (Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig S7). If the study goal is to mirror the style of classes that have previously been found, then Seurat is a good choice; in contrast, if the application would benefit from discovery of more granular cellular classes, SE2 will more likely produce that type of result (see Supplement [this file] on multiscale results). 
Both SE2 and Louvain/Seurat performance (ARI with ground truth) were systematically affected by preprocessing parameters (R = 0.39, R = 0.28) with both methods being most sensitive to data reduction type (UMAP vs ICA, Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig. 
SE2 is 60% faster the original SE and several times faster than Louvain and Leiden, on fully connected networks (Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig. For details of performance testing and significant caveats to interpreting these, see Supplementary methods [this file] . 
Networks are also generated under three different regimes, where the cross-links between clusters (1) have covarying proportion (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] ) and weights, (2) constant proportion and varying weight (Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig S2), or (3) varying proportion and constant weight (Additional File 1 [this file] : Fig S3).
pub_title: Robust, scalable, and informative clustering for diverse biological networks

The feature with the highest impact was , a newly classified multiclass feature ( Multimedia Appendix 3 [this file] ), followed by , which was the most influential feature in the previous model. 
The third model selected in this study analyzed the progression of skin involvement in PsV by incorporating all available features, including several binary features newly created from multiclass features such as obesity, depression, hypertension, and TNF-α–targeting therapy ( Multimedia Appendix 3 [this file] ). 
Patients were stratified into 2 groups based on their initial BASDAI scores: inconspicuous (BASDAI score of ≤3; 68/129, 52.7%) and conspicuous (BASDAI score of ≥4; 61/129, 47.3%; Multimedia Appendix 3 [this file] ).

pub_title: Optimizing prognosis-related key miRNA-target interactions responsible for cancer metastasis - PMC

title: oncotarget-08-109522-s001.pdf
context_description:
As illustrated by two key miRNA-target interactions, miR-155: ( -value=0.001, log-rank test, Supplementary Figure 1A [href=this file] ) and miR-21: ( -value=0.006, Supplementary Figure 1B [href=this file] ), it seems that key regulatory pairs are responsible for clinical prognosis. In KIRC, the key miRNA-target interactions, such as miR-29a: and miR-17: , are highly predictive of clinical outcome ( -value<0.05, Supplementary Figure 1C [href=this file] and Supplementary Figure 1D [href=this file] ).
While in KIRC, key targets of miRNAs in the low-risk group were mostly enriched in ‘cell death’, ‘cell proliferation’ and ‘vasculogenesis’, those in the high-risk group were mostly enriched in ‘cell adhesion’, ‘cell motion’ and ‘epithelial cell migration’ ( Supplementary Figure 2A [href=this file] ), which is consistent with that KIRC is a typical metabolic disease [ 32 [href=#R32] ].
Key targets of miR-204 in KIRC were specifically enriched in ‘apoptosis’ and ‘programmed cell death’ ( Supplementary Figure 2B [href=this file] ), consistent with inhibition of renal clear cell carcinoma tumor growth [ 38 [href=#R38] ].
Analogously, in KIRC, the top three hallmarks of cancer are ‘sustained angiogenesis’, ‘tissue invasion and metastasis’ and ‘insensitivity to antigrowth signal’ ( Supplementary Figure 2C [href=this file] ). It is of interest to note that a hallmark of metastasis ‘tissue invasion and metastasis’ is significantly influenced by prognosis-related key miRNA-target interactions in ten distinct types of cancer (Figure 3D [href=#F3] , Supplementary Figure 3 [href=this file] ).
It may suggest the important role of key miRNAs in cancer metastasis, since similar results were also observed in KIRC ( Supplementary Figure 2D [href=this file] ).
The results showed significant difference between two groups in terms of PFS ( -value=0.016, log-rank test, Supplementary Figure 4A [href=this file] ) and KPS ( -value=0.024, Fisher’s exact test, Supplementary Figure 4B [href=this file] ). The percentage of GBM patients with (M1) or without (M0) distant metastases showed extremely close to significance ( -value=0.077, Fisher’s exact test, Supplementary Figure 4C [href=this file] ).
Most cancer types (11 out of 16; 68.8%) showed that key miRNA-target interactions remained an independent prognostic signature for survival ( Supplementary Figure 4D [href=this file] ).
We found that in most TCGA cancer types (11 out of 16; 68.8%) key miRNA-target interactions did not provide prognostic value in more than one other cancer type ( Supplementary Figure 5 [href=this file] ).
Interestingly, we found that the combination of key miRNA-target interactions identified in malignant adenocarcinomas including LUAD, STAD and COAD could be an independent predictor for overall survival of another adenocarcinoma PAAD patients, individually ( Supplementary Figure 5 [href=this file] ).

( b)  Body weight (g=grams) of female wild type and transgenic mice at three and six months of age (error bar = SEM, unpaired two-tailed t-test, n=10/group) . (c)  Quantification of Western blots of soluble pS202/pT205 tau as detected by AT8 antibody (error bar = SEM, n=6/group). description: 2  Supplementary  Figure  1:  Characterization  of  TPR50  tau  Transgenic  Mouse  (a)  Body  weight  (g=grams)  of  male  wild  type  and  transgenic  mice  at  three  and  six  months  of  age  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=10/group).  (  b)  Body  weight  (g=grams)  of  female  wild  type  and  transgenic  mice  at  three  and  six  months  of  age  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=10/group)  .  (c)  Quantification  of  Western  blots  of  soluble  pS202/pT205  tau  as  detected  by  AT8  antibody  (error  bar  =  SEM,  n=6/group).  (d)  Quantification  of  Western  blots  of  soluble  total  tau  as  detected  by  Aβ−3  tau  antibody  (error  bar  =  SEM,  n=6/group).  (e)  Quantification  of  Western  blots  of  Sarkosyl-insoluble  pS202/pT205  tau  as  detected  by  AT8  antibody  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=6/group).  (f)  Quantification  of  Western  blots  of  Sarkosyl-insoluble  total  tau  as  detected  by  Aβ−3  tau  antibody  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=6/group).  (g)  Phospho-tau  levels  as  measured  by  ELISA  using  pT231  tau  antibody  at  three  months  (error  bar  =  SEM,  n=6/group).  (h)  Phospho-tau  levels  as  measured  by  ELISA  using  pT231  tau  antibody  at  six  months  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=6/group)  (i)  Brain  weight  (mg)  of  male  wild  type  and  transgenic  mice  at  six  months  of  age.  (error  bar  =  SEM,  unpaired  two-tailed  t-test,  n=6/group).  In  all  the  plots.  the  center  line  represents  the  mean  and  error  bars  showing  SEM.  Supplementary  Figure  2:  Transcriptome-wide  Differential  Gene  Expression  in  Different  Brain  Regions  and  Mouse  Strains  (  a-c  )  2-D  scatterplots  of  the  first  three  principal  components  of  differentially  expressed  (DE)  genes  with  FDR  <0.1  (p  values  obtained  using  linear  regression)  between  wild  type  and  transgenic  in  the  different  brain  regions  indicated.  (  d  )  Scatterplot  showing  the  fold  change  using  qPCR  and  RNA-seq  for  C57  TPR50  transgenic  mice  compared  to  wild-type  controls  (n=6/group,  Pearson  correlation).  (  e  )  Scatterplot  between  p-values  obtained  using  DESeq2  and  linear  regression  model  between  wild-type  and  transgenic  mice  (n=6/group,  Pearson  correlation).  Supplementary  Figure  3:  Differential  Expression  and  Regulators  of  Apoptosis  in  Different  Brain  Regions  and  Mouse  Strains  .  (  a  )  Rank-rank  hypergeometric  overlap  (RRHO)  plots  comparing  wild  type  and  transgenic  gene  expression  in  the  cortex  to  the  hippocampus,  brain  stem  and  cerebellum.  Each  pixel  represents  the  overlap  between  brain  regions,  color-coded  according  to  the  −log10  p-value  of  a  hypergeometric  test.  Scatterplot  of  correlations  between  DE  genes  with  p<0.005  in  the  cortex  (n=36  mice)  as  compared  to  the  hippocampus  (left  panel,  n=36  mice),  brain  stem  (left  panel,  n=36  mice)  and  cerebellum  (right  panel,  n=36  mice).  (  b-i  )  Expression  of  genes  involved  in  positive  regulation  of  apoptosis  (GO:  0043065)  in  transgenic  and  wild  type  mice  in  different  brain  regions,  at  different  time  points  across  strains  (n=6/group,  unpaired  two-tailed  Wilcox  rank  test).  (  i-l  )  Expression  of  genes  involved  in  negative  regulation  of  apoptosis  (GO:  0043066)  in  transgenic  and  wild  type  mice  in  different  brain  regions,  at  different  time  points  across  strains  (n=6/group,  unpaired  two-tailed  Wilcox  rank  test).  (  j  )  Venn  diagram  showing  DE  gene  overlap  (genes  with  p<0.005)  between  brain  regions  (n=6/group).  (  k  )  Barplot  of  the  number  of  DE  genes  with  p<0.005  (n=6/group).  DE  analysis  was  conducted  independently  for  each  brain  region,  mouse  strain  and  time  point.  In  all  the  boxplots,  the  upper  and  lower  lines  represent  the  75th  and  25th  percentiles,  respectively,  while  the  center  line  represents  the  median.  (  l  )  Log  2  fold  change  of  the  top  twenty  most  upregulated  genes  in  the  cerebellum  of  TPR50  transgenic  mice  (all  strains)  and  their  respective  expression  in  the  cortex  (n=6/group).  All  show  opposite  patterns  in  cerebellum  compared  with  cortex,  making  them  potential  protective  changes.  Supplementary  Figure  4:  mRNA  Consensus  Co-expression  Network  Analysis  .  (a)  cWGCNA  dendrogram  showing  the  mRNA  modules  in  the  cortical  samples  of  transgenic  mice  at  6  months.  Color  bars  below  give  information  on  correlation  of  transgenic  condition  of  RNA  integrity  number  (RIN)  with  expression  of  a  particular  gene,  red  is  positive  correlation  and  blue  is  anti-correlation  (n=6/group). In  all  the  boxplots,  the  upper  and  lower  lines  represent  the  75th  and  25th  percentiles,  respectively,  while  the  center  line  represents  the  median.
context_description:
All three F1 crosses share key features of the disease , including decreased survival ( Fig. 1b [rid=F1] ) and body weight ( Supplementary Fig. 1a [this file] – b [this file] ), progressive accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau in the cortex and hippocampus (AT8 staining; Fig. 1c [rid=F1] ), and prominent astrogliosis and microgliosis ( Fig. 1d [rid=F1] – f [rid=F1] ). Consistent with previous reports that FVB mice can be more vulnerable to neurodegeneration, we observed that F1 Tau transgenics on the FVB/C57 (TPR50xFVB/NJ) background had decreased survival and increased pathological tau as compared to the C57/C57 (TPR50xC57BL/6J) and DBA/C57 (TPR50xDBA/2J) progeny ( Fig. 1b [rid=F1] ) ( Supplementary Fig. 1c [this file] – h [this file] ). Importantly, no significant decrease in the weight of any of the affected brain areas was detected in transgenic animals at six months ( Supplementary Fig. 1i [this file] ), consistent with previous data showing no cell loss at this stage . 
The differentially expressed genes from transgenic and wild type mice clearly separate tau mutant from wild type genotypes within affected brain regions ( Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] – c [this file] ), but not in the cerebellum ( Supplementary Fig. 2a [this file] ), and are consistent are across strains ( Supplementary Fig. 2d [this file] , e [this file] ). There was significant overlap in differential expression ( Online Methods [rid=S19] ; Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ) between the cortex and hippocampus, and significant correlation between fold changes in differentially expressed genes (Rank-rank hypergeometric test; p<0.05) from these two regions (R =0.76, slope=0.92, Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). We find lesser, but significant correlation in gene expression between the cortex and brain stem (R =0.33, slope=0.82, Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Consistent with the absence of significant cell loss at six months in this model , positive regulators of apoptosis (GO ID:0043065) do not show significant changes across all 3 strains ( Supplementary Fig. 3b [this file] – e [this file] ) and negative regulators of apoptosis (GO ID :0043066) show modest, more significant changes ( Supplementary Fig. 3f [this file] – i [this file] ).We note that although we do not observe frank apoptosis, we do see evidence for initial activation of cellular pathways associated with inflammation in cerebral cortex by six months, including increases in GFAP and Iba-1 immunoreactivity in cortex ( Fig. 1d [rid=F1] – f [rid=F1] ). 
We observed no significant overlap in gene expression between the cortex and cerebellum ( Supplementary Fig. 3j [this file] – k [this file] ) and no correlation between differentially expressed genes in cortex and cerebellum (R =0.01, slope=0.14, Supplementary Fig. 3a [this file] ). Even more striking is that the expression changes of the top upregulated genes in the cerebellum are reversed in the cortex ( Supplementary Fig. 3l [this file] ), implying that protective changes may potentially occur in the cerebellum, as has been previously suggested . 
To place gene expression changes in a systems level framework, we performed consensus Weighted Gene Co-expression Network Analysis (cWGCNA ) across all three heterozygous F1 mouse strains to identify relationships not observed in only a single background ( Supplementary Fig. 4a [this file] , Supplementary Table 1 [rid=SD3] ). Cell-type enrichment analysis demonstrated that the salmon module is enriched in neuronal markers, the magenta module for oligodendrocyte markers, and the turquoise module for microglial, astrocyte and endothelial markers ( Fig. 2b [rid=F2] ) across multiple different cell type specific gene expression datasets ( Supplementary Fig. 4b [this file] ). Gene ontology (GO) analyses is consistent with the cell type enrichments, showing that the salmon module is enriched for synaptic pathways, magenta for DNA repair and transcription, while the turquoise module is enriched for immune and inflammatory categories ( Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] – d [this file] ). 
Genes correlated highly with phospho-tau levels (R >0.6; Online Methods [rid=S19] ) were found to be significantly enriched in the salmon (42-fold) and turquoise modules (9.5-fold), but not in the magenta and pink modules ( Supplementary Fig. 4e [this file] ). Given the consistent cell type enrichments and strong gene ontology enrichments ( Fig. 2b [rid=F2] , d-g; and Supplementary Fig 4b [this file] – d [this file] ) we relabel the salmon module, the Neurodegeneration-Associated Synaptic (NAS) module, and the turquoise module, the Neurodegeneration-Associated Inflammatory (NAI) module, so as to provide more intuitive names for these core disease-associated modules. 
Moreover, both the NAI and NAS module eigengenes show changes across affected brain regions (cortex, Fig. 2e [rid=F2] , h [rid=F2] ; hippocampus, Supplementary Fig. 4f [this file] – g [this file] ; brain stem, Supplementary Fig. 4h [this file] – i [this file] ) but not cerebellum ( Fig. 2i [rid=F2] , j [rid=F2] ), prior to decreases in brain weight that would be indicative of cell loss ( Supplementary Fig. 1i [this file] ). This is further supported by analysis of expression profiles from sorted neurons and glia from the Tg4510 and PS2APP AD model which show cell intrinsic changes in the NAI and NAS module trajectories ( Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] – d [this file] ). The NAI module is highly preserved in both microglia and astrocytes and significantly upregulated in these populations in transgenics ( Supplementary Fig. 5a [this file] , c [this file] , d [this file] – l [this file] ), while the neuronal NAS module is highly preserved in sorted neurons and downregulated in transgenics ( Supplementary Fig. 5b [this file] , e [this file] – l [this file] ). 
Functional annotation of the NAS module with GO and KEGG terms, confirms its broader relationship to synaptic function ( Fig. 2d [rid=F2] and Supplementary Fig. 4c [this file] ). In contrast, functional annotation of the NAI module highlights pathways associated with astrogliosis and inflammatory changes , including T cell activation and Toll-like receptor signaling pathways ( Fig. 2g [rid=F2] and Supplementary Fig. 4d [this file] ). 
Further analysis of 4 independent datasets from mouse models harboring pathological tau mutations including a replication dataset that we generated using the Tg4510 tau model (Methods, Supplementary Fig 5f [this file] ) confirm the preservation of the NAI and NAS modules ( Supplementary Fig 5e [this file] ), and the expected changes in gene expression early in the disease course ( Supplementary Fig. 5f [this file] - h [this file] , l [this file] ). The NAS and NAI models are highly preserved and their disease associations are maintained and both the NAI and NAS module expression changes occur with similar temporal profiles across each of these models ( Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] , i [this file] – l [this file] ). 
The NAS and NAI modules are dysregulated in patient cortex, but not in cerebellum, both in the previously published microarray-based data and in our newly generated RNA-seq dataset ( Fig. 3a [rid=F3] – d [rid=F3] and Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] , m [this file] – n [this file] ) consisting of both tau-positive and tau-negative FTD ( Fig. 3c [rid=F3] ). Moreover, the NAS module and its disease-trait relationship are preserved in iPSC-derived neurons from human FTD patients carrying GRN mutations ( Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] , o [this file] ). 
We also performed mass-spectrometry-based, label-free, quantitative proteomics in an independent set of GRN-positive and GRN-negative FTD frontal cortex ( Supplementary Fig. 5p [this file] , Supplementary Table 2c [rid=SD4] – d [rid=SD4] , Online Methods [rid=S19] ). 
Examination of RNA sequencing and proteomic post mortem brain datasets from AD patients showed preservation of both the NAI and the NAS modules at the mRNA ( Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] , Fig. 3g [rid=F3] – h [rid=F3] , Supplementary Table 4a [rid=SD6] ), and at the protein level ( Fig. 3i [rid=F3] ). 
We identified two miRNA modules associated with the transgenic condition (Bonferroni corrected P < 0.05, Fig. 4a [rid=F4] , Supplementary Table 3 [rid=SD5] ): the miM12 module that is anti-correlated, and the miM16 module ( Fig. 4b [rid=F4] ), which is positively correlated with the transgenic condition in affected regions, but not cerebellum ( Fig. 4c [rid=F4] and Supplementary Fig. 6a [this file] – e [this file] ). The miM16 module eigengene is strongly anti-correlated with the NAS module eigengene ( Fig. 4d [rid=F4] and Supplementary Fig. 6f [this file] ), and predicted targets of miR-203, an miM16 hub, are highly enriched (see Online Methods [rid=S19] ) in the NAS module ( Fig. 4e [rid=F4] and Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] , h [this file] ). Consistent with its potential regulatory role, miR-203 is robustly upregulated in transgenic mice at six months in disease-affected areas ( Fig. 4f [rid=F4] and Supplementary Fig. 6i [this file] – k [this file] ), and in the frontal cortex in both tau-positive and tau-negative FTD ( Fig. 4g [rid=F4] , h [rid=F4] ). 
To test the predicted causal relationship between miR-203 expression and NAS module down-regulation, we acutely over-expressed miR-203 ( Fig. 5a [rid=F5] ) in primary cortical mouse neuronal cultures ( Online Methods [rid=S19] , Supplementary Fig. 7a [this file] ), observing downregulation of its predicted targets ( Fig. 5b [rid=F5] ) and the NAS module more broadly ( Fig. 5c [rid=F5] , Supplementary Fig. 7b [this file] , Supplementary Table 4a [rid=SD6] ). We further experimentally validated several predicted direct targets of miR-203 ( , , , ) by luciferase reporter assays ( Fig. 5f [rid=F5] ) and western blot (BCL2L2 and VSNL1l; Fig. 5g [rid=F5] , see Supplementary Fig 9 [this file] for uncropped blots). 
To control for potential confounding by supra-physiological over-expression in vitro, we moderately overexpressed miR-203 (approximately 2-fold; Online Methods [rid=S19] ) or a scrambled miRNA control (sc-miRNA) ( Fig. 5h [rid=F5] ) targeting neurons in wild-type mice in vivo ( Supplementary Fig. 7c [this file] – f [this file] ). The NAS module is highly preserved ( Supplementary Fig. 7g [this file] , Supplementary Table 4a [rid=SD6] ) and down-regulated in neurons overexpressing miR-203 after six weeks ( Fig. 5i [rid=F5] ). Strikingly, the level of miR-203 expression correlates remarkably well with downregulation of both miR-203 predicted targets (R =0.81, slope=−2.3; Supplementary Fig. 7h [this file] ) and NAS module genes (R =0.81, slope=−2.2; Supplementary Fig. 7i [this file] ). Furthermore, apoptotic pathways are altered in miR-203-overexpressing neurons (, Figure 5j [rid=F5] , Supplementary Table 4b [rid=SD6] ), confirmed by Casp8 protein expression ( Figure 5k [rid=F5] , Supplementary Fig. 7j [this file] ). Additionally, miR-203 over-expression in one-month-old Tg4510 Tau transgenic cortex ( Supplementary Fig. 8a [this file] – b [this file] ) causes downregulation of predicted miR-203 targets ( Fig. 5l [rid=F5] ), the NAS module ( Fig. 5m [rid=F5] ), a significant increase in CASP8 protein ( Fig. 5n [rid=F5] ) and apoptotic pathways ( Supplementary Fig. 8c [this file] – d [this file] ) and genes involved in calcium signaling and neuroactive ligand receptors ( Supplementary Fig. 8e [this file] – f [this file] ). 
Both short term (6-weeks, Supplementary Fig. 8g [this file] – h [this file] ) and longer term (4-months, Supplementary Fig. 8i [this file] – j [this file] ) inhibition of miR-203 oppose the pathologic transcriptional changes in predicted miR-203 targets ( Supplementary Fig. 8k [this file] , Fig. 5o [rid=F5] ) and the NAS module broadly ( Supplementary Fig. 8l [this file] , Fig. 5p [rid=F5] ) including genes involved in calcium signaling and neuroactive ligand receptor pathways ( Supplementary Fig. 8m [this file] – n [this file] ), and apoptosis ( Fig. 5q [rid=F5] , Supplementary Fig. 8o [this file] – p [this file] ). Reducing miR-203 did not affect phospho-tau immunostaining ( Supplementary Fig. 8q [this file] – r [this file] ), consistent with its acting downstream of tau pathology. C-fos intensity was also significantly increased in mutant neurons expressing the miR-203 TuD construct, as compared to those expressing the control construct ( Fig. 5q [rid=F5] , Supplementary Fig. 8s [this file] , p-value <0.0001), suggesting functional rescue. 
It is noteworthy that modules identified in the initial individual F1 crosses that are not conserved and dysregulated across all three strains, are also not conserved in other mouse models, or human brain ( Supplementary Fig 10a [this file] – c [this file] ), supporting the approach that we have taken. 
As we show, long-term inhibition of miR-203 in the Tg4510 model, while upregulating anti-apoptotic pathways, downregulating pro-apoptotic pathways and increasing neuronal activity as measured by c-fos activation, does not reduce the phospho-tau burden ( Supplementary Fig. 8q [this file] – r [this file] ). 
Summary heatmap of module preservation of all datasets described in Supplementary Fig. 5e [this file] using module definitions from strain-aware network analysis. 
For a full list of enrichments refer to Supplementary Fig. 6g [this file] . 
Uncropped blots are shown in Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] . 
Scriptaid treatment does not alter miR-203 overexpression levels ( Supplementary Fig. 9 [this file] , indicating that the decrease in cell death is not a result of changes in viral infection, miRNA processing or regulation of miR-203 by scriptaid.
pub_title: Identification of evolutionarily conserved gene networks mediating neurodegenerative dementia.

We mixed genomic DNAs derived from transformed lymphoblastoid cell lines of four unrelated individuals at different proportions (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] a and Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. Combining the Mix 1 and Mix 2 datasets to double sequencing coverage only marginally improved sensitivity (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] b and Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. Moreover, MuTect2 and Strelka2, which are designed to detect somatic SNVs that are present in tumors but not matched normal samples, lacked the sensitivity to detect simulated mosaic SNVs shared between two matched samples (Fig. 1 [rid=Fig1] b and Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. 
The resultant reads were uniformly processed using a common workflow (see “ Methods [rid=Sec13] ”) and mapped to the human genome (version GRCh37d5) (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. 
For example, none of the putative SNV calls were identified by each of the six working groups and only three calls were identified by five of six groups (Fig. 2 [rid=Fig2] b and Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S1). 
We subjected 400 putative mosaic SNVs to validation experiments (Tables S 1 [this file] & S 2 [rid=MOESM2] ). 
Finally, to verify the validation status, we performed droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) experiments for thirteen calls (Additional file 1 [this file] : Table S3). 
Moreover, consistent with previous data [ 17 [rid=CR17] ], the SNV mutation spectrum was dominated by C>T transitions (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. 
Finally, 14/29 putative mosaic SNVs were located within regions of the genome containing germline copy number gains, leading to < 0.5 VAFs (Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig. 
By comparison, bona fide validated mosaic SNVs were detected as alternative reads on a single haplotype, giving the appearance of three haplotype states (i.e., the two parental haplotypes plus a “third” haplotype containing the somatic SNV on a single parental haplotype; Additional file 1 [this file] : Fig.
